TITLE: 'I am struggling all alone,' says a widowed Ethiopian mother of 6. Now there's hope
SUMMARY: After months of disruption in a massive national feeding effort by global groups, there's a scramble to digitally register more than 6 million Ethiopians to make sure food aid goes to those in need.

TITLE: 'Mr. Greedy,' a prolific penguin dad, has died at age 33
SUMMARY: Mr. Greedy, a beloved member of the Maryland Zoo, was a prolific breeder who helped boost the endangered African penguin population. He died following an age-related health decline, the zoo said.

TITLE: Jazz historian and critic Dan Morgenstern dies at 94
SUMMARY: Over the course of seven decades, Morgenstern helmed major jazz magazines, wrote books, produced concerts, won multiple Grammys, taught college and oversaw one of the world's largest jazz archives.

TITLE: Jannik Sinner beats Taylor Fritz to win U.S. Open, weeks after doping exoneration
SUMMARY: No.1-ranked Sinner, of Italy, prevented Taylor Fritz from ending the American major tennis title drought, less than three weeks after word emerged of Sinner's two positive drug tests.

TITLE: GOP report on Afghanistan withdrawal faults Biden and could add fuel to presidential debate
SUMMARY: House Foreign Affairs Committee report claims the Biden administration prioritized "optics" over safety. Democrats, the minority on the panel, reject the findings as relying on "cherry-picked" testimony.

TITLE: A Filipino preacher on the run from sexual abuse charges surrenders
SUMMARY: Apollo Quiboloy, accused of sexual abuse and human trafficking in the Philippines and similar charges in the United States, surrendered Sunday to authorities, officials said.

TITLE: A Miami-Dade officer is put on leave after Dolphins star Tyreek Hill is detained
SUMMARY: Hill was pulled over near the stadium for a traffic violation. The officers have been condemned for their use of force. The police department says it will review body camera footage.

TITLE: Dozens dead in Vietnam from Typhoon Yagi flooding, state media report
SUMMARY: Typhoon Yagi was the strongest typhoon to hit Vietnam in decades, with winds up to 92 mph. The country’s meteorological agency warns continuing downpours could cause floods and landslides.

TITLE: Are greedy companies to blame for grocery inflation? We looked at the data
SUMMARY: Many shoppers blame stores and manufacturers for supermarket inflation. But what do the companies' finances tell us?

TITLE: Hair and skin care products expose kids to hormone disrupting chemicals, study finds
SUMMARY: A new study links the recent use of hair oils, lotions and other personal care products with higher levels of phthalates in children. The hormone-disrupting chemicals are a health concern for kids.

TITLE: Ex-Memphis officers face trial in death of Black motorist Tyre Nichols
SUMMARY: Jury selection begins Monday in the federal civil rights trial of three former Memphis police officers charged in the 2023 beating death of Black motorist Tyre Nichols.

TITLE: The political 'flip-flop' attack doesn't always pack a punch for voters
SUMMARY: Ahead of Tuesday's presidential debate, both Vice President Harris' and former President Donald Trump's campaigns accuse the other of flip-flopping.

TITLE: How Harris' past debates set her up for sparring with Trump
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris has used debates as turning points throughout her political career. On Tuesday, she faces her biggest debate challenge yet.

TITLE: Cabernet is the most popular red wine in the U.S. Can it endure climate change?
SUMMARY: Bold cabernet sauvignon wines made Napa Valley famous. Now, hotter temperatures are starting to damage the grapes, so some wineries are starting to experiment.

TITLE: Harris and Trump debate in Philadelphia tomorrow night. Here’s what you need to know
SUMMARY: The ABC News presidential debate will be the first time Vice President Harris and former President Donald Trump face off ahead of the 2024 election. Here's what to expect.

TITLE: California farmers turn to agave amid drought conditions and climate change
SUMMARY: Farmers in California are trying to plant crops that don't require a lot of water. Some are turning to growing agave as a response to a warming state.

TITLE: France waves farewell to its sporting summer at the Paralympics closing ceremony
SUMMARY: The event and its dance party atmosphere lowered the curtain on successful back-to-back Games that captivated fans. Paris raised the bar high for future host cities, including Los Angeles in 2028.

TITLE: Alleged shooter's mom warned Ga. school. And, opposition leader flees Venezuela
SUMMARY: The mother of the alleged shooter at Apalachee High School warned officials the morning of the shooting. Here's how administrators responded. And, Venezuela's opposition leader has fled the country.

TITLE: 'Colored Television' is an ungentle satire set in post-post-racial America
SUMMARY: Danzy Senna's new novel is an exhilarating yet poignant riff on the struggling artist as a wannabe middle-aged sellout. The writing is endlessly quotable and meaningfully provocative.

TITLE: Team USA finished 3rd in the Paralympic medal count. Here are the highlights
SUMMARY: The U.S. placed third in the overall medal count, behind China and Great Britain. Here's a look at some of Team USA's athletic accomplishments, from winning streaks to historic firsts.

TITLE: Tropical Storm Francine forms in the Gulf of Mexico, with its sights on Louisiana
SUMMARY: Tropical Storm Francine has formed in the Gulf of Mexico and is expected to become a hurricane before it reaches the U.S. Gulf Coast on Wednesday.

TITLE: Florida’s coral reefs are still ailing but doing better
SUMMARY: A year after the worst coral bleaching ever recorded, Florida's reefs are slowly recovering. Despite elevated ocean temperatures, scientists say this summer they didn’t see significant bleaching.

TITLE: How one family of Afghan refugees is adjusting to their new life in Maine
SUMMARY: People fleeing violence and persecution can be haunted by their traumas for a long time, even after they have found safety in a new place. And children are particularly vulnerable. Rhitu Chatterjee has  the story of  a boy who fled Afghanistan and has recently settled in Maine.

TITLE: Hungry for new podcasts? Here are 8 episodes about how climate change affects our food
SUMMARY: Add these episodes to your listening rotation during the NPR Network's Climate Solutions Week, where we're dedicated to stories and conversations about the search for climate solutions.

TITLE: Princess Kate completes chemotherapy treatment for cancer
SUMMARY: The Princess of Wales announced earlier this year she had been diagnosed with an unspecified form of cancer.

TITLE: 'After Midnight' host Taylor Tomlinson is ready to joke about her bipolar II. Mostly
SUMMARY: Tomlinson was initially unsure about sharing her bipolar II diagnosis on stage. But, she says, "I got such amazing feedback from people who had been struggling with their mental health."

TITLE: Who is Apollo Carreon Quiboloy, the pastor on the FBI Most Wanted List?
SUMMARY: U.S. prosecutors allege the pastor illegally funneled money to his church  in the Philippines. They also say he victimized minors and young women, requiring them to perform "night duty."

TITLE: Tropical Storm Francine strengthens in the Gulf of Mexico, with its sights on Louisiana
SUMMARY: Tropical Storm Francine has strengthened in the Gulf of Mexico and is expected to become a hurricane before it reaches the U.S. Gulf Coast on Wednesday.

TITLE: Afghan Women's Musical Protest
SUMMARY: The ruling Taliban in Afghanistan issued a sweeping morality law in August. Among other things, it bans women's voices outside the home: no laughing, speaking loudly or singing. Afghan women outside the country are protesting the restriction by posting videos of themselves singing. We hear from some of them.

TITLE: With pedestrian fatalities mounting, regulators propose tougher vehicle design rules
SUMMARY: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is proposing new regulations for vehicle design intended to protect pedestrians in response to the rising number of fatalities on U.S. roads.

TITLE: Whatever happened to ... the Brazilian besties creating an mRNA vaccine as a gift to the world
SUMMARY: NPR's coverage of their effort to invent an mRNA vaccine that would be free for all countries to manufacture brought them an award for altruism in health. We checked in on their progress.

TITLE: U.S. urges Israel to swiftly investigate killing of American woman in West Bank
SUMMARY: The State Department urged Israel to move quickly to investigate the death of a U.S. woman during a protest against Israeli settlements in the West Bank last week. Eyewitnesses said she was shot in the head by Israeli forces policing the protest. Israeli authorities have said they are investigating the incident.

TITLE: Bodycam footage shows Miami-Dade Police forcibly handling Dolphins star Tyreek Hill
SUMMARY: Less than a minute after the first words were exchanged between officers and Hill, an officer roughly pulled Hill from the car and forced him to the ground. Hill was cited for careless driving.

TITLE: Everything to know about the new iPhone 16, AirPods and Apple's AI features
SUMMARY: Apple unveiled new models of its iPhone, AirPods and Apple Watch — most of which will be available in stores later this month.

TITLE: Native-led suicide prevention program focuses on building community strengths
SUMMARY: A research group is testing a new suicide prevention model in rural Alaska Native villages: supporting cultural activities that strengthen community bonds and a sense of shared purpose.

TITLE: Dozens killed from an Israeli strike in a Gaza humanitarian zone, Palestinians say
SUMMARY: Tuesday's strike was among the deadliest strikes yet in a sprawl of crowded tent camps along the Gaza coast that Israel designated as a humanitarian zone for hundreds of thousands of civilians.

TITLE: Big Lots is closing stores and filing for bankruptcy
SUMMARY: The U.S. discount retail chain said its customers will still be able to earn and redeem rewards, as well as use gift cards and store credit cards.

TITLE: The Polaris Dawn spacewalk is SpaceX’s ‘risky adventure’
SUMMARY: New spacesuits, untested astronauts, and a lot that can go wrong make this five-day mission unusually complex, but with a potentially great reward.

TITLE: 'I can poke fun at all sides': Harris and Trump impressionists prep for debate night
SUMMARY: Can impressions and satire shift voters? And how do the comedians think about their role? We put these questions to Harris and Trump impressionists.

TITLE: The Harris campaign takes its attacks against Trump over abortion on the road
SUMMARY: While former President Donald Trump tries to moderate his message on abortion, Vice President Harris’ campaign is warning voters that another Trump administration would threaten access to reproductive healthcare.

TITLE: Listen to NPR's live coverage of the ABC News Presidential Debate Simulcast
SUMMARY: NPR will offer live coverage, including live updates online, of the ABC News Presidential Debate Simulcast on Tuesday. Tune in to NPR's live on-air coverage starting at 9 p.m. ET.

TITLE: Indiana's cellphone ban means less school drama. But students miss their headphones
SUMMARY: Weeks into a new school year, students miss being able to listen to music, but teachers say the cellphone ban is making their jobs easier.

TITLE: Winter crabbing strained Chesapeake Bay’s blue crab population. It may soon resume
SUMMARY: After a 16-year prohibition, a group of Virginia watermen voted to reinstate winter crab dredging. Many argue the decision puts the blue crab’s fragile population in jeopardy.

TITLE: Trump likes to attack Harris' native California. Its politicians say bring it on
SUMMARY: The GOP nominee has trained his eye even more squarely on the Golden State and its progressive record -- a line of attack he’s likely to lean into at tonight’s debate with Vice President Harris.

TITLE: How you could own the Iron Throne or Jon Snow's sword from 'Game of Thrones'
SUMMARY: More than 2,000 items, like Jon Snow’s sword and the Iron Throne, from the iconic HBO series will be auctioned off in October. Here’s what’s for sale.

TITLE: NPR poll shows why the stakes are so high for Harris and Trump in the debate
SUMMARY: A lot of people say they'll tune in Tuesday night to the first presidential debate between former President Donald Trump and Vice President Harris, according to an NPR/PBS News/Marist poll.

TITLE: Tony Blair urges leaders to ignore 'waves of populist opinion'
SUMMARY: Tony Blair's <em>On Leadership: Lessons for the 21st Century

TITLE: Jordanian voters go to polls amid fears of a wider war
SUMMARY: For the first time, political parties in Jordan are enabled to play a bigger role, relying on their platforms, amid fears of a wider war in the region.

TITLE: Trump and Harris will meet face-to-face for the first time on the debate stage
SUMMARY: Trump and Harris didn't directly interact while he was in the White House and she was in the Senate. She debated fellow vice presidential candidate Mike Pence in 2020.

TITLE: These bakers want to make your bread tastier — with climate-resilient wheat
SUMMARY: A team of scientists and bakers in the Pacific Northwest is searching for ways to make whole wheat bread resilient to a warming world — and more delicious.

TITLE: Bank of America raises minimum hourly pay to $24, as tellers flee the industry
SUMMARY: Bank of America will pay hourly workers at least $24 per hour — a big jump from early 2019, when it paid $15 per hour. It has launched a series of pay raises as the industry struggles to fill bank teller jobs.

TITLE: Indian migrants drive surge in northern U.S. border crossings
SUMMARY: Unauthorized crossings through the U.S. northern border have surged due to an influx of Indian migrants. Many leave Canada in search of better economic opportunities.

TITLE: Guide to vital Harris-Trump debate. And, bodycam vid shows NFL star's traffic stop
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris and former President Donald Trump face off tonight in their one-and-only scheduled debate. And, police bodycam video of NFL star Tyreek Hill's shows escalated traffic stop.

TITLE: Indiana's cellphone ban means less school drama. But students miss their headphones
SUMMARY: Weeks into a new school year, students miss being able to listen to music, but teachers say the cellphone ban is making their jobs easier.

TITLE: Life coach or therapist? Know the differences
SUMMARY: There's multi-billion dollar market in the U.S. for life and health coaching. Many Americans are looking for alternatives to traditional mental health care. But unlike therapy, coaching is unregulated.

TITLE: Constitutional sheriffs wield unchecked power across America, journalist says
SUMMARY: Jessica Pishko says a group of sheriffs have become a flashpoint in the current politics of toxic masculinity, guns, white supremacy and rural resentment. Her book is The Highest Law in the Land.

TITLE: Regenerative agriculture is sold as a climate solution. Can it do all it says?
SUMMARY: Governments and industries are pouring billions of dollars into so-called “regenerative agriculture”. But while scientists say some of these farming practices do reduce planet heating pollution, for others the science is less clear.

TITLE: They won their immigration cases. But months later, they still await release
SUMMARY: Immigrant rights groups say ICE has a pattern of keeping immigrants detained for months, and even years, after they have won their immigration cases, putting a toll on them and their families.

TITLE: JD Vance spreads debunked claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets
SUMMARY: Local police say they’ve seen no evidence of crimes against pets alleged by Vance and GOP allies. The claims appear to have been spread by a neo-Nazi group before gaining a wider audience online.

TITLE: Mexico is on the verge of changing its constitution. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: The constitutional reform is controversial because it would completely remake Mexico's judiciary. One side says it would end corruption, the other that it would end judicial independence.

TITLE: Climate Solutions Week: The future of food
SUMMARY: Climate change is affecting our food, and our food is affecting the climate. NPR is dedicating a week to stories and conversations about the search for solutions, from how we farm to what we cook to reducing food waste.

TITLE: Man accused of killing a Ugandan Olympian by setting her on fire, dies of burn wounds
SUMMARY: Fellow athletes say that the tragic death of Rebecca Cheptegei, who was reportedly set on fire, highlights an unsettling trend of violence against female runners in particular and women overall.

TITLE: A Delta plane's wing damages another airliner on Atlanta airport runway
SUMMARY: The Federal Aviation Administration says it will investigate the incident, in which no injuries were reported. Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines says it is working to re-accommodate passengers on both flights.

TITLE: An Israeli strike on a Gaza humanitarian zone kills at least 19
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said it was targeting a Hamas command and control center in al-Muwasi, west of Khan Younis, and killed three Hamas commanders in the strike. Hamas did not confirm the deaths.

TITLE: Francine takes aim at Louisiana, where it's expected to hit as a hurricane
SUMMARY: Residents are being urged to finish any storm preparations. Francine is expected to bring storm surge, strong winds, heavy rainfall and flash flooding to Louisiana and parts of Mississippi and Texas.

TITLE: Cooking for the most powerful person in the world
SUMMARY:
There's an old line: "Tell me what you eat and I'll tell you who you are?" Well if it's true, then Cristeta Comerford knows the last five Presidents better than almost anyone.

She just retired after nearly 30 years as White House chef. Comerford cooked for Presidents from Clinton to Biden...making everything from family snacks to state dinners.

She is the first woman and the first person of color to hold the serve in that job.

She reflects on her groundbreaking role, and what she's learned from cooking for some of the most powerful people in the world.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Mauricio Pochettino is named the new coach of the U.S. men's national soccer team
SUMMARY: The Argentinian manager who has led some of Europe's biggest clubs will now take over the U.S. men's squad with less than two years to go before the U.S. co-hosts the FIFA World Cup in 2026.

TITLE: Francine becomes a hurricane as it approaches Louisiana
SUMMARY: Residents are being urged to finish storm preparations. Francine is expected to bring heavy rainfall and flash flooding to Louisiana, Mississippi, southern Alabama and the western Florida Panhandle.

TITLE: Trump repeats the false claim that Democrats support abortion 'after birth' in debate
SUMMARY: In Tuesday's presidential debate, former President Donald Trump again falsely claimed that Democrats support abortions "after birth" and "executing" babies.

TITLE: What to know about Project 2025, as Harris hits hit Trump over the controversial plan
SUMMARY: Vice President Kamala Harris quickly attacked former President Donald Trump on his association with the architects of Project 2025 in the presidential debate on Tuesday night.

TITLE: Who is Laura Loomer, the far-right activist who flew with Trump to the debate?
SUMMARY: Loomer is known for promoting conspiracy theories as well as anti-immigrant and anti-Muslim views.

TITLE: Taylor Swift endorses Kamala Harris in Instagram post after debate
SUMMARY: In an Instagram post after the presidential debate on Tuesday night, Taylor Swift said she was voting for Kamala Harris.

TITLE: Trump points to Hungary's Viktor Orbán as example of his support from foreign leaders
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump cited his close ties to Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán to counter attacks by Vice President Harris in Tuesday night's presidential debate that world leaders are “laughing” at Trump.

TITLE: What to know about Project 2025, as Harris hits Trump over the controversial plan
SUMMARY: Vice President Kamala Harris quickly attacked former President Donald Trump on his association with the architects of Project 2025 in the presidential debate on Tuesday night.

TITLE: Kamala Harris is a gun owner — but she's still a proponent of stricter gun laws
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris cited the fact she was a gun owner in Tuesday night's presidential debate, in a move designed to shut down suggestions from former President Donald Trump that she wants to “confiscate your guns.”

TITLE: Facial expressions spoke volumes when mics were muted in the presidential debate
SUMMARY: In a presidential debate, the split screen shot of the candidates — with one candidate speaking and the other reacting non-verbally — can easily become the story of the debate.

TITLE: The stereotype of immigrants eating dogs and cats is storied — and vitriolic as ever
SUMMARY: Immigration was always going to be part of Tuesday night’s presidential debate. More surprising was that the conversation veered into bizarre falsehoods about migrants eating pet dogs and cats.

TITLE: NPR fact checked the Harris-Trump presidential debate. Here's what we found
SUMMARY: From the economy to immigration and abortion, NPR looks at what the candidates said and adds context.

TITLE: Taylor Swift endorses Kamala Harris in Instagram post after the debate
SUMMARY: In an Instagram post after the presidential debate on Tuesday night, Taylor Swift said she was voting for Kamala Harris.

TITLE: The debate between Harris and Trump wasn’t close — and 4 other takeaways
SUMMARY: Tuesday’s debate between the current vice president and former president was a clear contrast from the June debate that forced President Biden from the race.

TITLE: 5 good habits to keep you out of credit card debt
SUMMARY: Stay on top of your monthly payments and avoid costly fees and interest charges with these smart credit card strategies.

TITLE: After the debate, Harris, with Biden, and Trump will commemorate 9/11 anniversary
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris will join President Biden on the anniversary of the Sept. 11 with visits to all of the crash sites. Former President Donald Trump will also travel to New York and Pennsylvania.

TITLE: How Memphis became a battleground over Elon Musk’s xAI supercomputer
SUMMARY: A massive project headed by Elon Musk in Memphis, Tenn., to power AI has moved at breakneck speed. But it's stirring controversy around pollution emissions. The EPA says it’s looking into it.

TITLE: Fearing the worst, schools deploy armed police to thwart gun violence
SUMMARY: Armed officers on campus could speed police response to gun violence. But there is scant research to support this strategy, and studies about racial bias raise other concerns about police in schools.

TITLE: 'The Bibi Files.' Benjamin Netanyahu fails to block documentary from screening
SUMMARY: An Israeli court this week rejected a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to block a documentary about his legal troubles from screening at a Canadian film festival.

TITLE: Is getting food delivered worse for the climate? Sometimes it’s better
SUMMARY: From meal kits to grocery service to restaurant delivery, we look at the carbon footprint of convenient food and the choices people can make to try to reduce it. Sometimes there are trade-offs.

TITLE: Russian publishers in exile release books the Kremlin would ban
SUMMARY: In Vladimir Putin’s Russia, writing about the war in Ukraine, the church or LGBTQ+ life could land you in jail. A new organization helps authors publish books in Russian they couldn't back home.

TITLE: Fact-checking the Trump-Harris debate. And, food delivery could help the environment
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris and former President Donald Trump faced off last night on several hot topic issues. NPR fact-checked the claims made. And, how food delivery could be environmentally friendly.

TITLE: 2 artists make flower altars for grieving communities after mass shootings
SUMMARY: Two California artists help grieving communities build floral alters in memory of mass shooting victims. Their latest stop is a high school in Winder, Ga.

TITLE: Flood sweeps away a hamlet in Vietnam as death toll after typhoon rises to 155
SUMMARY: A flash flood swept away an entire hamlet in northern Vietnam, killing 30 people and leaving dozens missing as deaths from Typhoon Yagi and its aftermath climbed to 155.

TITLE: Mammograms will better explain what it means to have dense breasts
SUMMARY: Nearly half of women over 40 have dense breasts, which raises their risk of breast cancer.  Mammograms should now include an assessment of breast tissue density.

TITLE: Inflation falls to its lowest level in more than 3 years. Here’s what that means
SUMMARY: Consumer prices in August were up 2.5% from a year ago — the smallest annual increase since February 2021. Falling inflation clears the way for the Federal Reserve to start cutting interest rates next week — likely by a quarter percentage point.

TITLE: Taylor Swift has endorsed Kamala Harris for president — will it matter?
SUMMARY: Swift wrote on Instagram, "I need to be very transparent about my actual plans for this election as a voter." How much sway do stars really have when it comes to putting the next president in the White House?

TITLE: Secretary of State Antony Blinken shows support in Kyiv visit
SUMMARY: Blinken and  British Foreign Secretary David Lammy are meeting with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who has been pressing the White House to lift its restrictions on long-range missiles.

TITLE: Hurricane Francine is predicted to make landfall west of New Orleans
SUMMARY: The storm became a hurricane Tuesday night; its maximum sustained winds are now topping 90 mph as it heads toward the Louisiana coast.

TITLE: Can eating less beef and dairy help save the Colorado River?
SUMMARY: Nearly half of the water drawn from the Colorado River goes to feed for beef and dairy cows. Researchers say modest changes in American diets could help farmers use less water — and help the climate.

TITLE: The Central Park 5 are exonerated. Trump doesn't seem to think so
SUMMARY: Following the 1989 brutal assault of a New York jogger, the former president took out full-page ads calling for the return of the death penalty. He refuses to apologize to the now Exonerated five.

TITLE: What Musk's Twitter takeover could tell us about a possible government appointment
SUMMARY: After buying Twitter in 2022, Elon Musk instituted sweeping changes — including rebranding the social media platform as "X." Authors Kate Conger and Ryan Mac recount the takeover in <em>Character Limit.

TITLE: Wall Street investors think Trump lost the debate, too
SUMMARY: Shares in former President Trump’s company plunged the day after his debate with Vice President Harris.

TITLE: At the debate, Harris made climate change a pocketbook issue
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris said the economic costs of climate change are already clear, with homeowners facing skyrocketing insurance prices.

TITLE: Secretary of State Antony Blinken reiterates support for Ukraine in Kyiv visit
SUMMARY: Blinken and  British Foreign Secretary David Lammy met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who wants the White House to lift restrictions on long-range missiles, and announced more aid.

TITLE: Hurricane Francine brings the rain, with landfall predicted west of New Orleans
SUMMARY: The storm's hurricane-force winds will start hitting the Louisiana coast on Wednesday afternoon, forecasters say. Francine has prompted evacuations and a state of emergency.

TITLE: A venture capital grant program for Black women officially ends after court ruling
SUMMARY: Attorneys representing conservative activist Edward Blum and the Atlanta-based Fearless Fund wrote that both parties “have settled,” asking the court to permanently dismiss the case.

TITLE: Twelve Years in an Iranian Prison for a Punctuation Mark
SUMMARY: It's been two years since the death of a woman in the custody of Iran's morality police led to protests across the country. The brutal government crackdown that followed continues today- with artists, journalists and activists targeted. NPR's Jackie Northam brings us the voices of some of those affected.

TITLE: During Tuesday's debate, Harris was in command; Trump was incoherent
SUMMARY:
Vice President Kamala Harris was dominant during Tuesday's presidential debate in Philadelphia. Former President Donald Trump struggled to stay on topic and a times sounded incoherent. With the race to the White House neck and neck will this debate make a difference?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: An undecided swing state voter watched the debate. It moved the needle
SUMMARY: Cameron Lewellen of Georgia headed into Tuesday's debate one of the small but potentially key slice of voters who are undecided about the presidential election. After, his vote is in sharper focus.

TITLE: Alberto Fujimori, ex-president of Peru who was convicted of human rights abuses, dies
SUMMARY: Alberto Fujimori, whose decade-long presidency began with righting Peru’s economy and defeating a brutal insurgency only to end in a disgrace, has died. He was 86.

TITLE: He's in a New York prison. Yet a judge let him stay on a U.S. House ballot — in Alaska
SUMMARY: A fringe candidate who's never been to Alaska and is currently in federal prison in New York is set to appear on the general election ballot for Alaska’s lone U.S. House seat, after a judge’s ruling.

TITLE: Hanif Abdurraqib is a 'genius.' His friends aren't impressed
SUMMARY:
Hanif Abdurraqib's writing has earned him a MacArthur "genius" grant. His most recent book, There's Always This Year: On Basketball and Ascension, landed a spot on Barack Obama's summer reading list. But those accolades don't matter to him as much as being a good friend and neighbor. Abdurraqib talks to Rachel about a youth spent unhoused and incarcerated, and the zen of making mixtapes.

To listen sponsor-free, access bonus episodes and support the show, sign up for Wild Card+ at plus.npr.org/wildcard

TITLE: Francine weakens as it moves inland after winds cause widespread blackouts
SUMMARY: Hundreds of thousands of power outages were reported in Louisiana and Mississippi early Thursday as residents in the region braced for possible flooding as Tropical Storm Francine moved inland.

TITLE: Protections for minority voters are at the center of a Florida redistricting case
SUMMARY: Voting rights groups challenging the state congressional map want the Florida Supreme Court to reinstate a district that gave Black voters in one region the chance to elect their preferred candidate.

TITLE: She couldn't go to her daughter's graduation, so the hospital brought it to her
SUMMARY: In 2014, Susan Kahn was in the hospital with terminal cancer, unable to attend her daughter's high school graduation. So the hospital staff brought the celebration to her.

TITLE: What does a busy president want to eat? This White House chef has the answer
SUMMARY: You know that old line, "Tell me what you eat and I'll tell you who you are"? If that's true, then Cristeta Comerford knows the last five presidents of the United States better than almost anyone.

TITLE: WATCH LIVE: SpaceX Polaris astronauts conduct the first-ever private spacewalk
SUMMARY: An internet entrepreneur and a SpaceX engineer are on their way to becoming the first private astronauts to walk in space.

TITLE: Schools are putting vape detectors in bathrooms -- paid for by Juul
SUMMARY: Some districts are using money from a $1.7 billion legal settlement against e-cigarette manufacturer Juul Labs to pay for the high-tech devices. But there are critics and also privacy concerns.

TITLE: These small Black-owned farms are growing crops with the climate in mind
SUMMARY: Across the Gulf South, small Black-owned farms are finding ways to use climate-friendly practices to grow crops while also addressing long-standing injustices.

TITLE: Sustainable eating habits that can help the environment without taking over your life
SUMMARY: What we eat plays a role in the health of our environment. Here are some things to consider when trying to make doable changes to improve your impact without breaking the bank.

TITLE: Afghan women sing to protest a law that orders them to keep quiet
SUMMARY: A new morality law is full of restrictions. No neckties for men. Photos cannot be reproduced. The harshest rules are for women — who are singing out on social media to protest the ban on singing.

TITLE: A rare look inside war-torn Sudan. And, the data behind grocery inflation.
SUMMARY: NPR gets a rare look inside war-torn Sudan, where millions are displaced and struggling for survival. And, we examine new data on why grocery prices remain high.

TITLE: Whatever happened to ... the global effort to wipe out cervical cancer with a vaccine?
SUMMARY: Now that the World Health Organization has endorsed a one-dose vaccine, global health groups are amping up their effort to inoculate the world's girls. How are they doing?

TITLE: SpaceX Polaris Dawn astronauts conduct the first-ever private spacewalk
SUMMARY: An internet entrepreneur and a SpaceX engineer have become the first private astronauts to walk in space.

TITLE: Jon Bon Jovi helps talk a woman off the ledge of a bridge while filming a music video
SUMMARY: Bon Jovi spotted a woman on the ledge of the pedestrian bridge where his crew was filming in Nashville late Tuesday. The singer and a team member helped her over the railing and back to safety.

TITLE: She couldn't go to her daughter's graduation, so the hospital brought it to her
SUMMARY: In 2014, Susan Kahn was in the hospital with terminal cancer, unable to attend her daughter's high school graduation. So the hospital staff brought the celebration to her.

TITLE: 14 pro-Trump electors linked to efforts to reverse his 2020 loss are back for 2024
SUMMARY: The return of 14 Republican presidential electors linked to efforts to reverse Donald Trump’s 2020 loss raises questions about what they will do if Trump loses again in their states.

TITLE: A'ja Wilson breaks the WNBA's single-season scoring record and eyes another milestone
SUMMARY: The Las Vegas Aces star surpassed the previous mark of 939 points set by Jewell Loyd in 2023. Wilson could potentially be the first WNBA player to reach 1,000 points in a year.

TITLE: The U.N. says 6 staff were killed in an Israeli strike on a Gaza school
SUMMARY: The U.N. relief agency for Palestinian refugees in the Gaza Strip said its employees were among 18 people killed in an Israeli airstrike on a school. Israel said the school was being used by Hamas.

TITLE: NYC cultural institutions split with staff over wearing keffiyehs, Palestine solidarity
SUMMARY: Nearly a dozen arts workers in New York City have recently left their jobs or been fired over conflict with their employers about expressing solidarity with Palestinian suffering.

TITLE: How a California county got PFAS out of its drinking water
SUMMARY: Water utilities across the country will have to comply with EPA limits on "forever chemicals" in drinking water by 2029. Orange County, Calif., got a head start.

TITLE: Harvey Weinstein indicted on more sex crimes charges ahead of New York retrial
SUMMARY: Weinstein, 72, underwent emergency heart surgery Monday. The indictment will remain under seal until Weinstein's arraignment, which could happen as early as Sept. 18.

TITLE: Trump must comply with gag order in New York after appeal dismissed
SUMMARY: New York's highest court on Thursday dismissed an appeal from former President Donald Trump to lift the remaining gag order in his hush money case.

TITLE: How Democrats and Republicans are gearing up for a post-election legal fight
SUMMARY: Trump has claimed that the only way he can lose on election day is if there’s voter fraud. New York Times reporter Nick Corasaniti explains the battle over the ballot box and post-election results.

TITLE: Swift sweeps, Chiles gets her bronze and other highlights from a star-studded VMAs
SUMMARY: The 40th MTV Video Music Awards celebrated today’s biggest stars and songs, as well as iconic moments from its own history. Here are some of the night's best moments and biggest winners.

TITLE: Keurig misled the public over claims its K-Cup pods are 100% recyclable, the SEC says
SUMMARY: Keurig agreed to pay $1.5 million in penalties — without admitting guilt or denying the SEC's findings that the K-Cup pod producer made inaccurate claims regarding the recyclability of those pods.

TITLE: Four private astronauts conduct the first commercial spacewalk
SUMMARY: NPR's Geoff Brumfiel fills us in on the first private spacewalk, which took place this morning.

TITLE: In Jordan's elections, anger at Israel over the Gaza war fuels Islamist gains
SUMMARY: The Islamic Action Front, the political wing of the Muslim Brotherhood, is now the single biggest opposition bloc in Jordan's 138-member parliament, winning one-fifth of the seats this week.

TITLE: After more than a century, the Campbell's company drops 'soup' from its name
SUMMARY: The Campbell Soup Company's CEO said the "subtle yet important change" to the name adopted in 1922 better reflects the broad number of products it makes.

TITLE: Trump’s Bedminster club hosted an alleged Nazi sympathizer who stormed the Capitol
SUMMARY: At two events, Donald Trump’s New Jersey golf club hosted a convicted Jan. 6 rioter known for extreme antisemitic and racist comments, whom prosecutors described as a ‘white supremacist.’

TITLE: Navient reaches $120 million settlement for misleading student loan borrowers
SUMMARY: According to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, $100 million will be used to make payments to impacted borrowers in a settlement with the former servicer of student loans.

TITLE: Making German Chocolate Without Using Cocoa
SUMMARY: Cocoa beans, which are used to make chocolate, are mostly grown in a few places making them susceptible to the effects of extreme weather events, driven by climate change. We hear about a team in Germany that is developing a chocolate made without cocoa.

TITLE: 3 more counts are dismissed in the Trump case indictment in Georgia
SUMMARY: A judge has dismissed three more counts in the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald Trump and his allies.

TITLE: Danity Kane's Dawn Richard sues Sean 'Diddy' Combs for sexual assault and battery
SUMMARY: In the lawsuit filed Tuesday in a New York federal court, Richard alleges that the hip-hop mogul sexually assaulted her, deprived her of food and sleep and refused to pay her adequately.

TITLE: Boeing Machinists union votes to strike
SUMMARY: The deal would have raised wages by 25%, lowered employees’ share of health care costs, and boosted retirement contributions by the company. But many rank and file union members were unhappy.

TITLE: A loose electrical cable is found on ship that caused Baltimore bridge collapse
SUMMARY: Investigators found a loose cable that could have caused electrical issues on the Dali, the cargo ship that lost power and struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge, causing the span to collapse.

TITLE: Boeing machinists go on strike after rejecting contract
SUMMARY: The deal would have raised wages by 25%, lowered employees’ share of health care costs, and boosted retirement contributions by the company. But many rank and file union members were unhappy.

TITLE: From Clinton to Trump, how talk about crime has changed since a landmark bill
SUMMARY: Crime is a perennial issue in presidential campaigns, but experts say public perceptions of safety and justice are much different today than 30 years ago.

TITLE: Who won the debate?! Our quiz won't tell you that, but we do have other trivia on it
SUMMARY: There was a debate this week! But don't worry, we have questions about other things as well. For instance, have you been following the latest penguin news?

TITLE: The Grand Canyon is experiencing one of its deadliest stretches in years
SUMMARY: At least 16 people have died at the park this year, including five fatalities in August alone. No single factor is to blame, but several deaths have followed stretches of extreme weather.

TITLE: A year after the Big 3 strike, some union autoworkers face an uncertain future
SUMMARY: Last fall's strike against Ford, GM and Stellantis yielded record contracts for autoworkers. With a slowdown in car sales, Stellantis workers now face job cuts, production slowdowns and uncertainty.

TITLE: Step inside this legendary shop full of handmade costumes — while you still can
SUMMARY: For nearly half a century, Ursula Boschet has run a legendary costume shop in Los Angeles. Now, the 90-year-old is closing up — and everything is for sale.

TITLE: Gas stoves may soon come with a tobacco-style health warning label in California
SUMMARY: In California, gas stoves may come with a health warning label.

TITLE: Harris and Trump’s post-debate plans. And, why climate change puts chocolate at risk
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump and Vice President Harris are campaigning in swing states heavily post their first presidential debate. And, why climate change could put chocolate in danger.

TITLE: Union autoworkers won big after striking. A year later, some face an uncertain future
SUMMARY: Last fall's strike against Ford, GM and Stellantis yielded record contracts for autoworkers. With a slowdown in car sales, Stellantis workers now face job cuts, production slowdowns and uncertainty.

TITLE: China is raising its retirement age, now among the lowest in world's major economies
SUMMARY: In an effort to address its shrinking population and aging work force, over 15 years, China will raise the retirement age for men to 63, and for women to 55 or 58 years depending on their jobs.

TITLE: Climate change makes farming easier in Alaska. Indigenous growers hope to lead the way
SUMMARY: Climate change threatens many traditional foods in Alaska. But it’s also making farming more possible. A new training program aims to help Alaska Native communities grow more of their own food.

TITLE: 2 Paralympic athletes from Congo reported missing after their competitions
SUMMARY: Congolese athletes Mireille Nganga and sprinter Emmanuel Grace Mouambako, as well as  a guide accompanying Mouambako, were reported missing shortly after competing in the 2024 Paralympic Games.

TITLE: Calls grow for Dolphins QB Tua Tagovailoa to retire as he sustains another concussion
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old left Thursday night's game after he leaned headfirst into a tackle and added to an already worrying history of brain injury, prompting fans and former players to urge his retirement.

TITLE: Justin Timberlake pleads guilty to impaired driving, gets $500 fine and will make PSA
SUMMARY: Justin Timberlake pleaded guilty to impaired driving, resolving the criminal case stemming from his arrest in the Hamptons. “I did not live up to the standards that I try to hold for myself," he said.

TITLE: How Trump is relying on a racist conspiracy theory to question election results
SUMMARY: Donald Trump has echoed a new iteration of a conspiracy theory that has taken root in the GOP that falsely claims there is a plan to bring nonwhite immigrants to the U.S. to replace white voters.

TITLE: The latest on where Gaza's polio came from — and the race to contain it
SUMMARY: There's one confirmed case. And likely hundreds more. As experts try to ID the source of the virus in Gaza, a huge vaccine effort has wrapped up stage 1 and gears up for the critical stage 2.

TITLE: Arkansas’ gov says Medicaid extension for new moms isn’t needed. Advisers disagree
SUMMARY: Arkansas is the only holdout state that has not pursued the Biden administration's offer to extend Medicaid coverage to new moms for a year after they give birth.

TITLE: In Arizona, California and Nevada, Trump focuses on his favorite foil: immigrants
SUMMARY: In a press conference Friday, former President Donald Trump repeated false conspiracy theories about immigrants eating pets in Ohio, which has been debunked several times.

TITLE: 'Baby Reindeer' is an Emmy favorite — and facing a lawsuit at the same time
SUMMARY: The woman who believes she inspired a stalker in the hit TV show <em>Baby Reindeer

TITLE: Should the U.N. Security Council be Reformed?
SUMMARY: The Security Council is the United Nations' most powerful body, with the ability to impose sanctions and authorize the use of force. There are five permanent members of the council: Russia, France, China, the U.S and Britain. And any one of those permanent members can veto council resolutions. The U.S. is proposing expanding the number of permanent members, including two permanent seats for African countries. We talk to the U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. about the proposal.

TITLE: A new sculpture takes its place at the national World War I Memorial in D.C.
SUMMARY: Sabin Howard's sculpture, <em>A Soldier's Journey,

TITLE: Shein and Temu face a big change to how they ship cheap Chinese goods
SUMMARY: New White House rules would close a tax loophole that lets Shein and Temu cheaply ship from China to American shoppers. The Biden administration says it undercuts U.S. workers, retailers and manufacturers.

TITLE: Australia, a biodiversity hotspot, recognizes 750 new species
SUMMARY: Australia has added 750 new species of plants, animals, fungi and other organisms to its official list of species living on the continent.

TITLE: Stranded NASA astronauts say being stuck in space is just part of the job
SUMMARY: Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams revealed what life has been like aboard the International Space Station after problems arose with their Starliner spacecraft, which returned home empty last week.

TITLE: A landslide linked to climate change ‘rang’ the Earth for 9 days, researchers say
SUMMARY: The scale of the geological event is like something from prehistoric times, with a tsunami 200 meters--656 feet--in height. But it happened last year. Researchers warn that similar events may reoccur.

TITLE: The possible origins of Friday the 13th and other unlucky days
SUMMARY: The superstition of Friday the 13th isn’t as old as you think. Here are some of the potential origins of unlucky days around the world.

TITLE: NASA prepares to head back to the moon.
SUMMARY:
This time next year, if everything stays on schedule, NASA will send its first crewed mission to the moon, since the end of the Apollo program. Artemis II will be the first flight around the moon in more than 50 years.

Its goal will be to test out the Orion capsule and all the other equipment, so that by 2026, Artemis III can put astronauts back ON the moon.

The Artemis program is aimed to kickstart a new, more enduring era of space travel that leads to Mars.It's also intentionally more representative than Apollo was. The Artemis program will eventually put the first woman on the moon, as well as the first person of color.

It's all as historic and high stakes as it gets, and also pretty daunting.

NPR's Scott Detrow goes behind the scenes at the Johnson Space Center in Houston to see how the team is preparing.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: 3 Americans sentenced to death in failed coup attempt trial in DRC
SUMMARY: A military court in the DRC sentenced US citizens and dozens of others for their role in a failed coup attempt in May.

TITLE: Report: ‘No evidence’ Hawaii officials prepared for deadly wildfire, despite warnings
SUMMARY: Despite days of warnings that critical fire weather was coming, the report found “no evidence” of Hawaii officials making preparations for the August 2023 wildfire that killed 102 people.

TITLE: Firefighters gain ground on 3 huge Southern California blazes
SUMMARY: The three wildfires that have ravaged the mountains east of L.A., destroying dozens of homes, injuring a dozen people and burning more than 155 square miles, still pose threats to some communities.

TITLE: U.S. hits Russian state media with new sanctions
SUMMARY: The U.S. State Department accuses a Kremlin news outlet of working hand-in-hand with the Russian military and running fundraising campaigns to pay for equipment for soldiers fighting in Ukraine.

TITLE: Trump’s own version of reality continues to confound political actors and observers
SUMMARY: Far from being disqualifying, this feature of the Trump persona presents itself as part and parcel of his appeal.

TITLE: One restaurant has a way to fight food waste: Making food out of 'trash'
SUMMARY: Shuggie's Trash Pie chef David Murphy shares three easy recipes for transforming unloved leftover ingredients into delicious eats.

TITLE: George Washington established the presidency. How much of it would he recognize now?
SUMMARY: The presidential office was first envisioned to be more like a clerk's job, and in its earliest incarnation, it was almost unseemly to be perceived as campaigning for the office, historians tell NPR.

TITLE: Biden discusses long range missiles for Ukraine with British PM
SUMMARY: President Biden met with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer Friday to discuss whether Ukraine should be allowed to use missiles that could reach deep into Russian territory.

TITLE: Celebrating science that's off the beaten track
SUMMARY: From pension fraud to plastic plants, this year's Ig Nobel prizes recognize science that can be lighthearted, surprising or unusual.

TITLE: Pioneering ballerina Michaela DePrince dies at 29
SUMMARY: DePrince, born in Sierra Leone, lost both her parents during the country’s civil war. She became the youngest principal dancer at the Dance Theatre of Harlem and later joined the Boston Ballet.

TITLE: In Portland, thousands gather to marvel at migrating birds’ nighttime routine
SUMMARY: As Vaux’s Swifts migrate south, they roost together in a chimney, drawing crowds

TITLE: Iran says it launched a satellite under program criticized by West over missile fears
SUMMARY: Iran launched a satellite into space with a rocket built by the country's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard, state-run media reported.

TITLE: FDA approves some Apple AirPods to be used as hearing aids
SUMMARY: An upcoming Apple software update will allow some AirPods to double as over-the-counter hearing aids. Only 1 in 6 American adults with hearing loss wears hearing aids.

TITLE: How we grow food affects the climate. Here are solutions communities are taking to help
SUMMARY: We've gathered examples from across the NPR Network of how we can change the food we grow to support climate goals.

TITLE: Venezuela says it arrested 6 foreigners allegedly involved in a plot to kill Maduro
SUMMARY: Three Americans, two Spaniards and a Czech citizen were arrested after Venezuelan officials accused them of coming to the South American country to assassinate President Nicolas Maduro.

TITLE: Four astronauts on Polaris Dawn flight return to Earth after 1st commercial spacewalk
SUMMARY: The five-day trip, funded by internet entrepreneur Jared Isaacman, broke several records including the first-ever commercial spacewalk using SpaceX’s Crew Dragon capsule on Polaris Dawn mission.

TITLE: How do you help young Afghan refugees heal? A new program in Maine offers a way
SUMMARY: Research shows that a toxic mix of past traumas and the stresses of resettlement puts refugee kids at significantly higher risk of long term mental health challenges. A new effort aims to mitigate those risks by supporting parents and children in refugee families.

TITLE: Exhausted? Irritable? It could be undiagnosed iron deficiency
SUMMARY: Around a third of women of reproductive age could have low iron. But doctors don’t routinely screen for the condition, though it can lead to anemia. Symptoms include exhaustion, headaches and more.

TITLE: Eating less beef is a climate solution. Here's why that's hard for some American men
SUMMARY: Climate researchers have long grappled with how to get Americans to eat less beef, a food with a huge global warming impact. Now some are thinking about it through the lens of gender.

TITLE: If Harris wins, she would make history. But she isn’t talking about that
SUMMARY: Hillary Clinton leaned into her identity when she ran for president. Vice President Kamala Harris is decidedly not.

TITLE: State bans on commercial food waste have been largely ineffective, study finds
SUMMARY: Much of the food supply in the U.S. goes uneaten, which contributes to climate change. Some states have tried to cut food waste in landfills, but their efforts have fallen short, researchers found.

TITLE: Torrential rains trigger mass evacuations as rivers surge in Central Europe
SUMMARY: Torrential rains in Central Europe have forced massive evacuations in the hardest hit areas in the Czech Republic, where floods reached extreme levels on Sunday.

TITLE: Not sure what to make for dinner? Here are recipes to help you eat sustainably
SUMMARY: Finding meals that are good for you, your wallet and the environment can be difficult. We've pulled together a few recipes to make sustainable choices even easier.

TITLE: Creative ways communities are reducing food waste
SUMMARY: While lots of powerful changes to reduce food waste can start at home, sometimes the scale of the problem benefits from a community-wide approach.

TITLE: As medical strike drags on in South Korea, patients are on edge
SUMMARY: Seven months have passed since South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol announced a plan to increase the number of doctors. Trainee doctors walked off their jobs in protest and they haven’t returned.

TITLE: Vance defends spreading claims that Haitian migrants are eating pets
SUMMARY: Sen. JD Vance, in a media appearance, blames the media for ignoring the situation in Springfield, Ohio, and justifies false stories about Haitian migrants.

TITLE: Top legal adviser to New York City mayor quits as investigations swell
SUMMARY: The top legal adviser to New York City Mayor Eric Adams resigned over the weekend, the latest sign of instability in the Democrat's administration as it deals with multiple federal investigations.

TITLE: Trump says 'I hate Taylor Swift' after pop star endorses Harris
SUMMARY: The Republican presidential nominee directed his vitriol at the pop star after Swift threw her support behind the Democratic presidential nominee.

TITLE: Gun shots fired near Trump at his Florida golf course, former president is 'safe'
SUMMARY: The Secret Service and the Trump campaign say the former president is 'safe' following a shooting nearby in Florida.

TITLE: Trump is safe after shots fired in apparent 'attempted assassination' in Florida
SUMMARY: A suspect was about 300 to 500 yards from former President Donald Trump on Sunday afternoon, pointing a rifle through the fence of Trump’s golf club in West Palm Beach, Fla., local authorities said.

TITLE: Live Emmys 2024: Here are the winners of TV's biggest night
SUMMARY: Eugene and Dan Levy are hosting the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards Sunday night. We'll be following along with the winners here.

TITLE: Live Emmys 2024: 'The Bear' leads the pack at TV's biggest night
SUMMARY: Eugene and Dan Levy are hosting the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards Sunday night. We'll be following along with the winners here.

TITLE: Trump was targeted in 'attempted assassination,' the FBI says
SUMMARY: Former President Trump was the target of what the FBI said “appears to be an attempted assassination” at his West Palm Beach golf club. President Biden said he was briefed and a person has been detained.

TITLE: Emmys 2024: 'The Bear,' 'Baby Reindeer,' 'Shogun' win big
SUMMARY: Eugene and Dan Levy hosted the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards Sunday night. Check out the award winners marked in bold.

TITLE: Trump was targeted in apparent 'attempted assassination,' the FBI says
SUMMARY: Former President Trump was the target of what the FBI said “appears to be an attempted assassination” at his West Palm Beach golf club. President Biden said he was briefed and a person has been detained.

TITLE: Emmys 2024: 'The Bear,' 'Baby Reindeer,' 'Shōgun' win big
SUMMARY: Eugene and Dan Levy hosted the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards Sunday night. Check out the award winners marked in bold.

TITLE: Climate change is one reason for hotter oceans. But there are others
SUMMARY:
Hurricane season is heating up: Hurricane Francine hit Louisiana last week and dumped rain across the South, and forecasters expect more stormy activity in the Atlantic in the next few weeks.

A big factor in this stormy weather is our extremely warm oceans. Scientists know climate change is the main culprit, but NPR climate correspondent Rebecca Hersher has been following the quest to figure out the other reasons. Hint: They may involve volcanoes and the sun.

Read more of Rebecca's reporting on this topic.

Questions about hurricanes or other weather disasters? Email us at shortwave@npr.org – we'd love to hear your ideas!

TITLE: Shanghai hit by strongest typhoon since 1949
SUMMARY: More than 414,000 people had been evacuated ahead of the powerful winds and torrential rain from Typhoon Bebinca. Schools were closed and people were advised to stay indoors.

TITLE: For people with opioid addiction, Medicaid overhaul comes with risks
SUMMARY: More than a million Americans use Medicaid to get addiction treatments like methadone. But as states update their systems, some patients have lost coverage. Even a short gap can be life-threatening.

TITLE: When Wil was struggling with depression, a therapist said just the right thing
SUMMARY: In 2014, Wil Davenport was being treated for depression at an inpatient mental health program. One day, his therapist issued a challenge that renewed his sense of purpose.

TITLE: People who exercise have healthier belly fat, new study finds
SUMMARY: Here's another good reason to keep exercising. A study finds people with obesity who exercise can store more fat<strong>

TITLE: A celestial trifecta: What to know about Tuesday’s lunar eclipse
SUMMARY: This month's harvest moon will not only coincide with a supermoon, but also with a blood moon and partial lunar eclipse.

TITLE: Rupert Murdoch is set to face his kids in court, with Fox News’ fate in the balance
SUMMARY: The future of Fox News – and the rest of the Murdoch media empire – is at stake in a trial this week in Reno, Nevada. Rupert Murdoch wants to change his will to consolidate his eldest son’s power.

TITLE: Her piano concert was six years in the making. Then Puerto Rico's power went out
SUMMARY: Puerto Rico’s unstable electric grid affects every sector of society, including the island’s rich cultural scene. An outage abruptly ended an emerging pianist’s recent concert, touching a nerve.

TITLE: 2nd apparent assassination attempt on Trump: Everything we know so far
SUMMARY: The FBI is investigating a second apparent assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump Sunday. The gunman was about 300 to 500 yards from Trump with an AK-style rifle with scope.

TITLE: Inside the U.S. city churning out Ukrainian weapons
SUMMARY: <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Here's what we know about the suspect in Trump's apparent attempted assassination
SUMMARY: Ryan Wesley Routh's digital footprint paints a picture of a disillusioned former Trump voter who took up an impassioned defense of Ukraine. Here's what else we know about the 58-year-old suspect.

TITLE: China frees American pastor after 18 years in detention
SUMMARY: The State Department said that 68-year-old David Lin is coming home after being arrested in China on vague contract charges that he and his family deny. He had been jailed there for 18 years.

TITLE: TikTok argued against its U.S. ban in court today. Here's what happened
SUMMARY: TikTok’s survival in the U.S. is riding on the outcome of the hearing. Federal judges peppered both the Justice Department and TikTok with skeptical questions about the ban, which takes effect in January.

TITLE: Here's everything we know about the apparent assassination attempt on Trump
SUMMARY: An agent spotted a rifle barrel poking through a fence; a witness got a photo of the suspect’s license plate as he fled. Now Ryan Wesley Routh is facing federal charges.

TITLE: The Boeing Strike: 4 moments the company fractured its bond with workers
SUMMARY: Though contract negotiations were the catalyst for Boeing machinists to go on strike, frustrations among workers have been building up for years.

TITLE: In France, A Shocking Story and Difficult Questions About Society
SUMMARY: A rape case in France involving a woman whose ex-husband is on trial for drugging her and recruiting other men to sexually assault her. Now thousands have turned out to support her and many are asking hard questions about the culture that allowed this to happen for years.

TITLE: Gymnast Jordan Chiles appeals to Swiss supreme court for her Olympic bronze medal
SUMMARY: Chiles was awarded the bronze medal at the Paris floor exercise final. But her medal was revoked by an arbitration court, which ruled an inquiry that had improved her score was filed seconds too late.

TITLE: These states will decide the election. We went to all of them to talk to voters
SUMMARY: Your guide to the six swing states that will decide this year’s presidential election: Georgia, Nevada, Wisconsin, Michigan, Arizona and Pennsylvania.

TITLE: What we know about the suspect in the Trump apparent assassination attempt
SUMMARY: Ryan Wesley Routh's digital footprint paints a picture of a disillusioned former Trump supporter who took up an impassioned defense of Ukraine. Here's what else we know about the 58-year-old suspect.

TITLE: In interview on X, Trump addresses apparent assassination attempt for the first time
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump spoke for the first time about the apparent assassination attempt on him Sunday at his golf course and talking to President Biden on Monday.

TITLE: Former officer says Tyre Nichols 'wasn't a threat' when taken from car during stop
SUMMARY: Emmitt Martin III, a former Memphis police officer who has pleaded guilty in the case, took the stand in the federal trial of former colleagues Tadarrius Bean, Demetrius Haley and Justin Smith.

TITLE: Sean 'Diddy' Combs' faces federal charges in New York, his lawyer says
SUMMARY: Sean "Diddy" Combs faces federal charges in New York, his lawyer said late Monday. Details of the charges weren't immediately announced by prosecutors.

TITLE: Sean 'Diddy' Combs is arrested in New York after federal indictment
SUMMARY: Sean "Diddy" Combs was arrested late Monday in New York, where he faces a sealed criminal indictment, prosecutors announced late Monday.

TITLE: DEA closing 2 offices in China as the agency struggles to stem flow of chemicals
SUMMARY: The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration is shutting down two of its hard-won offices in China, a move that comes even as the agency struggles to disrupt the flow of precursor chemicals.

TITLE: How one shaman helps others find healing and meaning in a modern world
SUMMARY: Helena Soholm, a Korean American shaman and transpersonal psychologist, integrates Western and Indigenous systems of knowledge to facilitate healing and growth in modern, technologically advanced societies.

TITLE: Man accused of drugging wife so dozens of men could rape her testifies in French court
SUMMARY: A man accused of drugging his then-wife and inviting dozens of men to rape her over nearly a decade is testifying in court on Tuesday in southern France, in a case that has shocked the country.

TITLE: He survived the water, but not the flood
SUMMARY: Climate-driven flooding destroyed Tony Calhoun’s home in 2022. But as the water receded, his despair only grew. Now, his family hopes to bring attention to the mental health toll of extreme weather.

TITLE: Cyberattacks plague health care. Critics call the federal response 'inadequate'
SUMMARY: The Change Healthcare cyberattack sparked a new strategy from the federal government on preventing destructive ransomware crimes. Critics say it doesn't go far enough.

TITLE: How to register to vote in 2024
SUMMARY: Here's what you need to know to register to vote — online, in person or by mail — in every state ahead of the 2024 general election.

TITLE: More and more artists want Trump to stop using their music. They face a costly fight
SUMMARY: The White Stripes are the latest musical act to take the former president to court over using their songs in his reelection campaign.

TITLE: Dear Life Kit: I resent that my WFH partner has more free time than I do
SUMMARY: A listener says she has trouble respecting her husband because of his work-from-home habits. While she works long hours, he gets to sign off early. Therapist Moraya Seeger DeGeare weighs in.

TITLE: These houses survived one of the country's worst wildfires. Here’s how
SUMMARY: The wildfire in Lahaina, Maui spread through extreme winds and intense heat. Still, a handful of houses were untouched thanks to the owners preparing the buildings and yards.

TITLE: So many music festivals have been canceled this year. What's going on?
SUMMARY: Music festivals are canceling their events like maybe never before. Call it the music festival recession.

TITLE: Complex political past of suspect in Trump's apparent 2nd assassination attempt
SUMMARY: Ryan Routh, the suspect in the Trump apparent assassination attempt, has a colored digital footprint. The former Trump supporter showed a strong interest in Ukraine. And, the battle of Fox News.

TITLE: This preventive drug could be a 'game changer' in ending the HIV epidemic
SUMMARY: In newly released data, lenacapavir, given via a twice-yearly injection, has shown remarkable effectiveness at eliminating HIV transmission during sexual contact. But its cost could be an issue.

TITLE: Instagram makes all teen accounts private, in a highly scrutinized push for child safety
SUMMARY: The social media app unveiled a new product for young users of the app that is intended to make the service safer for teenagers. The tools include making all teen accounts private and allowing parents to supervise activity.

TITLE: AI met fruit fly, and a better brain model emerged
SUMMARY: A virtual version of a fruit fly’s visual system could help scientists understand how brain networks process information. The model could also lead to more efficient AI systems.

TITLE: Abortion providers — and patients — are on the move, as state laws keep shifting
SUMMARY: Clinics in states where most abortions are legal, such as Kansas and Illinois, are reporting an influx of inquiries from patients hundreds of miles away — and are expanding in response.

TITLE: More and more artists want Trump to stop using their music. They face a costly fight
SUMMARY: The White Stripes are the latest musical act to take the former president to court over using their songs in his reelection campaign.

TITLE: Some Israelis are leaving the country due to the war in Gaza
SUMMARY: Uncertainty about the future, safety fears and concerns over the government's handling of the war in Gaza are leading some Jewish Israelis to leave their country and start new lives elsewhere.

TITLE: Scores of Hezbollah fighters wounded following pager blasts
SUMMARY: In what appears to be an widespread attack on part of the militant group’s communications system, the explosions took place in Beirut’s southern suburbs where Hezbollah has offices and in the south of the country.

TITLE: Disney trips meant for homeless NYC students went to school employees' families
SUMMARY: Disney trips that were meant for homeless students in New York City public schools were used by school employees' families instead, according to a report released by the district earlier this month.

TITLE: Florida wants to take the lead on Ryan Routh’s prosecution in Trump golf incident
SUMMARY: Florida is conducting its own investigation into the apparent assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump. Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis says the state’s case should take precedence.

TITLE: Vets helping Ukraine worry Trump assassination attempt suspect will hurt their cause
SUMMARY: U.S. military veterans who support Ukraine worry about political blowback since the suspect in the apparent assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump has connections to their movement.

TITLE: Conservative editor-in-chief appears to use racial slur to refer to Haitian migrants
SUMMARY: Rich Lowry, of the prominent conservative magazine National Review appeared to use the N-word to refer to Haitian migrants during an appearance on The Megyn Kelly Show.

TITLE: Hezbollah accuses Israel as thousands hurt in unusual pager blasts
SUMMARY: The attack raises fears of an escalation between Hezbollah and Israel, and comes following warnings from Israeli officials of possible military action against the Lebanese group.

TITLE: The U.S. has had a long history of political violence, but experts see a new trend
SUMMARY: The apparent second assassination attempt of Donald Trump is stirring concern about growing political violence in the U.S.

TITLE: Microsoft says Russia’s election interference efforts have pivoted to Harris and Walz
SUMMARY: The company identified a number of recent Russia-linked campaigns that have shifted focus to Harris, relying on videos to spread conspiracy theories and falsehoods about the Democratic nominee.

TITLE: Former officer testifies he beat a 'helpless' Tyre Nichols then lied about it
SUMMARY: Emmitt Martin III testified that he punched the 29-year-old Black man at least five times while two Memphis police colleagues held his arms and said “hit him."

TITLE: Exploding Pagers in Lebanon, Raising Tensions between Hezbollah and Israel
SUMMARY: Authorities in Lebanon are blaming Israel for an apparent attack in which pagers, used by Hezbollah in Lebanon, exploded simultaneously. At least nine people were killed, more than 2,700 were injured. Tensions between Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese paramilitary group backed by Iran, had already been high and there were fears their frequent attacks on each other could escalate into all-out war. We hear about what this all could mean from our correspondent in the region.

TITLE: A NASA probe is about to launch to an icy moon that could have life
SUMMARY: A NASA mission launching in October will send cameras and other scientific equipment to see, among other things, whether Jupiter's moon Europa could sustain life.

TITLE: Senate Republicans block IVF bill, as Democrats elevate issue ahead of November election
SUMMARY: Senate Republicans blocked a bill to ensure federal protections for access to in vitro fertilization treatments, calling it a "show" vote by Democrats. Republican leaders and Former President Trump, the GOP nominee for president, say they back IVF but not the legislation proposed by Democrats.

TITLE: Harris calls Trump's remarks about Haitian immigrants in Springfield a 'crying shame'
SUMMARY: Harris said Trump’s remarks about immigrants eating pets were lies rooted in racist tropes, and in some of her most forceful language yet about the debunked claim, insisted it “has to to stop.”

TITLE: Hezbollah pagers explode across Lebanon, causing nearly 3,000 casualties
SUMMARY: Lebanese officials say Israel is to blame for the explosions. Hezbollah members had turned to pagers, believing they were more secure than phones. Israel has declined to comment.

TITLE: A year after the strike is the UAW still winning?
SUMMARY:
A year ago at this time, members of the United Auto Workers Union were feeling powerful and optimistic. The group's new President Shawn Fain had called a historic strike. For the first time, the Union walked out on ALL three big automakers.

It was a bold move that by most measures worked. It ultimately brought Ford, GM and Stellantis much closer to the union's demands for historic raises and new job protections.

The strike's success had people predicting a bigger and more powerful union.

A year on the union is still staring down some major challenges.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: The Federal Reserve is on the verge of cutting interest rates. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The Fed is expected to start cutting interest rates on Wednesday — marking a milestone in the central bank's long-running battle against inflation.

TITLE: Disinformation and suppression loom over Georgia, says Black Voters Matter co-founder
SUMMARY: LaTosha Brown — the co-founder of Black Voters Matter — details how she's thinking about the election to come in Georgia, and the threat of voter suppression and disinformation.

TITLE: A records flaw could block thousands in Arizona from voting in state and local races
SUMMARY: Arizona officials say the flaw could disqualify nearly 100,000 people from voting in non-federal races. At issue is proof of citizenship records required by the state to participate in such elections.

TITLE: Trump held his first campaign event since the apparent assassination attempt
SUMMARY: Trump’s town hall in Michigan was shorter than his typical campaign rally, but he used the event to discuss everything from the failed attempts on his life to a promise to boost the auto industry.

TITLE: Report: Cancer diagnoses are more common but so is surviving
SUMMARY: A new report shows rapid development of new cancer treatment and detection is helping people live more. But more people are also getting diagnosed, and at younger ages.

TITLE: The FBI is investigating packages sent to election officials in more than 15 states
SUMMARY: The FBI and the U.S. Postal Service were investigating the origin of suspicious packages that have been sent to elections officials in more than 15 states. There were no immediate reports of injuries.

TITLE: Lael Wilcox rode around the world and then went for another bike ride
SUMMARY: American cyclist Lael Wilcox rode more than 18,000 miles in 108 days, 12 hours and 12 minutes. She's claiming the record for the fastest woman to ride around the world.

TITLE: See a loopy landlady in a caftan? Mrs. Roper may be romping through your town
SUMMARY: Hundreds of costumed "Helens" are cheerfully invading bars across the country in honor of Helen Roper, from the 1970s sitcom <em>Three's Company.

TITLE: Want to keep good workers? Praise them, a new study finds
SUMMARY: New research from Gallup and Workhuman finds that employees who receive recognition on the job are 45% less likely to leave their jobs. Younger workers, in particular, say appreciation is key.

TITLE: Meet Moo Deng, the baby pygmy hippo so popular you can visit her for only 5 minutes
SUMMARY: A baby pygmy hippopotamus in a Thailand zoo has become a worldwide internet sensation, leading to crowds at the zoo. Zoo officials say the increased attention has led to some bad visitor behavior.

TITLE: Georgia election officials worry a GOP-led board will OK last-minute voting changes
SUMMARY: Georgia election officials have said they are “gravely concerned that dramatic changes” approved by the State Election Board “will disrupt the preparation and training processes already in motion.”

TITLE: NPR Exclusive: U.S. overdose deaths plummet, saving thousands of lives
SUMMARY: After decades of devastating increases driven by fentanyl and other toxic street drugs,<strong>

TITLE: Tracking the exploding pagers used in apparent Israeli attack on Hezbollah
SUMMARY: Gold Apollo denied all involvement with the explosive pagers, telling NPR outside its offices in Taiwan that it was a Budapest-based company called BAC Consulting which manufactured the devices.

TITLE: What today's interest rate cut means for you. And, a big drop in U.S. overdose deaths
SUMMARY: The first interest rate cut since 2020 is expected to be announced today by the Federal Reserve. And, for the first time in decades, U.S. drug overdose deaths appear to be plummeting.

TITLE: A bookstore too controversial for China finds home in D.C.
SUMMARY: This Shanghai bookstore, now in D.C., was revived by its owner, who hopes to create a space for open discussions in the diaspora community, where people can sit and read together.

TITLE: Tupperware, no longer a kitchen staple, files for bankruptcy
SUMMARY: Tupperware's reliance on people selling its storage containers at home-and-garden parties or through social media was once its strength. Now it's a weakness, the company says in its bankruptcy filing.

TITLE: U.S. sues Dali ship owner and operator for $100 million over Baltimore bridge collapse
SUMMARY: “The ship’s owner and manager … sent an ill-prepared crew on an abjectly unseaworthy vessel to navigate the United States’ waterways,” the Justice Department says in its new civil claim.

TITLE: Another wave of blasts hits Lebanon, as Hezbollah reels from pager explosions
SUMMARY: Following Tuesday's stunning attack on pagers, Lebanon was hit by another deadly wave of exploding communications devices on Wednesday.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve starts cutting interest rates in a big moment for the economy
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve moved aggressively Wednesday to start cutting interest rates as easing inflation fears give way to concern about the job market.

TITLE: Connie Chung says booze and bawdy jokes helped her break into journalism's boys club
SUMMARY: In a new memoir, Chung reflects on the decades she spent covering the news, her marriage to Maury Povich and the prominent figures who acted inappropriately with her — including President Carter.

TITLE: In Kashmir, voting begins in first local elections since India revoked autonomy
SUMMARY: In Indian-controlled Kashmir, residents are voting in elections that some hope will lead to restoration of the territory's statehood, which ended when it became a federally governed territory in 2019.

TITLE: In break with tradition, the Teamsters will not endorse a presidential candidate
SUMMARY: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a union of 1.3 million workers, will not endorse Vice President Harris or former President Donald Trump for president, after decades of backing Democrats.

TITLE: What is School Like for Children in War Zones?
SUMMARY:
Life is uncertain for children in war zones. There, school can be a source of stability or just another thing that war obliterates. We hear reports on what school is like in three of the world's most active war zones: Sudan, Gaza and Ukraine.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.

TITLE: JD Souther, who collaborated on 'Heartache Tonight' and other Eagles hits, dies at 78
SUMMARY: Souther was a prolific songwriter and musician who helped shape the country-rock sound that took root in Southern California in the 1970s with his collaborations with the Eagles and Linda Ronstadt.

TITLE: Harvey Weinstein pleads not guilty to new sex crime charge in New York
SUMMARY: Prosecutors revealed last week that Weinstein had been indicted on additional sex crime charges that weren’t part of the case that led to his now-overturned 2020 conviction.
