TITLE: Alabama carries out nation's 3rd nitrogen gas execution
SUMMARY: An Alabama man convicted in the 1994 killing of a hitchhiker cursed at the prison warden shortly before he was put to death Thursday evening in the nation's third execution using nitrogen gas.

TITLE: United Nations nuclear agency again condemns Iran for failing to fully cooperate
SUMMARY: The resolution comes after the agency said Iran has defied demands to rein in its nuclear program and has increased its stockpile of uranium enriched to near weapons-grade levels.

TITLE: You can sword-fight at this club. But no politics allowed
SUMMARY: At the Pittsburgh Sword Fighters club, members are asked to leave their politics at the door, a rule that has led to closer relationships and more learning from one another.

TITLE: How will China impact the future of climate change? You might be surprised
SUMMARY: As a new Trump administration signals a retreat on climate action, China is stepping up. China is the biggest producer of climate technologies like electric vehicles and solar panels.

TITLE: More than 100,000 pounds of ground beef are recalled for possibly having E. coli
SUMMARY: The Minnesota Department of Agriculture alerted federal authorities about several illnesses in the past week.

TITLE: President-elect set to shape 'Trump judiciary' for next generation
SUMMARY: Legal experts predict President-elect Donald Trump will move quickly next year to cement and extend his legacy in appointing federal judges.

TITLE: In this election, demographics did not determine how people voted
SUMMARY: Groups that Democrats believed would always turn out in their favor did not do so this year. Here's how the vote shook out in the seven swing states.

TITLE: Tesla won the plug war. Enter the age of the EV charging adapter
SUMMARY: The auto industry is embracing Tesla's charging technology in order to share its vast Supercharger network. This is going to be a slow transition — expect to see a lot of adapters.

TITLE: Trump's new pick for attorney general. And, Russia's message to NATO countries
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump picks Pam Bondi as attorney general after Matt Gaetz withdraws from consideration. And, Putin says Russia tested a new intermediate-range ballistic missile on Ukraine.

TITLE: Searching for tiny dung beetles that clean the vast forest floor
SUMMARY: Creating a census of the dung beetles of Massachusetts gives clues into the health of forests and fields.

TITLE: TV's Dr. Oz invested in businesses regulated by the agency Trump wants him to run
SUMMARY: The celebrity doctor recently held investments worth tens of millions of dollars in health care, tech, and food companies which could pose significant conflicts of interest.

TITLE: Former Google CEO Eric Schmidt discusses the DOJ move to have Google sell off Chrome
SUMMARY: Michel Martin asks former Google CEO Eric Schmidt about the government's move to separate Google from its Chrome browser and the future of artificial intelligence as envisioned in the book "Genesis."

TITLE: Judge indefinitely postpones sentencing in Trump's hush money case
SUMMARY: The decision to indefinitely adjourn next week's sentencing date comes several days after both lawyers agreed that a stay would help sort out unprecedented legal questions.

TITLE: Trans health care under Trump may follow the abortion playbook and its Hyde amendment
SUMMARY: Republicans spent $222 million on anti-trans and LGBTQ advertising in the campaign. Various policy initiatives are on  the incoming administration's to-do list.

TITLE: 6 tourists in Laos have died after drinking tainted alcohol
SUMMARY: Tourists from the U.S., Australia, Denmark and the U.K. have died. A tourism police officer said a "number of people" had been detained in the case but that no charges have yet been filed.

TITLE: Wisconsin kayaker who faked his death has resurfaced in Europe after elaborate plot
SUMMARY: Wisconsin authorities say they have not yet issued a warrant for Ryan Borgwardt, who is believed to be somewhere in Eastern Europe. But that can change if he does not cooperate and return home soon.

TITLE: Jonathan Majors and ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari settle assault and defamation case
SUMMARY: In a civil lawsuit this spring, the actor's former girlfriend alleged a "pattern of pervasive domestic abuse" in addition to defamation. Her legal team said the suit has been settled.

TITLE: University of Texas, MIT and others announce free tuition for some undergraduates
SUMMARY: Nearly half a dozen institutions of higher education announced plans this week to make tuition free for undergraduates whose families make below a certain income threshold, starting in fall 2025.

TITLE: For the first time ever, Taliban reps were invited to the big U.N. climate conference
SUMMARY: Since the Taliban took power 2021, Afghanistan has not been invited to big climate conferences. And money for projects addressing climate-related issues has been frozen. Are things about to change?

TITLE: A Relationship Surviving 1,000 Days of War
SUMMARY: It has been over a thousand days since Russia began it's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The war has had huge geopolitical ramifications, but it has also has affected the lives of millions of ordinary people. Our correspondent in Kyiv tells us how the one couple in Ukraine has weathered the conflict.

TITLE: Trump nominates Russ Vought for White House budget director once again
SUMMARY: Vought was one of the architects of the conservative agenda known as Project 2025 and served as budget director during President-elect Donald Trump's first term in office.

TITLE: Trump nominates Wall Street investor Scott Bessent as treasury secretary
SUMMARY: President-elect Trump nominated Bessent, a former protégé of George Soros to be his next  treasury secretary.

TITLE: Trump names former Texas state Rep. Scott Turner to lead Housing and Urban Development
SUMMARY: HUD is bracing for possible budget cuts, something the first Trump administration proposed but was unable to get through Congress. Other changes could restrict who gets rental aid.

TITLE: Trump picks Oregon Congresswoman Lori Chavez-DeRemer to lead Labor Department
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump has nominated Congresswoman Lori Chavez-DeRemer of Oregon to lead the Labor Department. She was one of a few Republicans who support the pro-union PRO Act.

TITLE: A 'lynch mob' did not come for Matt Gaetz, but the phrasing remains powerful
SUMMARY: Even as a young child, I could understand the idea that words have meaning, which is why when Sen. Lindsey Graham referred to a "lynch mob" coming after Matt Gaetz, I felt my stomach drop.

TITLE: What to know about Trump's picks for CDC, FDA and surgeon general
SUMMARY: In a flurry of picks on Friday evening, Trump named three choices for top health jobs. Together they would help the incoming president shift the priorities of agencies that are key to public health.

TITLE: Storm lashes Northern California after leaving thousands without power in Seattle
SUMMARY: The storm arrived in the Pacific Northwest earlier this week, killing two people and knocking out power to hundreds of thousands, mostly in the Seattle area, before moving through Northern California.

TITLE: Florida health official advises communities to stop adding fluoride to drinking water
SUMMARY: Florida's surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, cited developmental concerns from higher levels of fluoride than are found in most U.S. water supplies.

TITLE: Atmospheric rivers aren't new. Why does it feel like we're hearing about them more?
SUMMARY: In recent years, "atmospheric river" has become used much more frequently in scientific papers and in media coverage. According to experts who study climate and weather, a few reasons may explain why.

TITLE: NATO and Ukraine to hold emergency talks after Russia's attack with new missile
SUMMARY: NATO and Ukraine will hold emergency talks Tuesday after Russia attacked the city of Dnipro with an experimental, hypersonic ballistic missile that escalated the nearly 33-month-old war.

TITLE: At least 11 killed in Israeli strikes in Beirut as diplomats push for cease-fire
SUMMARY: The strikes were the fourth on Beirut in less than a week. The escalation comes after a U.S. envoy traveled to the region this week in an attempt to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.

TITLE: South Africa's illegal gold miners are locked in an underground standoff with police
SUMMARY: Surviving on a diet of toothpaste and toilet paper, South Africa's notorious "zama-zama" illegal miners continue a weeks-long standoff with police in the darkness of a disused gold mine.

TITLE: Trump's deportation vow alarms Texas construction industry
SUMMARY: Texas builders warn mass deportations of undocumented migrants could devastate the construction industry, threatening housing and infrastructure work in one of the nation's fastest-growing states.

TITLE: Bringing Thanksgiving food on a plane? Here is what you should know
SUMMARY: Thanksgiving favorites such as mac and cheese, turkey and casseroles can be brought through TSA checkpoints. But cranberry sauce, maple syrup and gravy must go in checked baggage, the agency says.

TITLE: Opinion: Remembering Vladimir Shklyarov, a dancer for the people
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remarks on the death of ballet dancer Vladimir Shklyarov. Reports from Russian media say he fell from a 5th floor balcony.

TITLE: What a mollusc shell and fiber optic cables have in common
SUMMARY: A heart cockle shell has been found to let in light through a design that resembles fiber optic cables. This could inspire everything from helping coral survive to designing new camera lenses.

TITLE: NATO head and Trump meet in Florida for talks on global security
SUMMARY: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and the head of NATO, Mark Rutte, met on Friday in Palm Beach for talks on global security, the military alliance said Saturday.

TITLE: Climate change plays a role in global rise of dengue fever
SUMMARY: Over 12 million cases of dengue fever were reported in 2024, the most ever. A study suggests climate change has likely played a significant role in the disease's expansion.

TITLE: Israeli strikes in central Beirut kill at least 15 as diplomats push for cease-fire
SUMMARY: The strikes were the fourth on Beirut in less than a week. The escalation comes after a U.S. envoy traveled to the region this week in an attempt to broker a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.

TITLE: Infant dies and 10 others sick in latest listeria outbreak tied to ready-to-eat meat
SUMMARY: The cases appeared in California, Illinois, New Jersey and New York between July 31 and Oct. 24, the CDC said. Nine out of the 11 infected individuals were hospitalized.

TITLE: Winter storms sweep across the U.S. while a new system is expected for Thanksgiving
SUMMARY: A major storm dropped more snow and record rain in California, while on the opposite side of the country blizzard or winter storm warnings were in effect Saturday.

TITLE: Trump taps Brooke Rollins of America First Policy Institute for agriculture secretary
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump has tapped Brooke Rollins, head of the America First Policy Institute, to oversee the Department of Agriculture. She has a long history in conservative politics.

TITLE: Alcohol poisoning deaths in Laos renew concerns about methanol. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The U.S., Australia and U.K. have issued warnings for travelers in Vang Vieng after several tourists died in a suspected methanol poisoning outbreak.

TITLE: With talks teetering, climate negotiators struck a controversial $300 billion deal
SUMMARY: Representatives of developing countries and climate activists were furious over the outcome, saying $300 billion annually from industrialized countries is far short of what vulnerable nations need to better protect themselves from climate change.

TITLE: In 'Points North' podcast, researchers try to save ash trees from extinction
A photographer's devastating documentation of El Salvador's civil war in the 1980s
SUMMARY: In <em>Legacy of Lies, El Salvador 1981-1984

TITLE: Jimmy O. Yang opens up about one of his deepest fears
SUMMARY: Actor Jimmy O. Yang is learning how to take compliments. On <em>Wild Card

TITLE: Israeli strike kills Lebanese soldier as Hezbollah fires rockets at Israel
SUMMARY: An Israeli strike on a Lebanese army center on Sunday killed one soldier and wounded 18 others, the Lebanese military said.

TITLE: A new installation lets you hear extinct and endangered animal sounds, thanks to Björk
SUMMARY: The Icelandic pop star Björk's new installation at Centre Pompidou in Paris uses animal sounds to help people understand what's lost and what we stand to lose as a result of human-caused climate change.

TITLE: Fold paper. Insert lens. This $2 microscope changes how kids see the world
SUMMARY: The Foldscope brings a powerful science tool to schools that can't afford microscopes. Scientists use it too. Its creators have handed out 2 million units, including a new mini-model for younger kids.

TITLE: 2 Dartmouth fraternity members and a sorority have been charged in death of a student
SUMMARY: The Alpha Phi sorority and two members of Beta Alpha Omega have been charged after a student was found dead in a river after attending an off-campus party where alcohol was allegedly served to minors.

TITLE: Chuck Woolery, game show host of 'Love Connection' and 'Scrabble,' dies at 83
SUMMARY: The affable, smooth-talking game show host of "Wheel of Fortune," "Love Connection" and "Scrabble" later became a right-wing podcaster.

TITLE: Uruguay's leftist opposition candidate becomes country's new president
SUMMARY: The election was free of the anti-establishment fury that has vaulted populist outsiders to power elsewhere, like the United States and neighboring Argentina.

TITLE: Foreign ministers meet in Italy for the last G7 of the Biden administration
SUMMARY: Foreign ministers from the world's leading industrialized nations are meeting Monday, with a certain pressure to advance diplomatic efforts ahead of the new U.S. administration taking over.

TITLE: New Zealanders help save about 30 whales after a pod strands on a beach
SUMMARY: New Zealand is a whale stranding hotspot. It's often not clear why they happen but the island nation's geography is believed to be a factor.

TITLE: Should sex abuse evidence set the Menendez brothers free? A judge will decide.
SUMMARY: A judge will decide Monday whether new evidence warrants a re-examination of the convictions of Erik and Lyle Menendez in the shotgun murders of their parents 30 years ago.

TITLE: Adultery is no longer illegal in New York
SUMMARY: It was considered a Class B misdemeanor, which carries a jail sentence of up to three months.

TITLE: After 15 years, Megan Atherton reunites with her 'Unsung Hero'
SUMMARY: A special reunion conversation between Megan Atherton and the woman who changed the course of her life.

TITLE: Plastic waste is everywhere. Countries have one more chance to agree on a solution
SUMMARY: Negotiations over a U.N. treaty to cut plastics have been bogged down. Environmental groups blame the oil and gas industry.

TITLE: Romania in shock after far-right populist enters presidential election's runoff
SUMMARY: Romania's political landscape is reeling after a little-known, far-right populist secured the first round in the presidential election, going from an obscure candidate to beating the incumbent prime minister.

TITLE: The holidays are stressful. Restore your calm with these 5 quick tricks
SUMMARY: Keep these science-backed stress busters in your back pocket this holiday season. Whip 'em out the next time you're at a table full of bickering in-laws or your flight gets canceled!

TITLE: The history of one of Washington's weirdest traditions: the turkey pardon
SUMMARY: The history of the presidential turkey pardon is often misremembered. Here are the fowl facts.

TITLE: You can reduce your risk of dementia. Here's how to get started
SUMMARY: About 40% of dementia cases could be prevented or delayed by healthy lifestyle choices and preventive medicine. Here's a tool to gauge your brain care and track your progress.

TITLE: Tips from a top chef to beat holiday cooking stress
SUMMARY: Tips from a top chef to beat holiday cooking stress

TITLE: The man who helped roll back abortion rights now wants to "crush liberal dominance"
SUMMARY: Leonard Leo of the Federalist Society helped overturn abortion rights. He spoke to <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: These senators are key to the approval of cabinet picks. Plus, Thanksgiving recipes
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet picks will need approval from the Republican-led Senate. Here's who to watch. And, make-ahead recipes for Thanksgiving.

TITLE: Long COVID patients push to see federal research refocused on treatments
SUMMARY: The federal government has allocated $1.15 billion so far on long COVID research, without bringing any new treatments to market. Patients and scientists say it's time to push harder for breakthroughs.

TITLE: The man who helped roll back abortion rights now wants to 'crush liberal dominance'
SUMMARY: Leonard Leo of the Federalist Society helped overturn abortion rights. He spoke to <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Comic D.J. Demers jokes a lot about hearing loss  — but won't be 'the hearing aid guy'
SUMMARY: Demers was diagnosed with hearing loss when he was 4 years old. As a kid, he saw nothing funny about it — but then he learned to make people laugh. He just dropped his fourth stand-up special.

TITLE: Ocean explorers hoped they photographed Amelia Earhart's plane. Turns out it's a rock
SUMMARY: Earhart, her navigator and their plane disappeared during their attempted 1937 circumnavigation of the globe. A deep sea exploration company thought it might have solved the mystery, but it lives on.

TITLE: Macy's says an employee hid as much as $154 million in expenses
SUMMARY: The employee "intentionally made erroneous accounting accrual entries" to hide millions of dollars, Macy's said. The error forced the company to delay reporting its third quarter results.

TITLE: 'I think of my body as a teacher,' says Marine who struggled with disordered eating
SUMMARY: During her years as a military linguist, Bailey Williams pushed her body to extremes. Her new book is <em>Hollow: A Memoir of My Body in the Marines.

TITLE: Prosecutors file motion to dismiss Jan. 6 case against Trump
SUMMARY: The move was widely expected after Trump's election victory, and is in line with longstanding Justice Department policy that says a sitting president cannot be indicted or tried on criminal charges.

TITLE: Ed Sheeran and Fuse ODG rebuke Band Aid charity song. We ask Kenyans to weigh in
SUMMARY: The singers have criticized "They Don't Know It's Christmas" for perpetuating "damaging stereotypes" of Africans as a charity case. Bob Geldof defends the song. We went to Kibera for comments.

TITLE: Prosecutors file motion to dismiss Jan. 6, documents case against Trump
SUMMARY: The move was widely expected after Trump's election victory, and is in line with longstanding Justice Department policy that says a sitting president cannot be indicted or tried on criminal charges.

TITLE: The Consequences of Refusing to Serve in Israel's Military
SUMMARY:
Israel has mandatory military services for citizens over the age of eighteen that meet certain requirements, and refusing to serve, which has always been controversial is even more contentious now that the country is fighting in Gaza and Lebanon. We meet one young person choosing to go to jail rather than serve in the military.

Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org
Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

TITLE: Judge grants dismissal of Jan. 6 case against Trump
SUMMARY: The move came after federal prosecutors filed a motion to dismiss both the Jan. 6 and Mar-a-Lago documents cases against Donald Trump.

TITLE: Lebanon's first responders say Israeli strikes target them as they work to save lives
SUMMARY: More than 200 emergency and medical workers have been killed since last October, Lebanon's health ministry says. Many believe Israel's military is targeting them in its war against Hezbollah.

TITLE: Trump threatens Canada, Mexico, China with tariffs
SUMMARY: He said the countries weren't doing enough to control the flow of illegal drugs, especially fentanyl, and migrants across the border.

TITLE: Was the Infowars auction fair? A judge wants to hear arguments in December
SUMMARY: The Onion's bid came out on top, but a bankruptcy judge must sign off on the sale. Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and the losing bidder says the process was "rigged" against them.

TITLE: U.N. report: 85,000 cases of femicide in 2023. And that's likely an undercount
SUMMARY: These are women murdered by an intimate partner, a family member, a rapist, a stranger randomly assaulting females. Laws do not always offer protection and justice. What needs to be done?

TITLE: Walmart becomes latest -- and biggest -- company to roll back its DEI policies
SUMMARY: Conservative groups have filed lawsuits against workplace diversity initiatives that prioritize historically marginalized groups.

TITLE: Supporters of ousted Pakistani leader clash with police, at least six people killed
SUMMARY: Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds and at least one person has died in clashes.

TITLE: Formula 1 expands grid to add General Motors' Cadillac brand and new American team
SUMMARY: The approval ends years of wrangling that launched a U.S. Justice Department investigation into why Colorado-based Liberty Media, the commercial rights holder of F1, would not approve the team.

TITLE: Trump has promised lower taxes. These are 3 ways it could impact you
SUMMARY: From "no tax on tips" to Social Security, Donald Trump has made a range of promises about the taxes Americans will pay. We take a look at three changes we could see in the months ahead.

TITLE: Dirt-cheap toys imported into U.S. can be dangerous, group says. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: "We rarely come out and say, 'You should not do this.' But this is one of the exceptions," consumer advocate Teresa Murray says, warning against the lure of rock-bottom prices from unfamiliar sellers.

TITLE: Mohammad Rasoulof left Iran after making his most daring film
SUMMARY: Dissident filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof talks about how he escaped Iran on foot after making his new political thriller, <em>The Seed of the Sacred Fig

TITLE: Gospel-focused racial reconciliation in the Deep South
SUMMARY: Two former leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention, one Black and one white, want to bridge the Deep South's racial divide with faith-based discussions in cities once active in the slave trade.

TITLE: Angela Merkel and the future of NATO under a second Trump term
SUMMARY: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel says she had to consider whether she is a "feminist." She joined NPR's Mary Louise Kelly to discuss her new memoir, <em>Freedom

TITLE: After a break from strength training, muscle memory may help you bounce back
SUMMARY: If the season or an injury has derailed your gym routine, don't sweat it. New research shows your muscles can regain lost strength faster than you might think.

TITLE: The price America paid for its first big immigration crackdown
SUMMARY: The Chinese Exclusion Act was the first significant crackdown on immigration in American history. We explore the factors that led to the Act and examine what happened to the economy after it passed.

TITLE: Walmart becomes latest — and biggest — company to roll back its DEI policies
SUMMARY: Conservative groups have filed lawsuits against workplace diversity initiatives that prioritize historically marginalized groups.

TITLE: How Trump wants to cut spending. And, possible Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire deal
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump wants to use a presidential impoundment to make big cuts to government spending. And, what could block a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hezbollah.

TITLE: A new congressman nabs his great-grandfather's old office after a little lobbying
SUMMARY: After he's sworn in, Rep.-elect Tom Barrett of Michigan will work in the Capitol office his great-grandfather once used. Rep. Louis Rabaut died in 1961, two decades before Barrett was born.

TITLE: Eyewitnesses in Gaza say Israel is using sniper drones to shoot Palestinians
SUMMARY: NPR has collected multiple eyewitness accounts about small, gun-carrying drones shooting — and sometimes killing — civilians in Gaza. Israel's military has not confirmed whether it uses sniper drones.

TITLE: Supporters of ousted Pakistani leader Imran Khan clash with police
SUMMARY: Protesters surged into the capital Islamabad -- amid gunfire and teargas -- as they demanded the release of former Prime Minister Imran Khan.

TITLE: 'Demure' is Dictionary.com's word of the year. If that's news to you, here's the backstory
SUMMARY: Usage of the word soared after TikToker Jools Lebron used it in her signature catchphrase "very demure, very mindful."

TITLE: Severe weather threatens Thanksgiving travel for millions as officials warn of delays
SUMMARY: Millions of drivers and air travelers may face severe weather and long lines over the next few days. More than 50,000 flights are expected to take off on Tuesday, one of the busiest travel days.

TITLE: Beer before liquor? Busting 6 popular myths about hangovers
SUMMARY: People have a lot of opinions about how to cure a hangover. Are any of them true? Medical experts dispel common misconceptions about the effects of drinking too much alcohol.

TITLE: Netanyahu urges his cabinet to approve a ceasefire with Hezbollah in Lebanon
SUMMARY: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is urging Israel's security Cabinet to approve a ceasefire with Hezbollah, paving the way for a possible pause in over a year of fighting with the Iran-backed group.

TITLE: With a record number of international students in the U.S., Trump brings uncertainty
SUMMARY: Some schools and international students in the U.S. worry about what's to come in the incoming Trump administration. Meanwhile, a new report finds more international students in the U.S. than ever.

TITLE: Israel agrees to a ceasefire with Hezbollah that could stop the war in Lebanon
SUMMARY: Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with the militant group Hezbollah, bringing a possible pause in fighting on a major front of a war that's jolted the region since October 2023.

TITLE: Trump's tariffs may be targeted at others -- but they could impact you too
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump threatened to slap hefty tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico. Those tariffs would hurt America too — if they are carried out.

TITLE: A Ceasefire Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon
SUMMARY:
Israel has agreed to a ceasefire with the militant group Hezbollah in Lebanon that hopes to bring an end to 13 months of fighting which has uprooted masses of civilians on both sides, and left immense destruction. We hear from NPR reporters on both sides of the conflict.

Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org
Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

TITLE: Trump team signs a key transition agreement with Biden White House
SUMMARY: This is one of two agreements that was supposed to have been signed by Oct. 1. The Trump team has decided to forgo the second one, saying it has its own systems in place.

TITLE: Ceasefire between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah militants has begun
SUMMARY: A ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah went into effect at 4 a.m. Wednesday local time. Israel agreed Tuesday to the ceasefire to stop the war it's been fighting with the Iran-backed militant group for over a year.

TITLE: Trump turns to critic of COVID mandates to run NIH
SUMMARY: Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, a Stanford health researcher, is in line to lead the National Institutes of Health. Early in the pandemic he argued against lockdowns and focusing on people at highest risk.

TITLE: Brazil police report: Bolsonaro planned and participated in a 2022 coup plot
SUMMARY: The document describe the former president as one of the key leaders of the plot, and not a mere observer.

TITLE: Pakistan ends lockdown of its capital after dispersing Imran Khan supporters
SUMMARY: The operation came hours after thousands of Khan supporters broke through a barrier of shipping containers blocking off Islamabad and clashed with security forces.

TITLE: After turkey, take a trot. A little post-meal walk can be a big boost for health
SUMMARY: Among the latest health hacks to go viral on TikTok is the idea of short post-dinner "fart walk" to aid digestion. Turns out, the science on this trend is solid, and so are the health benefits.

TITLE: More deals, more spending: What Black Friday has in store
SUMMARY: This holiday shopping season is poised to break spending records. A new survey finds people plan to spend $771 on average.

TITLE: Israel and Hezbollah ceasefire takes effect. And, TSA-approved Thanksgiving foods
SUMMARY: Israel and the Iran-backed militant group Hezbollah begins their ceasefire, but many remain displaced. And, if you are traveling for the holidays here are the foods you can bring through TSA.

TITLE: PHOTOS: A drone's eye view of 'foodscapes,' from cattle to soybeans to shrimp
SUMMARY: Traveling to 36 countries and 5 oceans, George Steinmetz (and his drones) take us on a food tour in his new book <em>Feed the Planet:  A Photographic Journey to the World's Food

TITLE: Over 500 fossilized poops show how dinosaurs came to rule the Earth
SUMMARY: Researchers reconstructed the Triassic food web using nothing but scat.

TITLE: Traffic citations against Miami Dolphins star Tyreek Hill are dropped
SUMMARY: Tyreek Hill of the Miami Dolphins was cited for careless driving and failure to wear a seat belt in September. The citations were dismissed after the officers involved did not appear in court.

TITLE: A Remote Island Outpost that is Part of a Geopolitical Fight (Encore)
SUMMARY: In an episode we first brought you in April, we go to southeast Asia and the Spratly Islands.  Ownership of those island are in dispute. This has been the case for hundreds of years, but tensions have been raised recently as China has tried to expand its claims in the remote area. We get a rare glimpse of one of the islands that has a Filipino community living on it.

TITLE: China has freed 3 Americans following an apparent prisoner swap deal with the U.S.
SUMMARY: In a statement to NPR, a State Department spokesperson said all the "wrongfully detained" Americans in China are now home.

TITLE: The National Dog Show explained: How a dog contest became a Thanksgiving tradition
SUMMARY: Football isn't the only thing Americans like to watch on Thanksgiving. The National Dog Show continues its decades-long run, this time with a brand new breed. Here's what to know and how to watch.

TITLE: Is 'Do Unto Others' the way to bridge the political divide?
SUMMARY:
On a Sunday in mid-July, Pastor Chris Morgan welcomed worshipers to Christ United Methodist Church in suburban Pittsburgh with a simple message.

That Sunday was particularly difficult.

A day earlier, a man had nearly assassinated then-candidate Donald Trump forty miles north in Butler. Morgan asked people to pray for Trump and those killed and injured in the shooting, and asked the congregation to pray for the family of the shooter.

Morgan had already planned a sermon series, called Do Unto Others, to deal with the nation's — and his congregation's — political divisions ahead of Election Day.

NPR's Frank Langfitt went to Christ Church the weekend before Election Day – and the weekend after – to see if the efforts there made a difference.

As Americans prepare to come together at Thanksgiving, how do we bridge this country's political divide? And can we?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: How to watch Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, a tradition 100 years in the making
SUMMARY: Macy's is promising its largest Thanksgiving Day parade yet, exactly 100 years after the tradition first started. Here's a look at what to expect and how to watch.

TITLE: Federal judge dismisses defamation lawsuit against Fox News
SUMMARY: A judge threw out a suit against Fox News by a former Trump supporter who said he got death threats when the network aired false conspiracy theories about his involvement in the Jan. 6 insurrection.

TITLE: The world welcomes the Israel-Hezbollah ceasefire, but worries remain
SUMMARY: Celebratory gunfire rang out in Beirut to mark the start of a ceasefire between Israel and the Iran-backed militant group Hezbollah to end almost 14 months of fighting.

TITLE: A TikTok sale under Trump? Experts say it could actually happen this time
SUMMARY: Will TikTok be sold? The question has been asked before, during Trump's first term. But now, the situation has changed considerably.

TITLE: Here's why bird flu fears are intensifying
SUMMARY: Efforts to contain the virus are falling short. A teenager in Canada is in critical condition after an unexplained infection. And the arrival of flu season has scientists on edge.

TITLE: Court backs Texas over razor wire installed on US-Mexico border
SUMMARY: A federal appeals court Wednesday ruled that Border Patrol agents cannot cut razor wire that Texas installed on the U.S.-Mexico border in the town of Eagle Pass, Texas.

TITLE: Court backs Texas over razor wire installed on U.S.-Mexico border
SUMMARY: A federal appeals court Wednesday ruled that Border Patrol agents cannot cut razor wire that Texas installed on the U.S.-Mexico border in the town of Eagle Pass, Texas.

TITLE: Trump transition says Cabinet picks, appointees were targeted by bomb threats, swatting attacks
SUMMARY: Among those targeted were New York Rep. Elise Stefanik, Trump's pick to serve as ambassador to the United Nations, and Matt Gaetz, Trump's initial pick to serve as attorney general.

TITLE: Return to the Motherland or Illegal Land Transfer? Depends on Who You Ask (Encore)
SUMMARY: In an episode we first posted in January, we go to the West African country of Ghana.  The Ghanaian government began encouraging people of African descent from around the world to move to the country in 2019, calling it the "Year of Return". They even created settlements for the people who took them up on the offer, giving out free land. But our correspondent talks to locals who say their farm land was stolen to give to foreigners.

TITLE: Zuckerberg dines with Trump in Mar-a-Lago
SUMMARY: A spokesperson for Meta confirmed that Zuckerberg and Trump met on Wednesday, saying he was invited for dinner with the president-elect to talk about the incoming administration.

TITLE: 'Tired. Damn tired.' Some Black women are processing the grief of a Kamala Harris loss
SUMMARY: Most Black women voters supported Kamala Harris in her presidential run against Donald Trump. Now some say they are pulling back, to rest and mourn.

TITLE: Concerned about arguments at Thanksgiving? NPR readers give tips to help
SUMMARY: Many topics have divided the nation recently. NPR asked readers for insights into how they handle divisive conversations over the holidays. Here are the tips they provided.

TITLE: Come for the roller coaster, stay for the shops: Can malls be fun again?
SUMMARY: Mall of America's recipe for success includes an amusement park, pop-up stores, weddings and raves. Can local malls take a page from the country's largest shopping center?

TITLE: Lebanon says 2 hurt as Israeli troops fire after truce with Hezbollah
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said it had fired at people trying to return to certain areas of southern Lebanon on the second day of a ceasefire with the Hezbollah militant group.

TITLE: A social media ban in Australia for children under 16 will be first in the world
SUMMARY: A social media ban for children under 16 will become first law in the world to levy fines on TikTok, Facebook, Snapchat, Reddit, X and Instagram for allowing youth accounts.

TITLE: Israel and Hezbollah have a ceasefire agreement. Here's what it says
SUMMARY: The ceasefire agreement between Hezbollah and Israel brokered by the United States and France was characterized by President Biden as an attempt to deliver a "permanent cessation of hostilities."

TITLE: Putin threatens Ukraine in remarks after former-Soviet states security summit
SUMMARY: Putin said his military may use another of its new hypersonic missiles to target government or official buildings in Kyiv, in response to Ukraine's continued use of American and British weapons.

TITLE: Vito the pug is the first of his breed to win National Dog Show's top prize
SUMMARY: Vito, a pug from Chapel Hill, N.C., beat out more than 1,900 dogs representing more than 200 breeds and varieties that competed in this year's event.

TITLE: A social media ban in Australia for children under 16 is first in the world
SUMMARY: A social media ban for children under 16 will be the first law in the world to levy fines on TikTok, Facebook, Snapchat, Reddit, X and Instagram for allowing youth accounts.

TITLE: China sentences veteran journalist on espionage charges
SUMMARY: Longtime state media journalist Dong Yuyu met often with journalists and diplomats. His family believes he is now being persecuted for those exchanges.

TITLE: Democratic lawmakers report Thanksgiving bomb threats against their homes
SUMMARY: At least five Democratic members of Congress from Connecticut were targeted by bomb threats on Thursday. Police who responded said they found no evidence of explosives on the lawmakers' properties.

TITLE: Who Invented Indian Butter Chicken? (Encore)
SUMMARY:
In an episode we first brought you in March, we consider butter chicken. It is a much-loved Indian dish, both within that country and around the world. But who can claim they invented it? That question is the subject of a lawsuit. Our reporter tries to get to the bottom of butter chicken's origin and finds out that it is a journey through India's history.

You can find celebrated Indian chef Madhur Jaffrey's recipe for butter chicken here

TITLE: O Christmas tree, O Christmas tree, which is more sustainable: real or plasticky?
SUMMARY: It's time to discuss one of the perennial debates of the holiday season. Are real Christmas trees or their fake counterparts more eco-friendly?

TITLE: How do you re-create the voice of a 15th century king? Dig up his skeleton
SUMMARY: When Richard III's skeleton was found under a parking lot in England in 2012, it was an exciting enough discovery for the general public, but a game-changer for Yvonne Morley-Chisholm.

TITLE: Ireland votes in a close-run election where incumbents hope to cling on to power
SUMMARY: The parliamentary election will decide the next government, and will show whether Ireland bucks the global trend of incumbents being ousted by disgruntled voters.

TITLE: Disappointed by this year's climate talks, Indigenous advocates look to Brazil in 2025
SUMMARY: Indigenous advocates called the final agreement in Azerbaijan "drastically insufficient." Now they're focusing on next year's global climate summit in Brazil where Indigenous participation is expected to be historic.

TITLE: Venezuela's opposition leader says Maduro is 'weaker than ever'
SUMMARY: From hiding, María Corina Machado says she'll continue to fight for Venezuelan democracy.

TITLE: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season was the deadliest in nearly two decades
SUMMARY: The six-month season saw an above-average number of storms. Scientists say climate change is leading to more powerful and deadly hurricanes that can affect inland communities far from the coasts.

TITLE: Books We Love is back. Here are some highlights. And, what to expect on Black Friday
SUMMARY: NPR staffers bring you more than 300 new book recommendations in the latest edition of Books We Love. Plus, what to expect from a record-breaking holiday spending season.

TITLE: 2 pediatricians answer your questions about traveling with kids over the holidays
SUMMARY: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with pediatricians Candice Jones and Jaime Friedman, who offer tips on how to travel with little ones. (Story aired on Morning Edition on Nov. 24, 2024.)

TITLE: Radio host remembers the person who cultivated her voice: her grandmother
SUMMARY: In this week's StoryCorps, Philadelphia radio host Cherri Gregg remembers her grandmother, Maryhall Fuller Robinson Snead, who helped her find her voice.

TITLE: To help someone going through a crisis, use these 7 words
SUMMARY: Author and TV host Kelly Corrigan has a radical way to support a loved one through a crisis, big or small. Here's her technique to make someone feel like it's safe to open up.

TITLE: All I want for Christmas is ... help getting this song out of my head
SUMMARY: The Earworm Eraser is a 40-second audio track specifically designed to banish "Jingle Bells," "All I Want For Christmas Is You" and other much-too-catchy seasonal tunes.

TITLE: British lawmakers push forward a divisive bill to legalize assisted dying
SUMMARY: In a historic vote, lawmakers advanced a bill that would grant the option of assisted dying to those in England and Wales with a terminal diagnosis and a life expectancy of six months or less.

TITLE: A restored Notre Dame cathedral is unveiled days before its official reopening
SUMMARY: Notre Dame Cathedral has been closed to the public since a fire damaged the landmark in April 2019.

TITLE: Millions are heading home from the holiday to face snow and an Artic blast
SUMMARY: Some parts of the country will receive heavy lake-effect snow and others will see rain or dry weather with subfreezing temperatures.

TITLE: Chinese crypto businessman eats his controversial $6.2 million banana art piece
SUMMARY: Justin Sun uploaded a video of himself eating the $6.2 million absurdist piece conceptualized by Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan.

TITLE: Banana art eaten, banana art purchase
SUMMARY: Justin Sun uploaded a video of himself eating the $6.2 million absurdist piece conceptualized by Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan.

TITLE: Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau flies to Florida to meet with Trump after tariffs threat
SUMMARY: Trudeau flew to Florida on Friday to have dinner with President-elect Donald Trump at his Mar-a-Lago club after Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs on Canadian products.

TITLE: In a shock offensive, insurgents breach Aleppo, Syria's largest city
SUMMARY: Insurgents breached Syria's largest city Friday and clashed with government forces for the first time since 2016, in a surprise attack that sent residents fleeing.

TITLE: O Christmas tree, O Christmas tree, which is more sustainable: real or plasticky?
SUMMARY: It's time to discuss one of the perennial debates of the holiday season. Are real Christmas trees or their fake counterparts more eco-friendly?

TITLE: Ireland headed for coalition government, exit poll suggests
SUMMARY: An exit poll in Ireland's parliamentary election released late Friday suggests the three biggest parties have won roughly equal shares and the country is headed for another coalition government.

TITLE: Reporter Journal: A sunrise trek through wild solitude in New York City
SUMMARY: New York City is home to more than eight million people but NPR's Brian Mann mapped out an urban hike through solitude and parkland wildness.

TITLE: Opinion: The life and work of Seuk Kim, pilot and animal rescuer
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon remembers Seuk Kim, a volunteer animal rescue pilot who died in a crash earlier this week, transporting several dogs.

TITLE: How to solve the Gen Z social isolation problem? She tried surfing and it worked
SUMMARY: Young people today spend nearly 1,000 fewer hours per year hanging out with friends in person than they did 20 years ago. Some solutions for the loneliness epidemic are coming from unlikely places.

TITLE: SunFed cucumbers and Costco eggs recalled for potential salmonella contamination
SUMMARY: Cucumbers shipped to the U.S. and Canada, and organic eggs sold in 25 Costco stores in five southern U.S. states, were recalled this week for potential salmonella contamination.

TITLE: Millions are heading home from the holiday to face snow and an Arctic blast
SUMMARY: Some parts of the country will receive heavy lake-effect snow and others will see rain or dry weather with subfreezing temperatures.

TITLE: Chinese crypto businessman eats his controversial $6.2 million banana art piece
SUMMARY: Justin Sun uploaded a video of himself eating the $6.2 million absurdist piece conceptualized by Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan.

TITLE: Canada's Trudeau says he had an 'excellent conversation' with Trump after tariffs threat
SUMMARY: The Canadian prime minister's meeting with Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago came after the president-elect's threat to impose tariffs on two of America's leading trade partners raised alarms.

TITLE: World Central Kitchen workers killed by Israeli airstrike, Gaza health ministry says
SUMMARY: An Israeli airstrike hit a car in the Gaza Strip on Saturday, killing five people, including at least three employees with the food aid charity. World Central Kitchen said that it was "urgently seeking more details."

TITLE: FIFA should pay workers harmed in building World Cup venues, its committee report says
SUMMARY: The report said the main responsibility lay with the workers' direct employers and the Qatari government, but noted that "a credible argument can be made" that FIFA played a role as well.

TITLE: Trump picks longtime ally Kash Patel to replace current FBI director
SUMMARY: The president-elect plans to replace current FBI Director Christopher Wray with Patel, a close ally of the president-elect and former national security aide, has berated the Justice Department and the news media.

TITLE: How a Syrian rebel group pulled off its stunning seizure of Aleppo
SUMMARY: Over a few days, rebel fighters in northern Syria have launched incursions into several major cities with little resistance from government troops.

TITLE: Heavy snow blankets parts of the U.S. during busy holiday travel weekend
SUMMARY: Frigid air was expected to move over the eastern third of the U.S. by Monday, while heavy snow was forecast to cause hazards in the Great Lakes, Plains and Midwest regions.

TITLE: The 'magical' advent calendar that's as big as a town hall
SUMMARY: A small town in Germany turns its town hall into the 'world's largest' advent calendar each December. It started as a way to boost businesses in the winter, but it's grown to mean much more.

TITLE: Protesters gather for third night of demonstrations after Georgia announces suspension of EU talks
SUMMARY: Protesters gathered across Georgia on Saturday night in a third straight night of demonstrations against the government's decision to suspend negotiations to join the European Union.

TITLE: The 'Chinese Exclusion Era' shows how Trump's mass deportation plan could unfold
SUMMARY:
Donald Trump promises to deport millions of unauthorized immigrants once he returns to the White House. If he follows through, the scale of it would be unlike anything we've seen in our lifetimes.

Many supporters of Trump's mass deportation agenda say expelling unauthorized immigrants will help the US economy. But a look back at America's first major immigration crackdown suggests otherwise.

On this episode, host Adrian Ma and his colleagues from NPR's The Indicator podcast look at that immigration crackdown during the 'Chinese Exclusion Era,' and the economic impact it had on the West.

For a deeper dive into the economic history of the Chinese Exclusion Era, check out the latest installments of Planet Money's newsletter. In Part One, NPR's Greg Rosalsky covers the economic circumstances that led to a populist anti-Chinese movement. In Part Two, he explains the ways (both legal and extralegal) that movement succeeded in driving Chinese immigrants away from the U.S. and the economic fallout that ensued.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: UN says it is halting aid through main Gaza crossing because route is too dangerous
SUMMARY: The U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees said Sunday it is halting aid deliveries through the main cargo crossing into Gaza because of the threat of armed gangs who have looted recent convoys.

TITLE: Ira Glass admits he plays a 'nicer version' of himself on the radio
SUMMARY: <em>This American Life

TITLE: Protesters gather for third night of action after Georgia suspends EU talks
SUMMARY: Protesters gathered across Georgia on Saturday night in a third straight night of demonstrations against the government's decision to suspend negotiations to join the European Union.

TITLE: How to be not lonely? 'Cohousing' is an answer for some people
SUMMARY: In cohousing communities, neighbors share common spaces, chores and a sense of connection that benefits everyone. For some, it's an answer to the isolation of parenting that many families feel today.

TITLE: Over 40 people hospitalized in Georgia during protests over suspension of EU talks
SUMMARY: A third night of protests in Tbilisi over the government's decision to suspend talks to join the European Union left 44 people hospitalized as police used water cannons and tear gas, officials said.

TITLE: Lake effect snow is expected to continue pummeling parts of the Northeast and Midwest
SUMMARY: Some areas across the Great Lakes region have already received up to 3 feet of lake effect snow.

TITLE: Stellantis CEO resigns as carmaker continues to struggle with slumping sales
SUMMARY: Carlos Tavares is stepping down after nearly four years in the top spot of the automaker, which owns car brands like Jeep and Ram, amid an ongoing struggle with slumping sales.

TITLE: President Biden pardons his son. And, which Christmas trees are more sustainable
SUMMARY: President Biden has pardoned his son Hunter Biden, who he says was "selectively and unfairly prosecuted." And, a look into whether real or fake Christmas trees are better for the environment.

TITLE: Landmark climate change case will open at the top U.N. court
SUMMARY: The U.N.'s top court begins hearings Monday on the legal obligation of countries to fight climate change.

TITLE: As federal aid shrinks, communities try new ways to tackle child poverty on their own
SUMMARY: After Congress ended extra cash aid for families, local efforts aimed to fill the gap. In Flint, Michigan, Rx Kids gives cash aid to every family for a baby's first year. Will it work elsewhere?

TITLE: Dizzy after one drink? Social drinkers on obesity drugs lose the taste for alcohol
SUMMARY: A new study finds people who take weight-loss drugs also cut back on alcohol consumption. Researchers think the drugs could be a promising new treatment for addiction.

TITLE: Who are the rebels who have seized control of Aleppo, Syria?
SUMMARY: Syrian rebels have swept through parts of the country at lightning pace, taking control of the the second-largest city, Aleppo. But who are they and what are their aims?

TITLE: Crash prevention technology shows 'huge potential,' but the roadmap is up for debate
SUMMARY: Nearly all new cars now come with automatic emergency braking and other safety features. Researchers say these systems are saving lives, but there's still debate about how to make them better.

TITLE: FDA battles vaping industry at the Supreme Court
SUMMARY: The justices will hear arguments about the FDA's rejection of some e-cigarettes. High schoolers are at the center of the case.

TITLE: A landmark climate change case will open at the top U.N. court
SUMMARY: The hearings come after years of lobbying by island nations who fear they could simply disappear under rising sea waters,

TITLE: Hong Kong launches panda sculpture tour as the city hopes the bear craze boosts tourism
SUMMARY: Thousands of giant panda sculptures will greet residents and tourists starting Saturday in Hong Kong, where enthusiasm for the bears has grown since two cubs were born in a local theme park.

TITLE: The International Criminal Court is facing doubts as its member states meet
SUMMARY: The court faces pushback over arrest warrants for Israeli officials, sexual harassment allegations against the court's chief prosecutor and a very empty docket.

TITLE: TelevisaUnivision's CEO on the network's approach to covering President Trump's 2nd term
SUMMARY: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Daniel Alegre, the CEO of TelevisaUnivision, about his op-ed on the changing attitudes of Latino voters.

TITLE: Biden isn't the first president to pardon a relative. Here's how the power works
SUMMARY: Biden is now the third president to pardon a relative, after Bill Clinton and Donald Trump. Here's a look at the commonplace — yet often controversial — presidential power.

TITLE: President Biden makes long awaited trip to Africa
SUMMARY: President Biden makes his first and only trip to Africa in his presidency, as he travels to Cabo Verde and Angola.

TITLE: At Supreme Court, vaping may be frowned upon, but that could change with Trump
SUMMARY: The focal point of the case is 2009 law enacted by Congress that gives the Food and Drug Administration a mandate to curb the availability of nicotine products for minors.

TITLE: The U.S. is facing a youth mental health crisis. These skaters want to help
SUMMARY: The Skate Mind Project is working to bring psychological first aid to the skatepark — promoting stronger relationships within skating culture, and emphasizing parks and shops as community centers.

TITLE: Rebels Make Surprise Advances in Syria. Who are They and What Does it Mean?
SUMMARY:
Syria's bloody civil war against the government of Bashar al-Assad started in 2011 but it had been in a stalemate for years. All that changed recently when rebels lead by a group called Hayat Tahrir al-Sham rapidly routed government forces seizing the second most populous Syria city, Aleppo. We hear reaction from Syrians and about the group behind the revival of the conflict.

Support NPR and get sponsor-free episodes of State of the World. Sign up for NPR+ at plus.npr.org
Or donate to NPR this Giving Tuesday at donate.npr.org

TITLE: Writer Thoreau warned of brain rot in 1854. Now it's the Oxford Word of 2024
SUMMARY: The term brain rot first appeared in Henry David Thoreau's famous <em>Walden

TITLE: Photos: See inside the Bidens' last White House Christmas
SUMMARY: More than 300 volunteers spent the past week decorating the White House's public spaces and its 83 Christmas trees with nearly 10,000 feet of ribbon, more than 28,000 ornaments, over 2,200 paper doves and some 165,000 lights used on wreaths, garlands and other displays, according to the Associated Press.

TITLE: Joe Biden pardons his son. Is that justice?
SUMMARY:
Hunter Biden no longer has to worry about going to prison.

That's because his father President Joe Biden pardoned him with just weeks left in his presidency. The President's son was convicted in June on federal gun charges. Hunter Biden lied about his addiction to crack cocaine when he purchased a gun. And he pleaded guilty in September for failing to pay more than a million dollars in federal taxes.

The younger Biden was due to be sentenced in both cases later this month.

President Biden has granted his son a sweeping pardon. What will that mean for his legacy... and for the future of presidential pardons?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Creator of '2000 Mules' apologizes to man falsely accused of ballot fraud in the film
SUMMARY: Filmmaker and conservative pundit Dinesh D'Souza has issued a statement saying "inaccurate information" was provided to him about ballot box surveillance videos featured in the film.

TITLE: Negotiators fail to reach an agreement on a plastic pollution treaty. Talks to resume next year
SUMMARY: The negotiations in Busan, South Korea, were supposed to be the fifth and final round to produce the first legally binding treaty on plastics pollution, including in the oceans, by the end of 2024.

TITLE: U.S. will send Ukraine $725 million more in arms
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden has pledged to spend all of the military assistance funds Congress approved this year for Ukraine before the end of his administration on Jan. 20, 2025.

TITLE: Trump falls just below 50% in popular vote, but gets more than in past elections
SUMMARY: This year's popular-vote margin is the second-closest since 1968 and still tightening. It shows just how closely divided the country is politically<strong>,

TITLE: Teens can't get off their phones. Here's what some schools are doing about it
SUMMARY: Teens spend much of their days on their phones — many of them during school. Here's how schools and teachers are trying to fix that.

TITLE: 'Tis the season for porch pirates. Here are some tips to help protect your items
SUMMARY: Retailers are warning Americans to be vigilant about their packages and not let porch pirates steal the holiday spirit,

TITLE: The fight against medical debt is pivoting to the states after Trump's election
SUMMARY: Patient and consumer advocates fear a new Trump administration will scale back federal efforts to expand financial protections for patients and shield them from debt.

TITLE: The 2024 popular vote margin is tight. And, the history of Oxford's word of the year
SUMMARY: The 2024 popular vote margin between President-elect Donald Trump and Vice President Harris is tight. Here's what that says about America. And, the history of 'brain rot,' Oxford's word of the year.

TITLE: South Korea's president declares martial law
SUMMARY: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared an "emergency martial law" on Tuesday, accusing the opposition of paralyzing the government with anti-state activities.

TITLE: As Israel bans UNRWA, Palestinians stand to lose schools and clinics not only in Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel is severing ties with the main United Nations agency that provides aid to Palestinians. With the focus largely on Gaza, the move also threatens key services in the occupied West Bank.

TITLE: How do you make a film about Afghan women protesters without being in Afghanistan?
SUMMARY: Getting footage from the ground was a challenge for the director of <em>Bread & Roses.

TITLE: As Israel bans UNRWA, Palestinians stand to lose schools and clinics, not only in Gaza
SUMMARY: Israel is severing ties with the main United Nations agency that provides aid to Palestinians. With the focus largely on Gaza, the move also threatens key services in the occupied West Bank.

TITLE: The Gaza war has shaken up the Mideast. Now Syria's war has reignited
SUMMARY: Rebels have rekindled Syria's war with a lightning offensive that seemed to come from nowhere. But multiple upheavals, beginning with the Gaza war last year, have spread conflict across the region.

TITLE: 'Bread & Roses' is a guerrilla film about Afghan women protesters
SUMMARY: Getting footage from the ground was essential for filmmaker Sahra Mani, the director of <em>Bread & Roses.

TITLE: South Korea's lawmakers vote to lift president's martial law declaration
SUMMARY: South Korean lawmakers voted unanimously to reverse President Yoon Suk Yeol's declaration of an "emergency martial law" on Tuesday. Yoon had accused the opposition of anti-state activities.

TITLE: South Korea's lawmakers vote to lift the president's martial law declaration
SUMMARY: South Korean lawmakers voted unanimously to reverse President Yoon Suk Yeol's declaration of an "emergency martial law" on Tuesday. Yoon had accused the opposition of anti-state activities.

TITLE: J. Edgar Hoover made the FBI his personal weapon. Kash Patel could try doing it again
SUMMARY: Trump's pick to lead the FBI may test internal guardrails, historian and J. Edgar Hoover biographer Beverly Gage tells <em>Morning Edition.

TITLE: Putin's planes took Ukrainian kids into 'coerced' Russian adoption, a Yale report says
SUMMARY: Russia's president and senior Kremlin officials financed and facilitated the transport of at least 314 Ukrainian children into "coerced" foster care and adoptions, a new Yale University report says.

TITLE: South Korea's president says he will lift his martial law declaration
SUMMARY: After South Korean lawmakers voted to reverse President Yoon Suk Yeol's surprise declaration of "emergency martial law," Yoon announced that he would lift the order through a Cabinet meeting.

TITLE: Will Trump's next term make him richer?
SUMMARY:
Just before Donald Trump took office the first time, he held a press conference, announcing that he would turn over control of his business empire to his sons.

He said he wanted to address concerns about conflicts of interest even though he maintained he didn't really have to. Saying, "I could actually run my business. I could actually run my business and run government at the same time. I don't like the way that looks, but I would be able to do that if I wanted to."

Trump's second term may put that theory to the test. The former and future president hasn't yet announced any plan to wall himself off from his businesses while in office, and Trump's businesses like his many hotels and resorts could benefit substantially from his actions as President.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: What on Earth is Happening In South Korea?
SUMMARY: In a shocking turn of events, martial law was declared late at night by the president of South Korea, giving him extraordinary powers. Then after protests and an act of parliament, the order was reversed seven hours later. To try to understand what is happening with this key U.S. ally and trading partner, we hear from NPR's correspondent in Seoul.

TITLE: Elon Musk's more than $50 billion pay deal at Tesla was rejected again. Here is why
SUMMARY: A judge in Delaware has for the second time struck down a compensation package for Elon Musk after a Tesla shareholder filed suit.

TITLE: J. Edgar Hoover's biographer weighs in on Trump's pick to lead the FBI
SUMMARY: Kash Patel, Trump's pick to lead the FBI, may test internal guardrails, historian and J. Edgar Hoover biographer Beverly Gage tells <em>Morning Edition.

TITLE: Trump team signs an agreement with the DOJ for security clearances
SUMMARY: The new agreement will help Trump officials on agency landing teams access classified information needed to prepare to take over on Jan. 20.

TITLE: To many residents in southern Lebanon, life doesn't feel like there's a ceasefire
SUMMARY: Israel's military has imposed a curfew and created a no-go zone where villagers are prohibited from going home to villages across southern Lebanon. NPR speaks to residents inside.

TITLE: Search goes into the night for Pennsylvania woman who may have fallen into a sinkhole
SUMMARY: A grandmother looking for her lost cat apparently fell into a sinkhole that had recently opened above an abandoned coal mine and rescuers worked late into Tuesday night to try and find her.

TITLE: South Korea's president faces calls to resign or be impeached
SUMMARY: Opposition parties have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol and plans for rallies in major cities are underway.

TITLE: D.R. Congo's mining capital is at the heart of Biden's bid to counter China in Africa
SUMMARY: Kolwezi has some of the world's largest copper and cobalt reserves and that makes it a key location at the heart of the U.S. and China's jostle for mineral supremacy on the African continent.

TITLE: Supreme Court hears challenge to law banning gender-affirming care for trans kids
SUMMARY: At issue is a Tennessee law that bans access to hormones, puberty blockers, and other treatments for trans kids in the state.

TITLE: Inside RFK Jr.'s nonprofit's legal battles over vaccines and public health
SUMMARY: The nonprofit Children's Health Defense that Kennedy led has filed nearly 30 federal and state lawsuits since 2020, many challenging vaccines and public health mandates.

TITLE: 'Guardian' journalists strike to protest sale of sister paper 'Observer'
SUMMARY: Nearly 500 journalists have walked out of the Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, to protest what they see as a betrayal of the paper's values: the planned sale of the Observer

TITLE: North Carolina's voter ID law just got its first big test
SUMMARY: For more than a decade, North Carolina has seen a bitter back-and-forth over voter identification rules. The requirement finally got its first major test in last month's presidential election.

TITLE: South Korea's president faces calls to be impeached. And, tips to avoid porch pirates
SUMMARY: South Korea's president faces calls to resign or to be impeached after he briefly imposed martial law over the country. And, tips on how to avoid falling victim to porch pirates this holiday season.

TITLE: A North Carolina town is suing utility Duke Energy over climate change
SUMMARY: A small North Carolina town is suing Duke Energy for costs from climate change, claiming the utility knew its fossil fuel power plants were heating the planet and deceived the public.

TITLE: Nearly 500 journalists walk out at 'The Guardian' and its sister paper
SUMMARY: Nearly 500 journalists have walked out of the Guardian and its sister paper, the Observer, to protest what they see as a betrayal of the paper's values: the planned sale of the Observer

TITLE: Search continues for Pennsylvania woman who may have fallen into a sinkhole
SUMMARY: Rescuers contemplated the safest way to search for a woman who apparently fell into a Pennsylvania sinkhole while looking for her lost cat. A crumbling old coal mine was endangering rescue workers.

TITLE: After years of legal fights, North Carolina's voter ID law gets its first major test
SUMMARY: For more than a decade, North Carolina has seen a bitter back-and-forth over voter identification rules. The requirement finally got its first major test in last month's presidential election.

TITLE: What Trump's 2nd term might mean for the country's economy
SUMMARY: Economist David Wessel talks about Trump's plans on tariffs and tax cuts, and the potential economic impact of Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's Department of Government Efficiency.

TITLE: Montana lawmakers cross the aisle to block a trans bathroom ban in the state capitol
SUMMARY: Some Republicans joined Democrats in rejecting the measure, which would have restricted bathroom access. Rep. Zooey Zephyr, Montana's first openly transgender legislator, won a second term last month.

TITLE: Trump's SecDef pick Hegseth is under scrutiny. His mom went on TV to plead his case
SUMMARY: Pete Hegseth is fighting to keep his nomination on track after a series of negative reports about his past behavior — including a damning email his mom sent him during his second divorce.

TITLE: Who is Brian Thompson, the UnitedHealthcare CEO gunned down in New York?
SUMMARY: Thompson, a 50-year-old father of two, spent two decades at UnitedHealth Group before his shocking death. Tributes are pouring in from coworkers and public officials in his home state of Minnesota.

TITLE: Longer careers in ice hockey are linked to a greater risk of CTE, a new study finds
SUMMARY: A new Boston University study of 77 deceased male ice hockey players found that their chances of developing the degenerative brain disease known as CTE increased with each year they played the sport.

TITLE: Supreme Court appears skeptical of challenge to ban on gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: At issue is a state law in Tennessee that blocks minors from accessing gender-affirming care in the state.

TITLE: Trump's Defense pick Hegseth is under scrutiny. But he says he's 'not going anywhere'
SUMMARY: Pete Hegseth is fighting to keep his nomination on track after a series of negative reports about his past behavior — including a damning email his mom sent him during his second divorce.

TITLE: French lawmakers oust the prime minister after just 91 days, toppling the government
SUMMARY: France's government has been toppled by a no-confidence vote in parliament, for the first time sine 1962. Prime Minister Michel Barnier served the shortest time in the post in France's modern history.

TITLE: Trump chooses billionaire astronaut Jared Isaacman to run NASA
SUMMARY: Earlier this year, Isaacman became the first private citizen to conduct a spacewalk. But his longstanding ties with Elon Musk's company SpaceX raise possible conflicts of interest.

TITLE: Trump picks crypto backer Paul Atkins as new Securities and Exchange Commission chair
SUMMARY: Trump picked Atkins, a former SEC commissioner, to head the agency. Known for his support of cryptocurrencies, Atkins could help shape regulations for the industry.

TITLE: Afghan women reportedly barred from studying nursing and midwivery
SUMMARY: Several sources confirm the Taliban pronouncement, part of ongoing efforts to curtail education for girls and women. Women studying these subjects say they were barred from classes this week.

TITLE: The U.S. and China Vie for Influence in Africa
SUMMARY: Joe Biden's first and last trip to Africa as president wrapped up in a port city in Angola. It's the end of an 800 mile train line connecting the port to massive mineral deposits in Central Africa. The U.S. and other Western countries are raising billions to upgrade the rail line, a move that is seen as an effort to counter China's investments in mining in the region. We go to one of the mining cities along that train route to see how the geopolitics are playing out.

TITLE: Can Pete Hegseth's nomination survive?
SUMMARY:
At the time we publish this episode, Pete Hegseth, President-elect Trump's pick to run the Pentagon, is struggling to hold onto his nomination.

There's an ever growing list of accusations of sexual misconduct, alcohol abuse and financial misconduct.

The former Fox and Friends weekend host has spent Wednesday meeting with Senators and doing interviews trying to control the damage.

Pete Hegseth's nomination for Secretary of Defense hangs in the balance...will he survive?
