TITLE: Rights Group: Afghan women barred from studying nursing and midwivery
SUMMARY: Several sources confirm the Taliban pronouncement, part of ongoing efforts to curtail education for girls and women. Women studying these subjects say they were barred from classes this week.

TITLE: Supreme Court seems ready to uphold ban on gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: Three Tennessee families—and the Biden administration—are challenging the state's ban.

TITLE: Bitcoin hits $100,000 for the first time. 3 things to know about an incredible ride
SUMMARY: Bitcoin hit $100,000 for the first time. From how it got here to why critics are alarmed, here's what to know about the spectacular milestone.

TITLE: Legendary Medellin cartel drug lord released from U.S. prison after serving 25 years
SUMMARY: One of Colombia's legendary drug lords has been released from prison and is expected to be deported. Ochoa was first indicted in the U.S. for his alleged role in the 1986 killing of a DEA informant.

TITLE: A major power plant fails in Cuba, plunging the island into darkness — again
SUMMARY: The blackout, on Wednesday, affected the entire nation, leaving millions without electricity and forcing authorities to suspend classes and work activities indefinitely.

TITLE: The Black Gate: Vanished in the Night
SUMMARY: In the Xinjiang region of western China, the government has rounded up and detained hundreds of thousands of Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic groups, including the wife and young children of a Uyghur businessman named Abdullatif Kucar. NPR correspondent Emilly Feng follows Kucar as he desperately searches for his missing family. <em>To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

TITLE: Mexican troops seize a record fentanyl haul in northern Sinaloa state
SUMMARY: Mexican soldiers and marines have seized over a ton of fentanyl pills in two raids in the north, with officials calling it the biggest catch of the synthetic opioid in the country's history.

TITLE: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy take their DOGE government efficiency pitch to the Hill
SUMMARY: The leaders of the so-called "Department of Government Efficiency" are calling for large-scale layoffs of federal workers and the elimination of some federal agencies during Trump's second term.

TITLE: How sweet! A daily dose of dark chocolate may cut your risk of diabetes
SUMMARY: A new study finds people who eat a small, daily serving of dark chocolate have a reduced risk of developing Type 2 diabetes. People who ate milk chocolate did not have a lower risk. Here's why.

TITLE: An unknown infant was rushed to a Gaza hospital. A nurse gave her a name, and a home
SUMMARY: The newborn, found by rescuers after an Israeli attack, was rushed to a hospital. Nurse Amal Abu Khatleh gave her the name Malak, meaning angel. She is raising the baby until relatives can be found.

TITLE: The right (and wrong) things to say to a grieving friend
SUMMARY: It can be hard to find the right words to say to a friend whose loved one has died. Experts share the dos and don'ts of expressing condolences.

TITLE: How a staffing shortage can make special education jobs more dangerous
SUMMARY: Special educators are more likely to experience violence or aggression from students. That can make hiring a challenge, at a time when schools nationwide are struggling to fill these positions.

TITLE: Long before this week, South Korea had a painful history with martial law
SUMMARY: In 1980, violent clashes between government forces and pro-democracy demonstrators in the southwestern city of Gwangju created lasting scars that continue to shape South Korea to this day.

TITLE: Syrian opposition forces enter strategic city of Hama
SUMMARY: Syrian rebels have entered a second city in yet another blow to the President Bashar al-Assad after they took over Syria's second city only days before.

TITLE: Why do kids with cancer in the Global South have such low survival rates?
SUMMARY: In wealthy countries, a child diagnosed with cancer often has an excellent chance of survival. But in lower resource countries, survival rates are dramatically lower. What's going on?

TITLE: Hegseth fights to keep Defense nomination. And, police search for gunman who shot CEO
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump's defense secretary pick Pete Hegseth is fighting to keep the nomination. And, a New York City manhunt is underway for the killer of UnitedHealthcare's CEO Brian Thompson.

TITLE: The best games of 2024, picked by NPR's staff
SUMMARY: NPR staff and contributors share their favorite video games of 2024 so far.

TITLE: Pantone's 2025 color is Mocha Mousse: How the company sold color to the world
SUMMARY: Pantone isn't the only color system of its kind. But thanks to an innovative founder and savvy marketing, it's become the industry standard.

TITLE: Syrian opposition forces enter the strategic city of Hama
SUMMARY: Syrian rebels have entered another major city, in a further blow to President Bashar Assad after they took over Aleppo days earlier.

TITLE: Cryptic words were found on bullet casings at scene of CEO Brian Thompson's killing
SUMMARY: Shell casings with the cryptic words  "deny," "defend" and "depose" were found at the scene of the fatal shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO outside of a Manhattan hotel, police officials say.

TITLE: Stay away from Dr. Google, and other lessons learned about hypochondria
SUMMARY: Caroline Crampton developed excessive health anxiety after being treated for cancer as a teen. In A Body Made of Glass she chronicles her experience with

TITLE: Amnesty International accuses Israel of genocide in Gaza, which Israel strongly denies
SUMMARY: Amnesty International says Israel has sought to deliberately destroy Palestinians in its war with Hamas, by mounting deadly attacks, demolishing vital infrastructure and preventing aid deliveries.

TITLE: Anthem plans to put time limits on anesthesia coverage, alarming doctors
SUMMARY: Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield says it will put time limits on anesthesia care starting next year. Doctors and elected officials, including in New York and Connecticut, are asking it to change course.

TITLE: Syrian opposition forces enter the key city of Hama, in a new blow to Assad's regime
SUMMARY: Syrian rebels have entered another major city, in a further blow to President Bashar Assad after they took over Aleppo days earlier.

TITLE: Memphis police use excessive force and discriminate against Black people, the DOJ finds
SUMMARY: A Justice Department investigation launched after the beating death of Tyre Nichols in 2023 found that "Memphis police officers regularly violate the rights of the people they are sworn to serve."

TITLE: New images are released for a 'person of interest' in the CEO's killing in New York
SUMMARY: Shell casings with the cryptic words  "deny," "defend" and "depose" were found at the scene of the fatal shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO outside of a Manhattan hotel, police officials say.

TITLE: For a kid with cancer, where they live has a huge impact on whether they'll survive
SUMMARY: In wealthy countries, a child diagnosed with cancer often has an excellent chance of survival. But in lower resource countries, survival rates are dramatically lower. What's going on?

TITLE: Pope Francis goes electric in new eco-friendly popemobile
SUMMARY: Pope Francis, who heads the Catholic Church, has doubled down on his commitment to the environment with a new electric popemobile presented by Mercedes-Benz.

TITLE: A powerful 7.0 earthquake strikes off northern California coast
SUMMARY: A powerful earthquake has struck off the northern California coast. Several aftershocks continue to rattle the area off Eureka.

TITLE: Court rejects Boeing plea deal stemming from 737 Max crashes
SUMMARY: A federal judge in Texas has rejected a plea deal between Boeing and the U.S. Justice Department, saying the court should play a bigger role in selecting an independent monitor to oversee the company.

TITLE: A powerful 7.0 earthquake strikes off Northern California coast
SUMMARY: A powerful earthquake has struck off the Northern California coast, triggering tsunami warnings that were later canceled. Several aftershocks continued to rattle the area off Eureka.

TITLE: France's toppled government adds to the European Union's bigger political problems
SUMMARY: The political instability in France — and simultaneously in Germany, where the governing coalition collapsed a month ago — could have wide-ranging consequences.

TITLE: NASA delays Artemis II human moon mission once again as it wraps up heat shield investigation
SUMMARY: The mission to take four astronauts on a trip around the moon and back, previously targeting a launch at the end of 2025, has been delayed until at least April, 2026.

TITLE: How worried should we be about Disease X?
SUMMARY: An unidentified illness has claimed nearly 80 lives in DRC. Investigators are on the scenes to determine what it is — and how much of a threat it poses locally and globally.

TITLE: Protecting Unique Wilderness at the Bottom of the World
SUMMARY: Chile is poised to create it's 47th national part in the coming year, protecting wilderness at the southern tip of South America. That's thanks in large part to the work of a U.S. conservationist and her organization. We go to the bottom of the world to see the stunning landscape that will make up the park.

TITLE: Some rural Nevadans want Trump to stop the state's solar energy boom
SUMMARY: Backlash against massive solar energy farms drove strong rural turnout in Nevada may have helped flip the presidential vote there to Republican for the first time since 2004. But it's not a given Trump will derail President Biden's plans for more Nevada solar.

TITLE: Trump nominates Rodney Scott to lead Customs and Border Protection
SUMMARY: Rodney Scott at CBP and Caleb Vitello at ICE would work alongside Stephen Miller, who was named deputy chief of staff for policy and Tom Homan, also tapped to be a "border czar."

TITLE: Trump names former Sen. David Perdue of Georgia to be ambassador to China
SUMMARY: With his nomination, Trump is leaning on a former business executive-turned politician to serve as the administration's envoy to America's most potent economic and military adversary.

TITLE: 3 climbers from the U.S. and Canada are believed to have died in New Zealand
SUMMARY: Three mountain climbers — two from the U.S. and one from Canada — missing for five days on Aoraki, New Zealand's tallest peak, are believed to have died in a fall, the authorities said Friday.

TITLE: Slingshot spiders rely on good vibrations to catch supper
SUMMARY: The tiny ray spider uses launches its web to grab its prey out of the air. Though common practice in the superhero world, this ability is actually unusual in spiders.

TITLE: How measles, whooping cough and worse could roar back on RFK Jr.'s watch
SUMMARY: With anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in charge of the nation's biggest health agency, it wouldn't take much tampering to enable vaccine-preventable diseases to make a comeback.

TITLE: Police are still looking for the suspect in the shooting of the UnitedHealthcare CEO
SUMMARY: The manhunt for the person who fatally shot the head of one of the country's largest health insurers in New York City entered its third day Friday as police parsed newly discovered clues.

TITLE: Who or what else did President Biden pardon? Find out in the quiz!
SUMMARY: Also in your grab bag of weekly trivia: martial law, bitcoin, the first lady's holiday décor, a Kennedy who's not RFK Jr., brain rot and the popemobile.

TITLE: After a shocking shooting, Americans vent feelings about health insurance
SUMMARY: The death of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson triggered a deluge of painful stories about health care denials on social media.

TITLE: With the Voting Rights Act facing more threats, advocates renew a push for state laws
SUMMARY: With efforts to bolster the federal Voting Rights Act unlikely under Republican control of the new Congress, advocates are refocusing on state protections against racial discrimination in elections.

TITLE: Want a great photo of yourself? Try these confidence-boosting poses
SUMMARY: Anyone can be photogenic. It just takes practice. A model and a posing coach share postures and movements to help you get more comfortable in front of the camera.

TITLE: Microfeminism: The next big thing in fighting the patriarchy
SUMMARY: People are sharing the different tactics they use help to uplift women in small ways.

TITLE: The manhunt for the New York CEO's shooter enters its third day
SUMMARY: The manhunt for the person who fatally shot the head of one of the country's largest health insurers in New York City entered its third day Friday as police parsed newly discovered clues.

TITLE: Concerns over Trump's crypto promises. And, gift ideas for 5 personality types
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump has promised to make the U.S. the planet's "crypto capital." Here's why critics are concerned. And, gift ideas this holiday season for five personality types.

TITLE: A cancer survivor nearly died trying to prove he had recovered
SUMMARY: In this week's StoryCorps, two friends recall a harrowing ski trip in the Colorado mountains.

TITLE: Court upholds a U.S. ban on TikTok
SUMMARY: A federal appeals court agreed that the viral video app must be sold off by its China-based parent company, rejecting TikTok's claim that the crackdown violates the free speech rights of millions of Americans.

TITLE: After trying to impose martial law, South Korea's president faces an impeachment vote
SUMMARY: After President Yoon Suk Yeol's failed attempt to impose martial law, South Korea's parliament will vote Saturday on his impeachment. Yoon's own party chief has called for his powers to be suspended.

TITLE: Coronavirus FAQ: I didn't get the latest COVID vaccine. Should I? And if so ... when?
SUMMARY: If you haven't rolled up your sleeve for the jab, you're not alone. In fact, you're in the majority. Here's why doctors think the shot is important.

TITLE: A body has been found in the search for a woman missing near a Pennsylvania sinkhole
SUMMARY: A Pennsylvania coroner's office said investigators believe they have located the body of 64-year-old Elizabeth Pollard, who was last seen four days earlier near a sinkhole above a shuttered coal mine.

TITLE: She's 74 — and expecting: Wisdom the albatross astounds once again
SUMMARY: It started in the Eisenhower era: Every year, Wisdom, a Layan albatross, has returned to her nesting grounds on the Midway Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.

TITLE: This little electric car made history. 25 years ago, GM stopped making it
SUMMARY: The EV1 was the first modern, mass-produced electric vehicle from a major automaker — pioneering some technologies you can still find in today's EVs. But the model was controversial, and short-lived.

TITLE: A company that turned homeowners into renters abruptly shuts down
SUMMARY: EasyKnock, which pioneered 'sale-leaseback' deals for struggling homeowners, abruptly closes its doors

TITLE: Young people are dying of heat and their risks could grow, study finds
SUMMARY: Scientists have pointed out that extreme heat is particularly dangerous for older people. A new study shows that young, healthy people are also dying too often in extreme weather.

TITLE: The body of a woman missing near a Pennsylvania sinkhole has been found
SUMMARY: The remains 64-year-old Elizabeth Pollard, who fell into a sinkhole, were recovered Friday, four days after she went missing while searching for her cat, a state police spokesperson said.

TITLE: USDA orders testing across nation's milk supply amid rising bird flu cases
SUMMARY: The virus has spread to over 710 dairy herbs across 15 states, with California reporting the highest number of infections. At least 58 people have been infected with bird flu, including one child.

TITLE: The holidays are peak time for volunteers, but how about the rest of the year?
SUMMARY: Thanksgiving Day kicks off a wave of volunteers stirred by the holiday spirit, but those in charge of local charities say they'd rather have that help at other times of the year.

TITLE: Election confidence among Republicans surges after Trump's win, a new poll finds
SUMMARY: Almost 9 in 10 U.S. voters felt the November election was run well, according to new survey data. That's a jump compared with 2020 — an increase driven exclusively by Republican voters.

TITLE: Will Assad Survive in Syria? And Will the Conflict Widen Into a Regional War?
SUMMARY: Rebels in Syria are making rapid advances against the government forces of President Bashar al-Assad. Assad has managed to stay in power throughout the civil war that has engulfed his country for more than a decade. But he again finds himself in a precarious position. We weigh the chances of his political survival.

TITLE: Activists worry that Trump will bulldoze trans rights. Here's how they're preparing
SUMMARY: Trump's campaign promised policies targeting the transgender community once he's in office. LGBTQ groups face fear, anxiety and uncertainty as they prep for an anticipated challenging four years.

TITLE: Internet sleuths are trying to solve the New York CEO killing
SUMMARY: The public is racing to find evidence that might lead to the gunman who killed health insurance CEO Brian Thompson. When does crowdsourcing detective work help police, and when can it cause harm?

TITLE: Trump travels to Paris for Notre Dame Cathedral's reopening and to meet with Macron
SUMMARY: Donald Trump is off on his first international trip as president-elect, ready to join world leaders and dignitaries in Paris for a Saturday celebration of the renovation of Notre Dame Cathedral.

TITLE: How many species could go extinct from climate change? It depends on how hot it gets.
SUMMARY: A new study projects biodiversity threats if global warming speeds up. Under the most extreme scenarios, about one in three species could be facing extinction by the end of the century.

TITLE: A wolf walks into a flower — and appears to pollinate it
SUMMARY: The bees and ... the wolves?  Turns out, the Ethiopian wolf may be a pollinator, too.

TITLE: South Korean President Yoon's impeachment vote fails after ruling party boycotts it
SUMMARY: A South Korean legislative push to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his imposition of martial law fell through on Saturday.

TITLE: Musk and Ramaswamy's DOGE echoes past budget promises that faced big hurdles
SUMMARY: Vows to shrink the deficit, pay down the debt and run government more like a business have long been a stock element of politics. Candidates for office who have business backgrounds made it a mantra.

TITLE: Syrian opposition activists say insurgents have reached the suburbs of Damascus
SUMMARY: Syrian insurgents have reached the suburbs of Damascus as part of a offensive that has seen them take over some of Syria's largest cities, opposition activists and a rebel commander said Saturday.

TITLE: Photographer pays homage to Our Lady of Guadalupe and reclaims her connection with the divine
SUMMARY: Our Lady of Guadalupe is a significant religious figure who signifies hope and protection for countless Latinos in the U.S. and abroad. For photographer Amanda Lopez, she's an emblem of home.

TITLE: Ukrainians face another harsh winter as Russia attacks coal country
SUMMARY: Many Ukrainians continue to leave their coal mining towns, with the front line of the war with Russia nearby.

TITLE: Trump receives a Paris welcome full of presidential pomp from France's Macron
SUMMARY: French President Emmanuel Macron welcomed Donald Trump to Paris on Saturday with a full a dose of presidential pomp as the two men resumed the relationship they established during Trump's first term.

TITLE: Syrian insurgents reach the capital's suburbs as worried residents flee
SUMMARY: The insurgents' march across Syria gained speed on Saturday with news that they had reached the suburbs of the capital and with the government denying rumors that President Assad had fled the country.

TITLE: Photos: Notre Dame Cathedral reopens, with its first service since a devastating fire
SUMMARY: The bells of Notre Dame Cathedral rang on Saturday evening in Paris for the first time since a fire heavily damaged the Paris landmark in 2019.

TITLE: Insurgents reach gates of Syria's capital, threatening to upend decades of Assad rule
SUMMARY: Insurgents' stunning march across Syria accelerated Saturday with news that they had reached the gates of the capital and that government forces had abandoned the central city of Homs.

TITLE: Syrian government appears to have fallen in stunning end to long rule of Assad family
SUMMARY: The Syrian government appeared to have fallen early Sunday in a stunning end to the 50-year rule of the Assad family after a lightning rebel offensive.

TITLE: In Syria, the Assads leave a bitter legacy after a half-century of repressive rule
SUMMARY: President Bashar Assad and his father, Hafez Assad, combined to rule Syria for more than 50 years, always with an iron fist that crushed dissent and relied on the country's feared security forces.

TITLE: Syrian government falls to rebels, in stunning end to 50 year iron rule of the Assads
SUMMARY: The Syrian government collapsed early Sunday, falling to a lightning rebel offensive that seized control of the capital of Damascus and sent crowds into the streets to celebrate.

TITLE: NYPD releases 2 new photos of man sought in killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO
SUMMARY: Late Saturday, police released two additional photos of the suspected shooter that appeared to be from a camera mounted inside a taxi.

TITLE: John Lithgow on having a "good ending" — on and off screen
SUMMARY: Actor John Lithgow grew up in a theater family but always wanted to be a painter. On Wild Card this week, he opens up what changed his mind.

TITLE: PHOTOS: Take a ride with the Elephant Response Team. And be careful!
SUMMARY: Their job is to keep the peace amid a worsening and at times deadly conflict between humans and the world's largest land animal in the town of Livingstone, Zambia.

TITLE: Cancer interrupted their school lives, but also set them on a mission
SUMMARY: Pediatric cancer survival rates are a crowning medical achievement. But the impact of missing school is a less-discussed side effect children then face.

TITLE: Trump focuses on tariffs, not retribution, in first network TV interview
SUMMARY: President-elect Trump lays out plan for his first 100 days during interview with NBC News' "Meet the Press."

TITLE: Syrians ransack Assad's private residence in Damascus after the regime's downfall
SUMMARY: The private residence of deposed Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad was ransacked after rebels took over the capital, forcing him to flee the country.

TITLE: Assad is granted asylum in Russia as rebels seize control of the Syrian capital
SUMMARY: The Syrian government collapsed early Sunday, as rebels seized control of the capital Damascus. Deposed President Bashar al-Assad was granted asylum by Russia, according to state-run Tass news.

TITLE: Photos: See the fall of Damascus after Syrian rebels topple Assad's regime
SUMMARY: Assad's downfall came less than two weeks after an initial incursion west of the country's second largest city, Aleppo, triggered a cascading series of routs and retreats by the demoralized Syrian military.

TITLE: Lawsuit accuses Jay-Z of raping a 13-year-old with Sean 'Diddy' Combs in 2000
SUMMARY: Shawn Carter, known professionally as Jay-Z, was added as a defendant on Sunday in a lawsuit first filed in October. The anonymous accuser said the assault happened at an MTV music awards after-party.

TITLE: Ruby slippers worn in 'The Wizard of Oz' are auctioned for a record $28 million
SUMMARY: Including the Dallas-based auction house's fee, the unknown buyer will ultimately pay $32.5 million for the pair of iconic ruby slippers that were stolen from a museum nearly two decades ago.

TITLE: Kennedy Center pays tribute to the Grateful Dead, Raitt, Sandoval and The Apollo
SUMMARY: A packed house honored the Grateful Dead, director Francis Ford Coppola, jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval and singer-songwriter Bonnie Raitt. The venerable Harlem theater The Apollo also was recognized.

TITLE: South Korea's Justice Ministry imposes travel ban on President Yoon over martial law
SUMMARY: Yoon's martial law decree plunged South Korea into political turmoil and caused worry among its key diplomatic partners.

TITLE: Under Trump, an 'all of the above' energy policy is poised for a comeback
SUMMARY: Trump promised to "drill, baby, drill." What does that actually mean for the U.S. oil and gas industry – and other types of energy, too?

TITLE: Why these doctors started writing medical 'prescriptions' for solar power
SUMMARY: Doctors in Boston got tired of writing letters to power companies asking them to help vulnerable patients. Then they realized the solar panels on the hospital roof might offer a solution.

TITLE: Russia targets Ukraine's energy grid as winter sets in. Here's how one plant copes
SUMMARY: Russian strikes continue to destroy Ukraine's power grid, prompting nationwide power cuts while temperatures drop. Workers at a damaged plant try to restore its operation before the winter freeze.

TITLE: Mississippi communities scarred by ICE raids fear future under Trump
SUMMARY: Morton and nearby towns in central Mississippi saw the biggest workplace ICE raids in the country in 2019, when nearly 700 workers were arrested from chicken processing plants. Five years later, the impact is still felt here, even as activists and immigrants brace for more workplace raids under a second Trump term.

TITLE: A material that's almost entirely air keeps EV fires from spreading
SUMMARY: The Department of Energy is focusing on aerogels to reduce the severity of lithium battery fires.  A lab that creates the substance shares the technology behind it all.

TITLE: Yes, the number of food recalls has been rising. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: Food recalls fell sharply during the COVID-19 pandemic but are on an uptick now. Here's how the government is tracing outbreaks — and some tips on handling food safely to minimize the risk of illness.

TITLE: Artificial Intelligence wants to go nuclear. Will it work?
SUMMARY: The nuclear industry and big tech companies think they can solve each other's problems, but critics are skeptical the marriage can last.

TITLE: Kennedy Center pays tribute to the Grateful Dead, Bonnie Raitt, Sandoval and The Apollo
SUMMARY: A packed house honored the Grateful Dead, director Francis Ford Coppola, jazz trumpeter Arturo Sandoval and singer-songwriter Bonnie Raitt. The venerable Harlem theater The Apollo also was recognized.

TITLE: Rebels seized control of Syrian capital. And, Trump's 1st post-election TV interview
SUMMARY: Rebels have seized control of Syria's capital and President Bashar al-Assad fled to Russia. And, President-elect Donald Trump reveals his plans to govern in first post-election network TV interview.

TITLE: Biden creates a new national monument marking the legacy of Indian boarding schools
SUMMARY: The new monument will be in Carlisle, Pa., on what was the campus of a school where about 7,800 children from more than 140 tribes were sent for assimilation between 1879 to 1918.

TITLE: Supreme Court rejects challenge to Hawaii gun licensing rules -- for now
SUMMARY: At issue was a Hawaii State Supreme Court decision that allowed the state to prosecute a man carrying a loaded pistol without a license.

TITLE: The Eras era ends: A look back at Taylor Swift's record-breaking, 21-month tour
SUMMARY: Swift has made over $2 billion in ticket sales and spent over 25 hours singing the 10-minute version of "All Too Well" since March 2023. Here's a look at the historic tour and what might come next.

TITLE: A gang leader in Haiti is accused of massacring over 100 people
SUMMARY: A gang leader who controls a key port in Haiti's capital is accused of massacring older people and Vodou religious leaders to avenge his son's death.

TITLE: How Syria's revolution could reshape the Middle East
SUMMARY: The swift downfall of Bashar al-Assad is reverberating throughout the Middle East. Countries are urgently reassessing how to deal with a nation seeking to rebuild itself after years of civil war.

TITLE: In Lebanon, villagers on the border watch Syria's revolution with unease
SUMMARY: While Syrian refugees in Lebanon return home, many Lebanese remain on edge. Years of conflict have left the Syria-Lebanon borderlands scarred, and fears grow that instability could spill over again.

TITLE: Bidders are back in court battling over the auction of Alex Jones' Infowars
SUMMARY: A U.S. bankruptcy judge is hearing arguments for and against selling the show to The Onion, the satirical news site named the winning bidder. Host Alex Jones says the auction was rigged.

TITLE: Police have made an arrest in the United Healthcare CEO shooting
SUMMARY: A man has been arrested in Pennsylvania in connection with the shooting death of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson.

TITLE: Supreme Court rejects challenge to Boston's school admissions policy
SUMMARY: The court's action was the second time the justices declined to intervene in an admissions program based on geography since their 2023 ruling invalidating affirmative action in higher education.

TITLE: Soft medium, hard truths - National Endowment for the Arts recognizes a Navajo quilter
SUMMARY: A Navajo woman who has spent 50 years sewing has now been honored with an NEA award for her unique quilts. She is unafraid to criticize the mainstream culture that's marginalized Indigenous artists.

TITLE: Police arrest 'person of interest' Luigi Mangione in United Healthcare CEO shooting
SUMMARY: A man has been arrested in Pennsylvania in connection with the shooting death of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson.

TITLE: Syrian Refugees Displaced for Years Return Home
SUMMARY: The regime of President Bashar al-Assad crumbled in rapid fashion as rebel groups challenged his power. Assad is now in exile in Russia and the rebels have taken control of the capital, Damascus. Now displaced Syrians, some of whom have been out of the country for over a decade, are returning home. Our correspondent in Lebanon spoke to some returning Syrians.

TITLE: Top 'Washington Post' editor kills article on deputy's departure
SUMMARY: Washington Post Acting Executive Editor Matt Murray killed a story about the departure of a veteran and popular editor for a senior position at the New York Times

TITLE: How will Australia's teen social media ban actually work?
SUMMARY: Australia's Parliament has passed one of the strictest social media crackdowns in the world. Under the new law, anyone under 16 years old will be banned from opening a social media account.

TITLE: United Healthcare shooting 'person of interest' Luigi Mangione arraigned in Pennsylvania
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old man faces firearms and forgery charges in Pennsylvania. New York law enforcement are expected to submit their own charges related to the killing of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson.

TITLE: A record-breaking deal for slugger Juan Soto sends the baseball world into a spin
SUMMARY: The Dominican-born superstar Juan Soto will take his talents to Queens after the New York Mets reportedly signed him to a $765 million contract — a move that has the rest of the baseball world abuzz.

TITLE: Renowned poet and Black arts movement icon Nikki Giovanni dies at 81
SUMMARY: The poet and activist was a leading figure of the Black Arts Movement. Giovanni was working on her upcoming book of poetry, set to publish in the fall.

TITLE: What we know about Luigi Mangione, the suspect in United Healthcare CEO's killing
SUMMARY: Mangione was arraigned on firearms and forgery charges in Pennsylvania after his arrest Monday evening, and is expected to face charges in New York as well.

TITLE: New York prosecutors charge suspect with murder in death of United Healthcare CEO
SUMMARY: Manhattan prosecutors Monday night filed murder and other charges against Luigi Mangione, 26, in the killing of UnitedHealthcare's CEO last week, according to online court documents.

TITLE: Lawsuit: A Character.AI chatbot hinted a kid should murder his parents over screen time limits
SUMMARY: The parents of two Texas minors are suing a chatbot developer saying the company's services endangered their kids. One chatbot allegedly encouraged a child to self-harm and to kill their parents; another allegedly exposed them to sexualized content.

TITLE: Taller vehicles are more dangerous to pedestrians, even at low speeds, research finds
SUMMARY: A study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety shows higher speeds are worse for pedestrians regardless of vehicle height — but those risks are amplified for vehicles with taller front ends.

TITLE: What we know about Luigi Mangione, the suspect in UnitedHealthcare CEO's killing
SUMMARY: Manhattan prosecutors filed murder and other charges against Luigi Mangione Monday night. Earlier in the day Mangione was arraigned on firearms and forgery charges in Pennsylvania after his arrest.

TITLE: Florida prosecutor seeks to overturn convictions in cocaine sting operation
SUMMARY: A Florida prosecutor says he will seek to vacate as many as 2,600 convictions of people who bought crack cocaine made by the Broward County Sheriff's Office for sting operations between 1988 and 1990.

TITLE: 6 charged with human smuggling in deadly 2021 Mexico truck crash
SUMMARY: The truck had been packed with at least 160 migrants when it crashed into a support for a pedestrian bridge in the Mexican state of Chiapas.

TITLE: Lawsuit: A chatbot hinted a kid should kill his parents over screen time limits
SUMMARY: Two families are suing AI chatbot company Character.AI for allegedly encouraging harm after the kids became emotionally attached to the bots. One chatbot allegedly exposed them to sexualized content.

TITLE: 'We're absolutely in panic mode': Toymakers are bracing for Trump's tariffs
SUMMARY: Toy companies are preparing for tariffs in the new Trump administration. Nearly all toys sold in the U.S. are imported — mostly from China.

TITLE: A phone company developed an AI 'granny' to beat scammers at their own game
SUMMARY: The company behind the scam-baiting granny said the AI technology can keep scammers on the phone for 40 minutes at a time, keeping them away from real people.

TITLE: A suspect is charged with murder in the health care CEO shooting: Here is the latest
SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested and charged with murder on Monday. He was found at a McDonald's in Pennsylvania, but is expected to be extradited to New York.

TITLE: The fall of Syria's Assad has renewed hope for the release of U.S. journalist Austin Tice
SUMMARY: Austin Tice went missing during a reporting trip in Syria in 2012. His release is a top priority for the U.S. government following a rebel group's ouster of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

TITLE: A suspect is charged with murder in the UnitedHealthcare CEO shooting: Here is the latest
SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested and charged with murder on Monday. He was found at a McDonald's in Pennsylvania, but is expected to be extradited to New York.

TITLE: What we know about murder suspect Luigi Mangione. And, why food recalls are rising
SUMMARY: Police arrested Luigi Mangione yesterday and charged him with the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson last week. Here's the latest details. And, why food recalls are rising.

TITLE: Taiwan's Defense Ministry says a large Chinese military force has been detected nearby
SUMMARY: China's secretive military appears to be up to something around Taiwan, but it's unclear whether it's a formal military drill.

TITLE: 'If I can stay funny, I can stay alive,' Jamie Foxx says in Netflix special
SUMMARY: In his new Netflix comedy special, "What Had Happened Was," Jamie Foxx reveals he had a brain bleed and a stroke.

TITLE: Luigi Mangione, 26, is charged in UnitedHealthcare CEO's killing
SUMMARY: With the arrest of Luigi Mangione, police have apprehended and charged a suspect in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, though many questions remain unanswered.

TITLE: A suspect holding a handwritten manifesto is charged in the UnitedHealthcare CEO shooting
SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione, 26, was arrested and charged with murder on Monday. He was found at a McDonald's in Pennsylvania, but is expected to be extradited to New York.

TITLE: South Korea arrests its ex-defense minister over martial law efforts
SUMMARY: Former Defense Minister Kim Yong Hyun was formally arrested over his alleged collusion with in imposing martial law last week, as authorities investigate whether their acts amount to rebellion.

TITLE: Arctic tundra now emits planet-warming pollution, federal report finds
SUMMARY: Arctic tundra is releasing greenhouse gases into the atmosphere as hotter temperatures melt frozen ground and wildfires increase.

TITLE: 5 things to watch as Syria confronts a new future
SUMMARY: The sudden collapse of President Bashar al-Assad has come as welcome news to many, but there are jitters both inside and outside the country about what will follow.

TITLE: Police say UnitedHealthcare's CEO was likely killed with a ghost gun. What are they?
SUMMARY: Police say the suspect had a ghost gun, possibly made with a 3D printer, when he was arrested on Monday. Here's what to know about the increasingly widespread weapons and efforts to regulate them.

TITLE: Why Gen Z loves the digital compact cameras that millennials used to covet
SUMMARY: Digital compact cameras are showing up on wish lists this holiday season. Here's what to look for when buying one

TITLE: Trump-era Justice Department subpoenaed congressional staffers, watchdog finds
SUMMARY: But the department's internal watchdog found no evidence of political motivation by federal prosecutors.

TITLE: An Afghan museum, that buried its artifacts after Taliban takeover, is reborn online
SUMMARY: The Afghanistan Memory Home Museum shares details and belongings from those who've died in conflict. It shut its doors when the Taliban took power, buried much of its collection — but has now reemerged.

TITLE: Kroger and Albertsons grocery megamerger halted by federal court
SUMMARY: The ruling makes it increasingly likely that Kroger might abandon its $24.6 billion plan to buy Albertsons. The merger would have combined two of America's largest supermarket chains.

TITLE: The Mood Inside Syria
SUMMARY:
For the first time in a generation, Syrians are no longer living under the regime of a brutal dictator. Our reporter travelled from Lebanon to Syria's capital, Damascus, talking to Syrians along the way and tells us how people are adjusting to their new reality.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org

TITLE: Monarch butterflies will get federal protections as a threatened species
SUMMARY: U.S. officials decided to extend protections to monarch butterflies after warnings from environmentalists that populations are shrinking and the beloved pollinator may not survive climate change.

TITLE: Kroger and Albertsons grocery megamerger halted by two courts
SUMMARY: Two rulings — in federal and state courts — make it increasingly likely that Kroger might abandon its $24.6 billion plan to buy Albertsons. The merger aimed to combine two of America's largest supermarket chains.

TITLE: Bankruptcy judge rejects The Onion's bid for Infowars
SUMMARY: The bidder that lost last month's auction of conspiracy theorist Alex Jones' assets had complained that the process was rigged and "fatally flawed."

TITLE: Ex-defense chief in South Korea tried to kill himself after arrest
SUMMARY: Former Defense Minister Kim Yong Hyun was formally arrested over his alleged collusion with in imposing martial law last week, as authorities investigate whether their acts amount to rebellion.

TITLE: GM to retreat from robotaxis and stop funding its Cruise autonomous vehicle unit
SUMMARY: The automaker will focus on development of partially automated driver-assist systems for personal vehicles like its Super Cruise, which allows drivers to take their hands off the steering wheel.

TITLE: Dreaming of a Black Utopia in Trump's America
SUMMARY:
In his new book, The Black Utopians, author Aaron Robinson tells the story of how Black folks have created many different versions of utopian communities throughout history — and why those communities tend to be especially meaningful during times of political tension and racial unrest.

We want to hear from our listeners about what you like about Code Switch and how we could do better. Please tell us what you think by taking our short survey, and thank you!

TITLE: Through 'The Loss Mother's Stone,' mothers share their grief from losing a child to stillbirth
SUMMARY: Through her work, photographer Nancy Borowick says she hopes to draw awareness to women's stories, educate Americans and destigmatize the conversation that occurs between doctors and patients.

TITLE: Trump's withdrawn nominees latest in a long line of Cabinet members who never were
SUMMARY: Many presidents face failed Cabinet picks so when former Rep. Matt Gaetz withdrew from consideration for President-elect Donald Trump's Cabinet, it wasn't unprecedented, though Trump's style has been.

TITLE: One family thought they had left Syria forever. After Assad's fall, they plan to return
SUMMARY: Rehab Alkadi and her husband, Feras, fled Syria's war with their young son in 2013. They and other Syrian refugees in the U.S. are now hopeful for their country's future, even as uncertainty remains.

TITLE: Clues to Luigi Mangione's ideology. And, courts halt Kroger and Albertsons megamerger
SUMMARY: Murder suspect Luigi Mangione's digital footprint could provide clues to his ideology and possible motive. And, what's next for Kroger and Albertsons after courts halt megamerger.

TITLE: With Assad regime out, Syrians grapple with what comes next
SUMMARY: Under Syria's president, a vast jail complex in the capital Damascus was known as a place where Syrians were disappeared without trial. Now it's crowded with with families searching for loved ones.

TITLE: Kimberly Guilfoyle is the latest Trump family ally chosen for an ambassadorship
SUMMARY: Kimberly Guilfoyle, who got engaged to Trump's son in 2020, is the latest appointee he's chosen from his family tree. There's a long and controversial history of presidents picking relatives for jobs.

TITLE: Albertsons sues Kroger and ends failed grocery megamerger
SUMMARY: The lawsuit over a deal to combine the two largest U.S. supermarkets came just a day after it was blocked in both federal and Washington state courts.

TITLE: In South Korea, insurrection charges are closing in on the president
SUMMARY: Police, prosecutors and investigators have deemed President Yoon Suk Yeol as a suspect in a rare investigation into a sitting president for possible insurrection charges.

TITLE: Saudi Arabia will host the 2034 FIFA World Cup — a controversial pick
SUMMARY: FIFA's selection of Saudi Arabia to host the World Cup was celebrated in the kingdom but criticized by human rights groups, who fear residents, visitors and migrant workers will be at risk of abuse.

TITLE: Wisconsin kayaker who faked his death is back in the U.S. and in custody, police say
SUMMARY: Ryan Borgwardt disappeared in August while kayaking in Wisconsin, but an investigation revealed he intended to fake his death and had fled to Europe. Police said he willingly returned to the U.S.

TITLE: FBI Director Wray to resign at end of Biden administration
SUMMARY: Wray told employees at an FBI town hall that he is resigning next month to "avoid dragging the Bureau deeper into the fray." President-elect Donald Trump has already made a new pick for FBI director.

TITLE: The U.S. is facing a severe housing shortage. Will Trump's proposals help?
SUMMARY: The U.S. is short approximately four million homes. Wharton economist Ben Keys traces the beginning of the housing crisis to the 2008 financial meltdown — and says climate change is making things worse.

TITLE: Mystery drones flying over New Jersey have residents and officials puzzled
SUMMARY: The drones have been seen above critical infrastructure like reservoirs, rail stations and military bases. The governor says there is "no known threat," but the FBI is still investigating.

TITLE: Police say gun found with suspect matches casings at UnitedHealthcare CEO crime scene
SUMMARY: The New York police commissioner also said investigators matched Luigi Mangione's fingerprints with those found on items near the scene where the UnitedHealthcare CEO was fatally shot last week.

TITLE: A Wisconsin kayaker accused of faking his death appears in court
SUMMARY: Ryan Borgwardt disappeared in August while kayaking in Wisconsin, but an investigation revealed he intended to fake his death and had fled to Europe. Police said he willingly returned to the U.S.

TITLE: Judge declares mistrial over killing of gay University of Mississippi student
SUMMARY: Jimmy "Jay" Lee's body has never been found, but a judge declared him dead. Jurors said they were unable to reach a verdict after over nine and a half hours of deliberation.

TITLE: Rights group accuses Russian mercenaries of abuses against civilians in Mali
SUMMARY: Malian armed forces, the Russia-backed Wagner Group and jihadi groups deliberately killed civilians and burned homes in Mali according to Human Rights Watch.

TITLE: North Carolina GOP lawmakers enact a law eroding the Democratic governor's powers
SUMMARY: North Carolina lawmakers have enacted a law over the governor's veto that would diminish the powers afforded to his successor and other other Democratic statewide winners in the Nov. 5 elections.

TITLE: An explosion in the Afghan capital kills the Taliban refugee minister
SUMMARY: The explosion struck inside the ministry, killing Khalil Haqqani, officials said. His last official photo showed him at a meeting chaired by the deputy prime minister earlier Wednesday.

TITLE: Dear Life Kit: My daughter was left out of the holiday newsletter — again!
SUMMARY: A father wonders why his father-in-law keeps neglecting to mention his daughter in his annual newsletter to family. It includes updates on the other grandchildren. Why not her?

TITLE: South Korea's Yoon defends martial law decree as an act of governance
SUMMARY: In an address to the nation, President Yoon Suk Yeol claimed the opposition-controlled parliament has been destroying the country's liberal democratic order.

TITLE: The Geminids meteor shower peaks at the end of the week. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: The Geminids are one of the best and most visible annual meteor showers, when at least 120 meteors can usually be seen per hour. But 2024 will be different, thanks to the year's final full moon.

TITLE: UHC murder suspect railed about U.S. health care. Here's what he missed
SUMMARY: The man charged in the killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson was critical of U.S. health care. Experts say the system's problems are complex and can't be pinned on one player or industry.

TITLE: These neurons in the abdomen help form the gut-brain connection
SUMMARY: Scientists have identified two types of brain cells in the abdomen that appear to control different aspects of digestion.

TITLE: The Game Awards 2024: Key nominees and what to expect
SUMMARY: Morning Edition host A Martinez and NPR gaming editor James Mastromarino discuss the nominees of this year's Game Awards and their significance in gaming culture.

TITLE: Some Syrian refugees in Berlin ponder returning post-Assad, others call Germany home
SUMMARY: Germany hosts almost a million Syrians who fled war and dictatorship.

TITLE: Biden commutes the sentences for 1,500 people, the largest act of clemency in a day
SUMMARY: The 1,500 people had been serving long prison sentences that would have been shorter under today's laws and practices. They had been on home confinement since the COVID pandemic.

TITLE: FBI Director to resign. And, UHC CEO killing brings attention to U.S. life expectancy
SUMMARY: Why FBI Director Christopher Wray will step down from the role at the end of Biden's term. And, the UHC CEO killing turns public attention to the U.S. life expectancy and health care.

TITLE: The Geminids meteor shower peaks this week. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: The Geminids are one of the best and most visible annual meteor showers, when at least 120 meteors can usually be seen per hour. But 2024 will be different, thanks to the year's final full moon.

TITLE: As Time's 'Person of the Year,' Trump outlines his top priorities in lengthy interview
SUMMARY: In a wide-ranging and long interview, President-elect Donald Trump tells TIME Magazine his priorities for the first days of his second time at the presidency.

TITLE: Missing American Travis Timmerman found wandering barefoot outside Damascus
SUMMARY: The 29-year-old had last been seen in Budapest, Hungary. He said he was detained earlier this year after crossing into Syria on foot from Lebanon and held in prison until the fall of the Assad regime.

TITLE: She fled during Assad's regime. Now this Syrian activist is considering going home
SUMMARY: Germany hosts almost a million Syrians who fled war and dictatorship. The toppling of the Assad regime has raised questions for exiles about their next step.

TITLE: FAA chief Mike Whitaker announces that he will step down in January
SUMMARY: Mike Whitaker says he will step down as head of the Federal Aviation Administration on Jan. 20. It's not unusual for FAA administrators to resign at the change of administration, though some have stayed longer.

TITLE: Biden commutes sentences for 1,500 people, the largest act of clemency in a day
SUMMARY: Biden said he plans to take more steps using his clemency powers in the remaining weeks of his presidency.

TITLE: Trump says Kari Lake will lead Voice of America. He attacked it during his first term
SUMMARY: If successful, Trump's move would install a loyalist at the helm of the network. A U.S. judge found Trump appointees illegally violated Voice of America's journalistic independence in his first term.

TITLE: FBI missed 'basic step' in its intelligence efforts ahead of Jan. 6 Capitol riot
SUMMARY: The long-awaited report from DOJ Inspector General office comes nearly four years after a crowd of Donald Trump's supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021 to try to prevent Congress from certifying Joe Biden's election win.

TITLE: This drug is the 'breakthrough of the year' -- and it could mean the end of the HIV epidemic
SUMMARY: That's the title that <em>Science

TITLE: At 18, India's Gukesh Dommaraju becomes the youngest World Chess Champion ever
SUMMARY: Dommaraju unseated China's Ding Liren to become the new world chess champion. "Every chess player wants to experience this moment, and very few get the chance," Dommaraju said after the match.

TITLE: Ukraine Struggles to Keep the Power On Under Russian Bombardment
SUMMARY: Russia continues to pound Ukraine with missile strikes, often targeting infrastructure like power plants. That has caused Ukrainians to endure power cuts even during the harsh winter. Our correspondent visits a power plant to see what it takes to keep the lights on in war.

TITLE: Trump invites China's Xi to next month's inauguration
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump is breaking with precedent in inviting a foreign head of state to his inauguration.

TITLE: What was the worst year of your life and what did you learn from it? We want to hear
SUMMARY: <em>All Things Considered

TITLE: At 18, India's Gukesh Dommaraju becomes the youngest world chess champion ever
SUMMARY: Dommaraju unseated China's Ding Liren to become the new world chess champion. "Every chess player wants to experience this moment, and very few get the chance," Dommaraju said after the match.

TITLE: Wray is out. Patel may be in. What's it mean for the FBI?
SUMMARY:
FBI Director Christopher Wray announced yesterday that he will resign before President-elect Trump takes office. This comes after Trump announced he would appoint loyalist Kash Patel to lead the Bureau.

President-elect Trump's pick to lead the FBI, Kash Patel, held several national security positions in the first Trump administration. Since then, he's found money and attention as a pro-Trump influencer promoting conspiracy theories.

What can that tell us about his plans for the FBI?

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: The 2024 Game Awards recap: All winners and most surprising reveals
SUMMARY: Astro Bot, Balatro, and Metaphor Re: Fantazio claimed the most trophies at The Game Awards in a night dominated by sweeps, surprising reveals and fourth-wall breaks.

TITLE: Stanley recalls about 2.6 million travel mugs
SUMMARY: The company behind the uber-viral water bottles is recommending customers affected by the recall reach out for a replacement part.

TITLE: How D.C. tackled a child care crunch through a tax hike on the rich
SUMMARY: In Washington, D.C., a tax on residents earning more than $250,000 a year is boosting the wages of child care workers. Two years in, it's proving to be a great investment.

TITLE: Here are the deadlines for mailing your holiday gifts to ensure they arrive on time
SUMMARY: Mail carriers and shipping companies will be closed on Christmas Day.

TITLE: How much do you remember about 2024? What does 2025 hold? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: Who or what died? Who or what broke up? Why so many bears? And what color IS "brat green," anyway? Test yourself in this year's final news quiz.

TITLE: Americans are furious over health care. Is this an Occupy Wall Street moment?
SUMMARY: The public outrage unleashed by the killing of UnitedHealthcare's CEO echoes the anti-banking fury after the financial crisis and comes as populist economic fatigue helped re-elect Donald Trump.

TITLE: For kids with rare genetic disorders, customized CRISPR treatments offer hope
SUMMARY: The gene-editing technique is effective for treating some illnesses but it's been too expensive to consider it for rare conditions. A new approach in the works could make it more widely available.

TITLE: Russia targets Ukrainian infrastructure with widespread aerial strikes
SUMMARY: Russia launched a massive aerial attack against Ukraine on Friday as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy described it as one of the heaviest bombardments of the country's energy sector since Russia's full-scale invasion.

TITLE: People in colder countries understand the magic of winter. What's their secret?
SUMMARY: Researcher Kari Leibowitz traveled to places with some of the harshest winters on Earth to understand how people thrive in the cold and dark. Her findings may inspire you to find comfort and joy in the season.

TITLE: Foreign students advised to make plans before Trump. And, 2024's final news quiz
SUMMARY: Why universities are advising international students to return before Inauguration Day. And, the last NPR news quiz of the year.

TITLE: Father and son reflect on Black love and loss
SUMMARY: In this week's StoryCorps, a father and son talk about sources of love in their lives.

TITLE: What Syria means for Hezbollah's efforts to rebuild Lebanon
SUMMARY: With a ceasefire in place, Hezbollah wants to rebuild Lebanon. But its supply chains across Syria have been weakened by Israeli airstrikes, rebel fighting and the ouster of its ally Bashar al-Assad.

TITLE: Will Luigi Mangione's tipster get the $60K reward? It's complicated
SUMMARY: The FBI and NYPD offered up to $60,000 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the UnitedHealthcare shooting suspect. But cashing in on the reward is a complicated process.

TITLE: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi injured during trip abroad
SUMMARY: A spokesperson said Pelosi was "admitted to the hospital for evaluation."

TITLE: How to prevent drowning: a ground-breaking report that's startling yet hopeful
SUMMARY: The World Health Organization gathered data from 139 countries for its first-ever report on how to prevent drowning.

TITLE: Jubilant Syrians gather for Friday prayers for the 1st time since Assad's ouster
SUMMARY: In Damascus, people stood shoulder to shoulder at one of Syria's holiest sites, the Umayyad Mosque, in the first Friday prayers since Bashar al-Assad was overthrown less than a week ago.

TITLE: Tech moguls Altman, Bezos and Zuckerberg donate to Trump's inauguration fund
SUMMARY: The donations are seen as the latest example of tech moguls' changing stance toward the incoming president. During his first administration, Trump clashed with Bezos and Zuckerberg.

TITLE: McKinsey & Company to pay $650 million for role in opioid crisis
SUMMARY: The powerful consulting firm McKinsey will "accept responsibility" and pay $650 million for helping to fuel the opioid crisis, but executives will once again dodge prosecution.

TITLE: Supreme Court to hear challenge to California's authority to set vehicle emissions standards
SUMMARY: Ohio and 16 other Republican-dominated states have sued, asserting that a waiver granted to California to set its own rules violates the basic design of the U.S. Constitution, which they assert should treat states as equals.

TITLE: Paula Abdul settles suit alleging sexual assault by 'Idol' producer Nigel Lythgoe
SUMMARY: Paula Abdul and former <em>American Idol

TITLE: People in Syria Lost and Found
SUMMARY: The U.N. estimates over a 100,00 people have gone missing in Syria under the regime of Bashar al-Assad. And many families never knew the fate of their loved ones. Now that the regime has fallen, the search is on for the missing. We join some Syrians on that search.

TITLE: Texas challenges shield laws by suing New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills
SUMMARY: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed the lawsuit against a New York doctor who prescribed abortion pills for a client near Dallas, pitting an abortion ban against laws that protect physicians.

TITLE: Can Syria avoid another slide into autocracy?
SUMMARY:
The brutal regime of Bashar al Assad fell over the weekend with dizzying speed. Syrians within the country and around the world burst into celebration.

Now, the rebel group Hay'at Tahrir al Sham, or HTS has to govern. They are designated a terrorist organization by the US.

And some worry that HTS could slide into its own kind of autocratic regime.

That fear is not unfounded. Across the Middle East and North Africa, many revolutions have overthrown autocrats, only for those countries to descend back into chaos or a more oppressive rule.

The Syrian revolution began amid a wave of uprisings in the region that led to new, undemocratic regimes. Can Syria avoid a similar fate today?

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Supreme Court to consider whether Catholic group is exempt from religious taxes
SUMMARY: At issue is whether the charity Catholic Charities is qualified to be exempt from state unemployment taxes as a religious institution.

TITLE: American citizen Travis Timmerman is now with U.S. forces after being found in Syria
SUMMARY: Travis Timmerman, a U.S. citizen found wandering barefoot in Damascus after being freed from a Syrian prison following the fall of the Assad regime, was handed over to U.S. forces in Syria on Friday.

TITLE: South Korea's parliament votes to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his martial law order
SUMMARY: South Korea's parliament voted Saturday to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol as authorities investigate allegations of rebellion over his controversial Dec. 3 martial law decree.

TITLE: 80 years later, Glenn Miller's sudden disappearance remains unsolved
SUMMARY: Glenn Miller was the swing era's biggest star. Then, he vanished without a trace.

TITLE: Will The FDA finally ban Red No. 3? A decision could come soon
SUMMARY: The food colorant has been linked to behavioral problems in children, including inattention and hyperactivity. California passed a law to ban it last year.

TITLE: South Korea's parliament votes to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol
SUMMARY: South Korea's parliament impeached Presisdent Yoon Suk Yeol for his attempt to impose martial, the first time such a measure had been imposed on the nation in more than four decades.

TITLE: Opinion: Airbnb will recreate gladiator drama in the Colosseum
SUMMARY: NPR's Scott Simon details the "gladiator experience" that 16 lucky — or unlucky — people might have next year inside the Roman Colosseum. Will they not be entertained?

TITLE: 'Wait Wait' for December 14, 2024: Live at Carnegie Hall with Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson
SUMMARY: This week, <em>Wait Wait

TITLE: Will the FDA finally ban Red No. 3? A decision could come soon
SUMMARY: The food colorant has been linked to behavioral problems in children, including inattention and hyperactivity. California passed a law to ban it last year.

TITLE: Pearl Harbor survivor dies at 100
SUMMARY: Bob Fernandez was a 17-year-old sailor on board the USS Curtiss during the Dec. 7, 1941, attack that propelled the U.S. into World War II.

TITLE: Luigi Mangione retains high-profile former prosecutor as defense lawyer
SUMMARY: Karen Friedman Agnifilo was second-in-command at the Manhattan District Attorney's Office. There, she prosecuted violent crime cases, including those that had "a mental health component."

TITLE: Woman who accuses Jay-Z of raping her at 13 shares new details about alleged assault
SUMMARY: The woman said that during the alleged assault, she tried to resist but Jay-Z told her to stop. She also acknowledged some inconsistencies in her account but firmly maintained that she was attacked.

TITLE: ABC agrees to give $15 million to Trump's presidential library to settle lawsuit
SUMMARY: ABC News agreed to pay $15 million to Trump's presidential library to settle a lawsuit over George Stephanopoulos' inaccurate on-air assertion that Trump was found liable for raping E. Jean Carroll.

TITLE: One week into post-Assad rule in Syria - a view from Damascus
Assad's fall came too late for one NPR reporter's father
SUMMARY: Assad's fall came too late for the father of NPR's Diaa Hadid, who was briefly detained by Syrian forces during their occupation of northern Lebanon.

TITLE: Trump's tariffs threat is dividing business owners across the country
SUMMARY: Businesses are divided over Trump's plan to impose sweeping tariffs. Some companies welcome the protection from foreign competition, while others worry about rising costs and retaliation.

TITLE: Ilana Glazer appreciates how becoming a parent forced them to draw some lines
SUMMARY: Ilana Glazer is grateful for the limits of parenthood. On<em> Wild Card

TITLE: Trump appoints foreign policy adviser Richard Grenell as special missions envoy
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump announced Saturday that he's picked longtime foreign policy adviser Richard Grenell to serve as an envoy for special missions, dealing with tough foreign policy decisions.

TITLE: Storms across US bring heavy snow, dangerous ice and a tornado in California
SUMMARY: Inclement weather plagued areas of the U.S. in the first half of the weekend, with dangerous conditions including a major ice storm in Midwest states and unsual tornado activity in Central California.

TITLE: This cookbook is unlike any other from India. Pass the honeycomb, please!
SUMMARY: In<em> Dalit Kitchens of Marathwada,

TITLE: At least 11 dead in the French territory of Mayotte as Cyclone Chido causes devastating damage
SUMMARY: At least 11 people have died after Cyclone Chido caused devastating damage in the French territory of Mayotte in the Indian Ocean, France's Interior Ministry said Sunday.

TITLE: U.S. has made contact with Syrian rebel group HTS, Blinken says
SUMMARY: Comments by Secretary of State Antony Blinken this weekend were the first time a U.S. official has acknowledged contact with the Syrian rebel group that drove Bashar al-Assad from power.

TITLE: Zakir Hussain, legendary tabla virtuoso who defied genres, dies at 73
SUMMARY: Hussain's career spanned over five decades, during which he was revered as both a national treasure in India and admired worldwide.

TITLE: Storms across U.S. bring heavy snow, dangerous ice and a tornado in California
SUMMARY: Inclement weather plagued areas of the U.S. over the weekend, with heavy snow in upstate New York, a major ice storm in the Midwest and severe weather warnings around Lake Tahoe.

TITLE: As drone sightings spread across East Coast, federal officials still don't know much
SUMMARY: Clusters of drones have been reported flying over at least six states. The Biden administration is pushing Congress to pass legislation that would expand counter-drone authorities.

TITLE: Israel will close its Ireland embassy over Gaza tensions
SUMMARY: Israel said Sunday it will close its embassy in Ireland as relations deteriorated over the war in Gaza, where Palestinian medical officials said new Israeli airstrikes killed over 46 people including several children.

TITLE: 2 men were arrested in Boston for allegedly flying a drone near the airport
SUMMARY: Two men were arrested in Boston on Saturday for allegedly operating a drone "dangerously close" to Logan International Airport, police said.

TITLE: Trump claims a 'massive' mandate, but presidents often overread their victories
SUMMARY: There's a long history of presidents claiming that their win means the will of the people is behind their agendas. But elections are rarely full-throated endorsements of a candidate's every policy.

TITLE: How are states spending their opioid settlement cash? Look yours up in this database
SUMMARY: From addiction treatment to toy robot ambulances, here's how state and local governments used billions in opioid settlement funds in 2022 and 2023. Explore this database to find our how officials are using the payouts where you live.

TITLE: The federal EV tax credit has an uncertain fate. What car shoppers should know
SUMMARY: Currently, drivers can get a tax credit worth up to $7,500 for buying or leasing an EV. But the incoming administration promised to roll back those credits, which they consider wasteful spending.

TITLE: France rushes help to Mayotte, where hundreds are feared dead from Cyclone Chido
SUMMARY: France was rushing help by ship and military aircraft to its poor overseas territory of Mayotte in the Indian Ocean on Monday after the island was shattered by its worst storm in nearly a century.

TITLE: As a kid, I hated playing sports. As an adult, I fell in love with them
SUMMARY: Want to start a new fitness activity? These older athletes have ideas.

TITLE: The Biden overtime rule was struck down. Now, some workers are losing pay raises
SUMMARY: The overtime rule would have made more than 4 million workers newly eligible to earn overtime on Jan. 1. Then a federal judge in Texas said the Biden administration had gone too far.

TITLE: A desert festival where robots are the headliner
SUMMARY: Scientists are using the Mojave Desert to test robots for the next space age.

TITLE: A 50 thousand year-old love story between humans and Neanderthals
SUMMARY: Tens of thousands of years ago, modern humans mated with Neanderthals. But exactly how and when that happened, and who those groups of humans were, was less known. New research adds some clues.

TITLE: ABC News' $15M settlement with Trump. And, renewed hope for an Israel-Hamas ceasefire
SUMMARY: ABC News agreed to a $15M settlement in a defamation lawsuit with President-elect Donald Trump. Here's a look at why. And, multiple factors have led to renewed hope for an Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal.

TITLE: NPR wants to know: What is a key lesson you learned this year?
SUMMARY: The year is coming to a close, which can bring a lot of reflection. What went great and what might have gone sideways? Every year we learn lessons on what to improve, what are some of yours?

TITLE: Life Kit's most-read stories of 2024: Sleep myths, tipping etiquette, home design tricks
SUMMARY: Comics, social etiquette and myth-busting stories ruled Life Kit in 2024. That includes guidance on what to do if a partner cheats — and how to tip at fast food joints.

TITLE: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, a longtime theater lover, makes her Broadway debut
SUMMARY: Jackson made a cameo in the romantic comedy musical <em>& Juliet

TITLE: These global stories were very, very, very popular in 2024
SUMMARY: Our blog published hundreds of stories in 2024. These are the 11 that captured the most pageviews. If you look at the headlines, you'll understand why.

TITLE: Some workers are losing pay raises after overtime rule was struck down
SUMMARY: The overtime rule would have made more than 4 million workers newly eligible to earn overtime on Jan. 1. Then a federal judge in Texas said the Biden administration had gone too far.

TITLE: First public comments attributed to Assad claim he never planned to leave Syria
SUMMARY: Former Syrian President Bashar al-Assad is believed to have issued his first remarks since opposition forces took over the capital over a week ago in a Telegram post from Moscow.

TITLE: Germany's Scholz loses a confidence vote, triggering new elections
SUMMARY: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz had hoped for this outcome when he called for the confidence vote, analysts say. His aim: to win fresh elections in February and come back with a stronger mandate.

TITLE: Amazon manipulated injury data to make warehouses appear safer, a Senate probe finds
SUMMARY: A Senate committee investigation, led by Sen. Bernie Sanders, accused Amazon of risking worker safety for speed while manipulating injury data to make its warehouses seem safer than they are.

TITLE: Three people are dead and several more are hospitalized in Wisconsin school shooting
SUMMARY: At least three people, including the alleged shooter, are dead after a shooting at a Wisconsin grade school.

TITLE: Sotheby's to auction off ancient Ten Commandments tablet
SUMMARY: One of the earliest tablets inscribed with the Ten Commandments (dating to A.D. 300-800) is scheduled to go up for auction at Sotheby's on Wednesday.

TITLE: 2 people and the suspected gunman are dead in Wisconsin school shooting
SUMMARY: At least three people, including the alleged shooter, are dead after a shooting at a Wisconsin grade school.

TITLE: Will Sectarian Groups Get Along in a New Syria?
SUMMARY: As the future of Syria begins to emerge, one minority group is particularly fearful about how they'll be treated. The Alawites feel like they were mistreated by now-deposed dictator Bashar al-Assad, but because he was a member of that sect, they are also unfairly tied to him in the minds of other Syrians. We go to an Alawite neighborhood of Damascus to hear their concerns.

TITLE: TikTok asks the Supreme Court for an emergency order to block a US ban unless it's sold
SUMMARY: A similar plea was filed by content creators who rely on the platform for income and some of TikTok's more than 170 million users in the U.S.

TITLE: 2 people and the suspect are dead in Wisconsin school shooting
SUMMARY: At least three people, including the alleged shooter, are dead after a shooting at a Wisconsin grade school.

TITLE: Can Trump turn promises into policy?
SUMMARY:
Donald Trump becomes the 47th President of the United States in just over a month.

Throughout his campaign, Trump laid out a list. Things he plans to accomplish in a second term — some on day one. They include: closing the border...imposing tariffs... and ending the war between Russia and Ukraine.

Trump also campaigned on bringing down food prices...in fact, he told NBC's Kristen Welker, it's the reason he won.

President-elect Trump has a long to-do list for his first days in office. How much of it can he actually get done? A lot says senior Trump advisor Jason Miller.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: New York judge says Trump is not immune from hush money conviction
SUMMARY: A spokesperson for President-elect Trump said the case should never have been brought, called for its immediate dismissal.

TITLE: Police identify Wisconsin school shooting suspect as a 15-year-old female student
SUMMARY: At least three people, including the suspect, are dead after a shooting at a Wisconsin grade school. Police talked to the family of the suspect and searched her home, but have no motive yet.

TITLE: Canada's finance minister resigns, posing biggest test of Trudeau's political career
SUMMARY: The stunning move raised questions about how much longer the prime minister of nearly 10 years — whose popularity has plummeted due to concerns about inflation and immigration — can stay on.

TITLE: An explosion kills the head of Russia's nuclear defense forces in Moscow
SUMMARY: An explosive device planted close to an apartment block in Moscow killed the head of Russia's Nuclear, Biological, and Chemical Defence Forces, Russia's Investigative Committee said.

TITLE: 'Love Is Blind' cast are employees, labor board says. Could a reality TV union be next?
SUMMARY: The case could have big implications for what glues reality show fans to the tube. A pending ruling, whatever the outcome, would set a precedent that other unscripted TV cast members could follow.

TITLE: 'Fake electors' from 2020 are casting 2024 votes for Trump while facing felony charges
SUMMARY: Eight of the Republicans set to cast Michigan and Nevada's 2024 Electoral College votes for President-elect Donald Trump still face felony charges related to efforts to reverse Trump's 2020 loss.

TITLE: A transplanted pig kidney offers a grandmother hope for life without dialysis
SUMMARY: The patient was in kidney failure and her immune system would reject a human organ. Scientists hope genetically modified pig organs prove safe and will alleviate the organ shortage and save lives.

TITLE: FBI warns Americans to keep their text messages secure: What to know
SUMMARY: The U.S. believes hackers affiliated with China's government are infiltrating telecoms and stealing users' data. The FBI has urged people to use end-to-end encryption to keep their info safe.

TITLE: Magnitude 7.3 earthquake causes widespread damage in Pacific island nation of Vanuatu
SUMMARY: The earthquake was centered 10 miles west of Port Vila, the largest city in Vanuatu, a group of 80 islands that is home to about 330,000 people.

TITLE: Here's what we know about the deadly school shooting in Madison, Wisconsin
SUMMARY: The suspect is likely to have died from a gunshot wound, but the cause of death has yet to be confirmed by a medical examiner.

TITLE: Apprenticeships are a trending alternative to college — but there's a hitch
SUMMARY: Apprenticeships are becoming a popular alternative to college as a career path. But demand is outpacing the supply of employers who offer them.

TITLE: At the Florida Senior Games, pickleball is the crown jewel. Here's why
SUMMARY: Pickleball is the fastest-growing sport and it's also popular with older athletes. <em>All Things Considered

TITLE: How the holidays could be affecting your medical care
SUMMARY: A new study suggests that holidays can affect your provider's decision making.

TITLE: Deadly Wisconsin school shooting. And, a pig kidney transplant surgery provides hope
SUMMARY: A Wisconsin school shooting left multiple people dead and several injured. Here's the latest. And, a milestone pig kidney transplant provides doctors with hope for the future of transplant surgeries.

TITLE: Syrian families scour hospitals and morgues for loved ones lost under Assad's rule
SUMMARY: People in Syria are looking for their relatives and friends in prisons, hospitals and morgues. The U.N. estimates over 100,00 people have gone missing in Syria under the Assad regime.

TITLE: The suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings is charged in the death of a 7th woman
SUMMARY: The New York architect facing murder charges in a string of deaths known as the Gilgo Beach killings was charged in the death of Valerie Mack, 24, whose remains were found on Long Island in 2000.

TITLE: Here's what we know about the deadly school shooting in Wisconsin
SUMMARY: The suspect is likely to have died from a gunshot wound, but the cause of death has yet to be confirmed by a medical examiner.

TITLE: Most U.S. shootings are done by men, but the Wisconsin school attack is an exception
SUMMARY: Authorities say a 15-year-old girl carried out the shooting that killed two and wounded several at a Wisconsin school. Female shooters are relatively rare, statistically speaking.

TITLE: Taking vitamin D is unlikely to prevent falls or fractures. Here's what it does
SUMMARY: Vitamin D is good for the immune system, but in older people it doesn't prevent falls or fractures, according to health experts at the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Here's why you need it.

TITLE: Luigi Mangione is charged with murder as an act of terrorism in CEO's death
SUMMARY: The man accused of killing UnitedHealthcare's CEO has been charged with murder as an act of terrorism. The indictment could help move along procedural steps toward extraditing the suspect.

TITLE: Senators launch probe into sale-leaseback company, citing NPR's reporting
SUMMARY: EasyKnock, the subject of the probe, announced its sudden closure earlier this month.

TITLE: The Indian Movie Acclaimed Abroad But Snubbed at Home
SUMMARY: The film "All We Imagine As Light" is an Indian film that has won rare international acclaim from Cannes and the Golden Globes. But at home in India the international buzz was ignored and it was passed over as India's entry for the Oscars. Our correspondent in Mumbai, where the film was shot, explores why it is not receiving the same acclaim in India.

TITLE: The Wisconsin shooting suspect is female. That's rare, data says
SUMMARY: Authorities say a 15-year-old girl carried out the shooting that killed two and wounded several at a Wisconsin school. Female shooters are relatively rare, statistically speaking.

TITLE: The president of the NCAA calls for a ban on 'prop bets' in college sports
SUMMARY: As sports betting has spread across the U.S., college athletes have increasingly faced harassment from bettors. A federal ban on wagers that concern individual performances could help, the NCAA says.

TITLE: Harris nods to the coconut tree meme that started it all
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris had some fleeting meme-mentum in the early days of her campaign. On Tuesday, she nodded to that in remarks to young voters.

TITLE: Lawmakers release spending bill to fund federal government until March 14
SUMMARY: Congressional leaders released a stop-gap spending bill to fund the government until March 14.

TITLE: Carlos Watson gets nearly 10 years in prison in case about failed startup Ozy Media
SUMMARY: Watson, 55, and the now-defunct company were found guilty last summer of charges including wire fraud conspiracy. He has denied the allegations and plans to appeal.

TITLE: In last-ditch effort, Democrats push to get Julie Su confirmed as Labor Secretary
SUMMARY: Acting Secretary Julie Su has led the Labor Department for nearly two years, despite never getting a Senate confirmation vote. With time running out, her staunchest supporters haven't given up.

TITLE: U.S. to pay $116M settlement over rampant sexual abuse at Calif. women's prison
