SUMMARY: The lawsuits were brought by more than 100 women who say they were abused or mistreated at a now-shuttered federal prison in California that was known as the "rape club" because of rampant staff-on-inmate sexual misconduct.

TITLE: Man set to be put to death in Indiana's first execution in 15 years
SUMMARY: Barring intervention by Gov. Eric Holcomb, Corcoran is scheduled to be executed before sunrise Wednesday at the Indiana State Prison in Michigan City.

TITLE: Energy chief Granholm warns against 'unfettered exports' of liquefied natural gas
SUMMARY: Granholm's statement came as the Energy Department released a long-awaited study that found U.S. LNG shipments drive up domestic wholesale prices and frequently displace renewable energy sources.

TITLE: At least 25 killed after an overcrowded boat capsizes in Congo
SUMMARY: It capsized a few hundred meters into the journey along the Fimi River, the latest such tragedy to strike Congo.

TITLE: Nuclear bunker sales increase, despite warnings they won't provide protection
SUMMARY: Critics warn argue that people planning to live through an atomic blast aren't focusing on the real and current dangers posed by nuclear threats.

TITLE: Deadly violence in Nigeria tied to United Methodist Church schism over LGBTQ policies
SUMMARY: A religious schism has turned deadly in Nigeria, with a church member fatally shot and two young children killed as homes were set ablaze, according to United Methodist News Service.

TITLE: What we learned from Elian Gonzalez, 25 years later
SUMMARY:
Twenty-five years ago, a boy named Elian Gonzalez appeared — remarkably alive — in the waters off the coast of Miami. Immediately, his fate became the subject of an international debate: Should he stay in the U.S.? Or should he be returned to Cuba, to live with his father? From our play cousins at Futuro Studios, this is part of their series Chess Piece: The Elián González Story.

We want to hear from you! Please tell us what you think about Code Switch by taking our short survey. Thank you!

TITLE: Trains, tracks, and tradition: Lionel celebrates 125 years of Christmas fun
SUMMARY: Lionel trains turns 125, celebrating more than a century of holiday magic. From historic models to smartphone-controlled locomotives, these iconic toy trains continue to captivate kids and collectors alike.

TITLE: Michael Vick says he will be the new head football coach at Norfolk State University
SUMMARY: Vick, a four-time Pro Bowl player, is returning to his home state of Virginia to coach the team.

TITLE: 'Cancer ghosting' can be more painful than treatment, survivors say
SUMMARY: Loss of social support after a cancer diagnosis is a surprisingly common experience, social workers and cancer patients say. For young cancer survivors, it is a particularly difficult part of the disease.

TITLE: Churches are making room for grief and loss at Christmas
SUMMARY: More and more congregations are trying to be sensitive to those who are grieving during the holidays. The move ranges from special services to the inclusion of hymns and prayers that speak to sadness during regular Sunday worship.

TITLE: The American industry that wants more government intervention
SUMMARY: As President-elect Trump promises to eliminate government agencies and regulations, one American industry — mining — is asking for more intervention. They say national economic and military security are at stake.

TITLE: This weightlifting gym helps older people build more than just strength
SUMMARY: At Fivex3 Training, a gym in Baltimore, several mornings a week are reserved for older people to train.

TITLE: Mangione charged with murder as act of terrorism. And, path to unionizing reality TV
SUMMARY: Luigi Mangione is charged with murder as an act of terrorism in the killing of the UnitedHealthcare CEO. Here's what that means. And, could reality TV stars unionize? Why it could be hard.

TITLE: How much power would RFK Jr. have at HHS? A former health secretary weighs in
SUMMARY: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., is making the case with senators that he should lead Health and Human Services. Kathleen Sebelius, who had the job under Obama, explains the power and limits of the role.

TITLE: These were the top animal stories on NPR in 2024, including a boy's pregnant octopus
SUMMARY: This year, the animal kingdom was filled with triumph, loss and new discoveries. Here is a look at NPR's top animal stories of 2024.

TITLE: You don't look a day over 4.35 billion! Here's the moon's anti-aging secret
SUMMARY: Early interactions with the Earth may have heated up the Moon and caused it to remelt, producing new lunar rocks and erasing old craters.

TITLE: Supreme Court agrees to review TikTok ban-or-sale law
SUMMARY: The high court said Wednesday it will review a challenge submitted by TikTok asking for the overturn of a law that could ban the video-sharing app by Jan 19.

TITLE: Supreme Court takes up South Carolina's effort to defund Planned Parenthood
SUMMARY: The state cut off funding to Planned Parenthood because it provided non-abortion services to Medicaid patients.

TITLE: The bald eagle isn't actually America's national bird — but that's poised to change
SUMMARY: After learning the U.S. doesn't officially recognize the bald eagle as its national bird, a Minnesota man swooped in. This week the House passed his bill, which now heads to Biden's desk.

TITLE: Viewers watched 20.35 billion hours on Twitch in 2024. 'Stream Big' explores why
SUMMARY: According to the Twitch 2024 community recap, viewers watched 20.35 billion hours on the live-streaming service. A forthcoming book explains why.

TITLE: Scientists know our bodies are full of microplastics. What are they doing to us?
SUMMARY: Plastic particles are found in our organs, blood and even semen. But do they stay in us forever? What damage are they doing? Here are 6 questions scientists are trying to answer

TITLE: With a ban looming, TikTok's future is more uncertain than ever
SUMMARY: In April, Congress passed a law forcing TikTok to sell to a non-Chinese company or face a nationwide ban. Law professor Alan Rozenshtein, delves into the legal and cultural stakes of that law.

TITLE: Genital herpes is a 'forgotten' virus. But that doesn't mean it's gone away.
SUMMARY: Over 800 million people have genital herpes — and in many cases the virus can flare up over a person's lifetime, causing painful symptoms. So why doesn't the world pay more attention?

TITLE: The CDC has confirmed the first severe case of bird flu in a human in the U.S.
SUMMARY: A person in Louisiana has been hospitalized after becoming infected with a case of bird flu that's been linked to wild birds and poultry.

TITLE: Turkey looks set to play an outsize role in shaping the new Syria after Assad
SUMMARY: As the world watches Syria grapple with the aftermath of Bashar al-Assad's brutal regime and the formation of a new government, one neighbor has emerged as having great influence over the new Syria.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve lowers interest rates again -- but hints at fewer cuts next year
SUMMARY: The Fed lowered interest rates by a quarter percentage point — but policymakers are projecting fewer rate cuts next year as inflation remains elevated.

TITLE: With a January ban looming, TikTok's future in the U.S. is more uncertain than ever
SUMMARY: A new law gives TikTok a Jan. 19 deadline to sell to a non-Chinese company or face a nationwide ban. Law professor Alan Rozenshtein explains what this means and how President-elect Trump might intervene.

TITLE: Dreaming of a white Christmas? There's hope, depending on where you live
SUMMARY: A few parts of the country may get a white Christmas in 2024, but the majority will not. And in the future, shifts in weather patterns driven by global warming may make them even less likely.

TITLE: Why Syria's Military Imploded So Quickly
SUMMARY:
Former Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad depended on his military to keep him in power for years. Then in just a matter of days, that same feared military disintegrated as rebel groups took control of the country. Our reporter in Damascus talks to former military members to understand why the military collapsed so fast.

Support our non-profit journalism by joining NPR+ at Plus.NPR.org

TITLE: Prisoners allege a culture of violence by guards at federal facility in Virginia
SUMMARY: At a federal prison in rural Virginia, more than 50 prisoners say they've been abused. But when they try to file a complaint--they're stopped, often by the same guards they say are abusing them.

TITLE: Dozens of Prisoners Allege a Culture of Violence by Guards at Federal Facility in Virginia
SUMMARY: At a federal prison in rural Virginia, more than 50 prisoners say they've been abused. But when they try to file a complaint--they're stopped, often by the same guards they say are abusing them.

TITLE: Bird flu update: California declares emergency and U.S. sees 1st severe human case
SUMMARY: A person in Louisiana has been hospitalized after being exposed to sick and dead birds. Meanwhile, California has declared an emergency over its growing outbreak in cattle.

TITLE: Dozens of prisoners allege a culture of violence by guards at federal facility in Virginia
SUMMARY: At a federal prison in rural Virginia, more than 50 prisoners say they've been abused. But when they try to file a complaint — they're stopped, often by the same guards they say are abusing them.

TITLE: France's highest court upholds corruption conviction of ex-President Nicolas Sarkozy
SUMMARY: Sarkozy, 69, faces a year in prison, but is expected to ask to be detained at home with an electronic bracelet — as is the case for any sentence of two years or less.

TITLE: About 3 dozen high-rise buildings in South Florida are sinking, a study finds
SUMMARY: The 35 buildings surveyed along an almost 12-mile stretch from Miami Beach to Sunny Isles Beach have sunk or settled by 0.8 to 3.1 inches, scientists found.

TITLE: About 10,000 Amazon workers authorize plan to strike Thursday
SUMMARY: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters said workers in Atlanta, New York City, California and Illinois plan to join the picket line.

TITLE: Dozens of men are found guilty of raping a woman in France who was drugged to sleep
SUMMARY: A French panel of judges found dozens of men guilty of raping a woman whose ex-husband had drugged her unconscious over the course of a decade.

TITLE: Employers lobby to keep health care prices transparent in hopes of containing costs
SUMMARY: Donald Trump's first administration advanced rules forcing hospitals and insurers to reveal prices for medical services. Employers don't want to risk backtracking during Trump's second administration.

TITLE: How the Assads used a civil war to turn Syria into a narco state
SUMMARY: As Syria's economy collapsed during its civil war, the country became something of a narco state. The regime of ousted President Bashar al-Assad earned billions by trafficking in the drug Captagon.

TITLE: Biden set an ambitious new climate goal. Will it still matter under Trump?
SUMMARY: The Biden administration set a new climate goal for the U.S. The White House argues states, cities and corporations will continue the work, even as Trump plans to exit the Paris climate agreement.

TITLE: After losing VP bid, Walz searches for role in pushing back against Trump
SUMMARY: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz saw his national profile skyrocket when he became Vice President Harris' running mate. Now, he's back home figuring out when he will push back or work with Republicans.

TITLE: Calling all students! NPR's Student Podcast Challenge returns for 2025
SUMMARY: For it's seventh year, our national podcasting competition will invite students from around the country, in grades four through 12, to bring us their best audio stories.

TITLE: 'They don't live where we live': How communities hear each other in a divided country
SUMMARY: NPR spoke with 30 small groups of people around the country about what they'd want other people to understand about their community — and what they want to understand about others

TITLE: Teamsters say thousands of workers at Amazon could strike Thursday
SUMMARY: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters said workers in Atlanta, New York City, California and Illinois plan to join the picket line.

TITLE: Think you can't dance? Get up and try these tips in our comic. We dare you!
SUMMARY: Anyone can dance. As you read this comic, follow each step — and you'll be moving and grooving in no time.

TITLE: Possible government shutdown looms. And, tips to help with seasonal depression
SUMMARY: Possible holiday government shutdown looms as President-elect Donald Trump and advisers like Elon Musk object to bipartisan spending bill. And, simple ways to help with seasonal depression.

TITLE: Dozens of men are found guilty in mass rape case of French woman drugged by her husband
SUMMARY: A French court found dozens of men guilty of raping Gisèle Pelicot, whose then-husband repeatedly drugged her unconscious over the course of a decade. Her ex-husband was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

TITLE: Georgia appeals court blocks Fulton DA Willis from election interference case
SUMMARY: Fulton County DA Fani Willis and her office can't continue prosecuting the Georgia election interference case involving Donald Trump — the last remaining criminal charges against the president-elect.

TITLE: HIV is spiking in new hot spots. Here's what's being done to control it
SUMMARY: As the new cases and related deaths fall in sub-Saharan Africa, the virus is rearing its head elsewhere. What's the cause? And the solution?

TITLE: Like old times: Trump sends Congress scrambling to avoid a shutdown
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump and his newest top-lieutenant, Elon Musk, have sent Washington scrambling to avoid a government shutdown, even before Trump takes office.

TITLE: Five Fingers Crush The Land from NPR's Throughline
SUMMARY: As NPR correspondent Emily Feng reported in our three-part series "The Black Gate," hundreds of thousands of Uyghur people have been detained in China. They've been subjected to torture, forced labor, religious restrictions, and even forced sterilization. In this episode from 2021, our colleagues at the history podcast Throughline explore who the Uyghur people are, their land, their customs, their music and how they've become such a target in China today. To listen to this series sponsor-free and support NPR, sign up for Embedded+ in Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

TITLE: Georgia court blocks Fulton DA Willis from Trump election interference case
SUMMARY: A court ruled that Fulton County DA Fani Willis and her office can't continue prosecuting the Georgia election interference case involving Donald Trump — the last active prosecution against Trump.

TITLE: Federal regulators prohibit drone flights in dozens of locations across New Jersey
SUMMARY: The Federal Aviation Administration is temporarily barring drone flights over critical infrastructure at 22 locations in New Jersey amid mounting concerns about a flurry of reported drone sightings.

TITLE: Who can say it's healthy? The FDA has a new definition for food labels
SUMMARY: At a time when more than half the American diet comes from processed, packaged foods, the FDA has new rules aimed at helping people make healthier choices in the grocery store.

TITLE: The popular 'hospital-at-home' effort is at stake in the federal spending battle
SUMMARY: Started during the pandemic, hundreds of hospitals in 39 states deliver acute inpatient care in people's homes. The popular program had a five-year extension in a stopgap spending agreement that is now in doubt.

TITLE: How Netanyahu survived another tumultuous year
SUMMARY:
At the start of this year Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was facing a crisis. Just a few months before, Hamas had breached Israel's border with Gaza, killing some 1200 people in Israel on October 7th.

As the year ends, Netanyahu is spending some of it in a courtroom to fight corruption charges that have dogged him since 2019. The Israeli Prime Minister has called the charges absurd.

You might think that would be detrimental to his political career, but instead Netanyahu looks stronger than he has since the war began.

This — despite that trial, an international arrest warrant and a grinding war.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Mangione faces federal murder and stalking charges over UnitedHealthcare CEO killing
SUMMARY: A new federal charging document reveals that the suspect in CEO Brian Thompson's shooting death was found in possession of a notebook containing hostile writings about the health insurance industry.

TITLE: How will Australia's under-16 social media ban work? We asked the law's enforcer
SUMMARY: Australia's top online internet regulator explains how the nation plans to roll out the world's first social media ban for kids under 16.

TITLE: Examining The Biden Administration's International Legacy
SUMMARY: The outgoing U.S. national security advisor, Jake Sullivan, has been a top advisor and envoy to President Biden on issues of foreign policy. He talks to NPR about his view of recent events in the Middle East, the U.S. relationship with China and the future of the war between Russia and Ukraine.

TITLE: Trump's promise to end CBP One app worries migrants waiting in Mexico
SUMMARY: Incoming president Donald Trump has vowed to end the CBP One app, which people outside the U.S. use to book appointments to petition for asylum.

TITLE: California man allegedly messaged Madison school shooter about plans ahead of attack
SUMMARY: New information has emerged in the investigation into a school shooting at a small Christian school in Madison, Wisconsin, though authorities are still searching for a motive.

TITLE: Federal murder charge against Mangione could mean death penalty in CEO killing
SUMMARY: The 26-year-old suspect in the killing of CEO Brian Thompson appeared in federal court on Thursday, where he was charged with murder, a crime that carries a possible sentence of the death penalty.

TITLE: Snow, ice and strong winds make for dangerous conditions in upper Midwest
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service issued a winter storm warning for large areas of Minnesota, Wisconsin and the Dakotas, where some interstates were snow-covered and treacherous.

TITLE: History has never ended, but are we at a crossroads again?
SUMMARY: Oxford professor Ben Ansell says we are witnessing a battle between nationalism and liberalism that will write our own time indelibly into the history books of tomorrow.

TITLE: Big Lots says it is having going-out-of-business sales as it seeks a new buyer
SUMMARY: The national discount retailer says that a previously announced deal to sell itself to a private-equity group fell through.

TITLE: Saturday is the winter solstice. Make the most of the shortest day of the year
SUMMARY: Saturday marks the shortest day of the year and the official start of winter in the Northern Hemisphere. NPR has compiled plenty of expert tips for celebrating the solstice and weathering winter.

TITLE: 'Bill of the Month': The series that dissects and slashes medical bills
SUMMARY: Since 2018, readers and listeners sent KFF Health News-NPR's "Bill of the Month" thousands of questionable bills. Our crowdsourced investigation paved the way for landmark legislation and highlighted cost-saving strategies for all patients

TITLE: Louisiana forbids public health workers from promoting COVID, flu and mpox shots
SUMMARY: An NPR investigation found Louisiana health officials told staff to stop promoting vaccines for COVID, flu and mpox, holding flu shot events or otherwise encouraging the public to get those vaccines.

TITLE: Trump is all about tariffs as he leads a party that used to be all about free trade
SUMMARY: Once upon a time, Republicans spoke of free trade in glowing terms. With his constant threats of tariffs and a history of implementing them, President-elect Donald Trump has flipped that on its head.

TITLE: NPR's most-read stories of 2024 include a scam-fighter and zombie second mortgages
SUMMARY: How can you outsmart scammers? What would you do if your friend was attacked by a wild cougar? NPR readers wanted to know the answers to those questions and more in 2024.

TITLE: Big Health Care is ending a terrible year. Is anyone happy with this business?
SUMMARY: Patients are protesting, bipartisan lawmakers are threatening regulation – and investors are selling their shares.

TITLE: Trump's reelection victory pushes some LGTBQ Minneapolis residents to safety training
SUMMARY: For some marginalized communities the second Trump term is fraught with fears over personal safety. In Minneapolis, one organization is helping with de-escalation services and gun training.

TITLE: The world's biggest and oldest iceberg is on the move once again
SUMMARY: About the size of Rhode Island, the iceberg known as A23a got stuck in an ocean vortex this summer, spinning in place for months. Now, it's free, and heading back into open Antarctic waters.

TITLE: GOP stop-gap bill fails, bringing potential shutdown closer. And, NPR's guide to dance
SUMMARY: Congress has until midnight tonight to avoid a government shutdown after House Republicans were unable to pass a stop-gap funding bill yesterday. And, tips to improve your dance moves.

TITLE: Starbucks workers say they will begin a strike in 3 cities on Friday
SUMMARY: Starbucks and Starbucks Workers United said in February they had come to common ground in moving forward for the rest of the year. But the union says Starbucks has not kept its end of the commitment.

TITLE: Watch: A satellite time-lapse shows the world's biggest iceberg is on the move again
SUMMARY: About the size of Rhode Island, the iceberg known as A23a got stuck in an ocean vortex this summer, spinning in place for months. Now, it's free, and heading back into open Antarctic waters.

TITLE: Climate-warming gas leaks must be fixed by utilities in a new proposed rule
SUMMARY: Natural gas utilities likely will face stricter federal regulations for their climate-warming methane emissions. Among the biggest sources of leaks is the meter outside a gas customer's home.

TITLE: An Indiana man is sentenced to 130 years in prison for murdering 2 teenage girls
SUMMARY: Richard Allen, who was convicted in the 2017 killings of two teens who vanished during a winter hike, received the maximum prison sentence in a case that's long cast a shadow over the town of Delphi.

TITLE: Great global photos from 2024: These images delighted us, touched us, dazzled us
SUMMARY: People love looking at photos. (Just ask Instagram.) This year, we published a number of photo-driven posts that resonated deeply with our audience. Here are some of our favorites.

TITLE: Watch: Satellite video shows world's biggest iceberg, A23a, break free
SUMMARY: About the size of Rhode Island, the iceberg known as A23a got stuck in an ocean vortex this summer, spinning in place for months. Now, it's free, and heading back into open Antarctic waters.

TITLE: Once again, the debt ceiling is roiling Washington. Here are 4 things to know
SUMMARY: Lawmakers will have to authorize additional borrowing to pay the government's bills, but there's no reason it has to be done right away — except for politics.

TITLE: CFPB sues three top U.S. banks for failing to protect consumers from Zelle fraud
SUMMARY: The consumer financial watchdog says customers of the top three banks lost more than $870 million over seven years due to a lack of safeguards against fraud on the Zelle network.

TITLE: What a government shutdown could mean for your holiday travel plans
SUMMARY: Millions of Americans are planning to travel in the coming days. Here's what a potential government shutdown could mean for flying, driving and more — and what you can do to prepare.

TITLE: In a lawsuit, CFPB says 3 top U.S. banks failed to protect consumers from Zelle fraud
SUMMARY: The consumer financial watchdog says customers of the top three banks lost more than $870 million over seven years due to a lack of safeguards against fraud on the Zelle network.

TITLE: At least one dead and 50 injured after a car plowed into a German Christmas market
SUMMARY: A car plowed into a busy outdoor Christmas market in the eastern German city of Magdeburg in what authorities suspect was an attack. The driver was arrested.

TITLE: Malaysia plans to restart a private search for the missing Flight MH370
SUMMARY: Over a decade later, none of the bodies of the 239 passengers and crew members abroad have been recovered.

TITLE: House Republicans to move forward with Plan C to fund the government
SUMMARY: But several hurdles remain to avert a government shutdown ahead of a Friday midnight deadline.

TITLE: The Fight for a Crucial City in Ukraine
SUMMARY:
Ukrainian soldiers are struggling to stabilize defensive lines near the city of Pokrovsk, in the country's east, against Russia's much larger advancing army. We go to the front lines of Pokrovsk, to see how the fight is playing out.

Support our non-profit journalism by joining NPR+

TITLE: A year in radio: Some of the favorite stories from 2024
SUMMARY: Some of the All Things Considered staff whose voices you don't always hear on air share their favorite stories that aired on the show in 2024.

TITLE: What happens if Congress doesn't fund the government?
SUMMARY: If lawmakers can't reach a deal to avoid a shutdown, many federal workers would be furloughed, while essential functions like Social Security payments would continue.

TITLE: At least 2 dead and dozens injured after a car plowed into a German Christmas market
SUMMARY: A car plowed into a busy outdoor Christmas market in the eastern German city of Magdeburg in what authorities believe was an attack. The driver was arrested.

TITLE: Advocates want Biden to spare the lives of the 40 prisoners on federal death row
SUMMARY: Anti-death penalty advocates hope President Biden will grant clemency to 40 people on federal death row. He has already commuted the sentences of nearly 1,500 people and pardoned 39 others.

TITLE: House approves spending bill, leaving senators hours to act before shutdown deadline
SUMMARY: The House has approved a short-term spending bill to fund the government until March 14. The timing leaves the Senate just hours to act before a midnight deadline to prevent a government shutdown.

TITLE: Senate passes stop-gap spending bill, preventing a government shutdown
SUMMARY: The Senate has approved a short-term spending bill to fund the government until March 14.

TITLE: Latinos are the fastest-growing fanbase in the NFL. What's the league's playbook?
SUMMARY: <em>The NFL is reaching more Latinos than ever. Here's how they've scored with a Spanish-speaking audience.

TITLE: A pair of satellites will create artificial solar eclipses to study the sun
SUMMARY: Astronomers hope the Proba-3 mission will help them get a better view of the corona, the sun's outer atmosphere, which is even hotter than the sun's surface.

TITLE: How AI deepfakes polluted elections in 2024
SUMMARY: The most visible use of AI in many countries was to create memes and content whose artificial origins weren't disguised. They were often openly shared by politicians and their supporters.

TITLE: The FDA restricts a psychoactive mushroom used in some edibles
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration has told food manufacturers the psychoactive mushroom<em> Amanita muscaria

TITLE: People power's unfinished work: Can Bangladesh be an exception?
SUMMARY: The Wilson Center's Michael Kugelman says that for many Bangladeshis, a successful youth-led mass movement has shattered a long malaise and kindled a newfound optimism about the country's future.

TITLE: Death toll in attack on German Christmas market rises to 5, with more than 200 hurt
SUMMARY: The driver was arrested shortly after the car barreled into the market at around 7 p.m. on Friday, when it was teeming with holiday shoppers looking forward to the weekend.

TITLE: Opinion: The Pope wants priests to lighten up
SUMMARY: A reflection on the comedy stylings of Pope Francis, who is telling priests to lighten up and not be so dour.

TITLE: For Pagans, winter solstice is a time for reflection and celebration
SUMMARY: <em>In the darkness of winter solstice, pagans celebrate Yule — welcoming longer days to come

TITLE: Netflix is dreaming of a glitch-free Christmas with 2 major NFL games set
SUMMARY: It comes weeks after Netflix's attempt to broadcast live boxing between Jake Paul and Mike Tyson was rife with technical glitches.

TITLE: Big dreams: He's the founder of a leading African photobook library
SUMMARY: Paul Ninson had an old-school, newfangled dream: a modern library devoted to photobooks showing life on the continent. He maxed out his credit cards, injured his back — and made it happen.

TITLE: FDA approves weight loss drug Zepbound to treat obstructive sleep apnea
SUMMARY: The FDA said studies have shown that by aiding weight loss, Zepbound improves sleep apnea symptoms in some patients.

TITLE: Sudan's biggest refugee camp was already struck with famine. Now it's being shelled
SUMMARY: The siege, blamed on the Rapid Support Forces, has sparked a new humanitarian catastrophe and marks an alarming turning point in the Darfur region, already overrun by violence.

TITLE: Party City files for bankruptcy and plans to shutter nationwide
SUMMARY: Party City was once unmatched in its vast selection of affordable celebration goods. But over the years, competition stacked up at Walmart, Target, Spirit Halloween, and especially Amazon.

TITLE: Two US Navy pilots shot down over Red Sea in apparent 'friendly fire' incident, US military says
SUMMARY: Two U.S. Navy pilots were shot down Sunday over the Red Sea by apparent "friendly fire", the most serious incident to threaten troops in over a year of America targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels.

TITLE: Pickup truck driver killed by police after driving through Texas mall and injuring 5
SUMMARY: A pickup truck driver fleeing police careened through the doors of a JCPenney store in Texas and continued through a busy mall, injuring five people before he was fatally shot by officers.

TITLE: Two US Navy pilots shot down over Red Sea in apparent 'friendly fire' incident
SUMMARY: Two U.S. Navy pilots were shot down Sunday over the Red Sea by apparent "friendly fire", the most serious incident to threaten troops in over a year of America targeting Yemen's Houthi rebels.

TITLE: I discovered one way to fight loneliness: The Germans call it a Stammtisch
SUMMARY: Modern life can be lonely. Some are looking to an old German tradition – of drinking and conversation – to deepen connection through regular meetups.

TITLE: This Christmas I'll be grieving. Here's how I'll be finding joy.
SUMMARY: Since her husband's death, newscaster Windsor Johnston has been looking for ways to recapture joy and continue her healing journey — one that's taken her to a place she'd never expected.

TITLE: On tap for the holidays: A blend of multicultural drink traditions and fond memories
SUMMARY: For this year's <em>All Things Considered

TITLE: College students get emotional about climate change. Some are finding help in class
SUMMARY: A recent survey finds that more than half of young people aged 16-25 are highly worried about climate change. Some universities are now trying to help them navigate those emotions in class.

TITLE: Israeli strikes across Gaza kill at least 20, including five children
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes across the Gaza Strip overnight and into Sunday killed at least 20 people, including five children, Palestinian medical officials said.

TITLE: Review by Senate Democrats finds more unreported luxury trips by Clarence Thomas
SUMMARY: A report by Democrats on the Judiciary Committee found additional travel taken in 2021 by Thomas but not reported on his annual financial disclosure, including trips on private jets and a yacht trip.

TITLE: Millions face wintry weather for what could be a record-setting holiday travel season
SUMMARY: More than 119 million people are expected to travel for Christmas and Hanukkah, which both fall on the same day this year, through the New Year, according to AAA.

TITLE: Blake Lively accuses 'It Ends With Us' studio of harassment and smear campaign
SUMMARY: In a legal complaint, the actor says co-star Justin Baldoni and his team launched a smear campaign as a way to silence Lively's narrative about his and a producer's alleged repeated sexual harassment.

TITLE: A million taxpayers will soon receive up to $1,400 from the IRS
SUMMARY: People who missed one of the COVID stimulus payments or had received less than the full amount were able to claim the credit.

TITLE: Albanian prime minister says TikTok ban was not a rushed reaction
SUMMARY: Prime Minister Edi Rama said over the weekend that the government will shut down TikTok for one year, accusing the popular video service of inciting violence and bullying, especially among children.

TITLE: Nissan and Honda announce merger talks amid a rapidly changing global market
SUMMARY: Japanese automakers Honda and Nissan have announced plans to work to a merger, forming the world's third-largest automaker by sales as the industry undergoes changes in its move from fossil fuels.

TITLE: The Refugees Trapped in a Corner of Syria, Now Free
SUMMARY:
In a remote corner of southeastern Syria near the border with Jordan, some 7,000 people have been trapped in a refugee camp for more than nine years. They had fled Syrian regime forces and ISIS attacks and had nowhere else they could go. Our reporter is the first person to visit the camp and learns what the future of the residents looks like now that the regime has fallen.

Support our non-profit journalism by joining NPR+

TITLE: What the Israel-Hezbollah war did to Lebanon's cultural heritage sites
SUMMARY: Part of a Crusader castle crumbled. An 18th century minaret felled. Church mosaics burned. Archaeologists are assessing damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites from Israeli strikes on Lebanon and Syria.

TITLE: Biden commutes sentences of 37 federal death row prisoners
SUMMARY: Opponents of the death penalty had urged President Biden to take this step, given the number of executions that took place during President-elect Donald Trump's first term.

TITLE: Why Trump's tariffs on Mexico would mean higher avocado prices at the grocery store
SUMMARY: Most avocados consumed in the U.S. are grown in Mexico. Here's what Trump's proposed tariffs would mean for prices at the grocery store and for the avocado industry.

TITLE: The Reddit community revives the holiday spirit after popular Secret Santa events end
SUMMARY: Swapping presents with strangers on the internet is a favorite pastime for many Reddit users. After two popular holiday gift exchanges ended, bereft merrymakers are set on keeping the tradition going.

TITLE: Undocumented people are among most vulnerable to climate-infused disasters
SUMMARY: Many undocumented people are not eligible for federal financial disaster aid and several remain fearful even when help is offered.

TITLE: 'May love rest gently in your broken heart': What to say to a grieving friend
SUMMARY: When a good friend's loved one passes away, it can be hard to find the right thing to say. NPR readers share words of comfort they've shared with others — or wish they'd heard themselves.

TITLE: Trauma lingers on for survivors of the deadly 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami
SUMMARY: One of modern history's worst natural disasters, the tsunami left about 230,000 dead across a dozen countries.

TITLE: The fun — and confusion — of celebrating Christmas and Hanukkah on the same date
SUMMARY: Christmas and Hanukkah rarely fall on the same date, but this year they do. One mixed-faith family in Oakland, Calif., doubles down for double whammy holiday.

TITLE: How hopes for Myanmar's democracy faded and why leadership is needed (again)
SUMMARY: Former U.S. Ambassador to Myanmar Derek Mitchell asks how hopes for Myanmar's democracy faded and why leadership is needed again in restoring them.

TITLE: 'We are not California': New Jersey dealers push back on electric truck rules
SUMMARY: Vehicle dealers are pushing back on rules that would increase the number of electric trucks sold in New Jersey. It could be a preview of a brewing fight over state rules about cars.

TITLE: For young adults, caregiving isn't just hard. It can shape you for life
SUMMARY: Caregiving responsibilities can cut young people off from peers and interrupt their emerging life story. And there's been little research or support directed at this group. That's starting to change.

TITLE: Biden commutes 37 federal death row sentences. And, a push to understand long COVID
SUMMARY: President Biden commuted 37 of the 40 men on federal death row to life without parole this morning. Here are the factors that drove his decision. And, a push to better understand long COVID.

TITLE: How an Israeli community helped its children heal from trauma after the Oct. 7 attack
SUMMARY: Kibbutz Be'eri was hit hard in the Hamas-led attack of Oct. 7, 2023. Survivors were evacuated to a hotel, where they worked together to create programs to help their children recover from trauma.

TITLE: Forget what you think you know about fruitcake
SUMMARY: For generations of Americans, making fun of fruitcake has been a holiday tradition.

TITLE: The Container Store files for bankruptcy, vows to keep stores operating as normal
SUMMARY: The Container Store said its 102 locations and website will continue to operate as normal during the bankruptcy process.

TITLE: House panel releases report on sexual misconduct allegations against Matt Gaetz
SUMMARY: Among other accusations, the committee found Gaetz engaged in sexual activity with a 17-year-old girl and used or possessed illegal drugs on multiple occasions. Gaetz fiercely denied the allegations.

TITLE: Walmart illegally opened delivery drivers' deposit accounts, U.S. says
SUMMARY: Lawsuit alleges Walmart and the payments platform Branch Messenger cost delivery drivers millions of dollars in fees, opening deposit accounts without consent and requiring their use to get paid.

TITLE: The numbers were good, but feelings were bad: The US economy in 2024
SUMMARY:
By most objective measures, the US economy is in good shape. Employers added about 2 million jobs this year. Unemployment is low. In much of the country, gasoline is now selling for less than $3 a gallon.

The Economist has called the United States' performance "the envy of the world."

But even as the U.S. is outperforming most other countries, many Americans remain frustrated by the high cost of living. And that's fueled a lot of unhappiness, and a political comeback for President-elect Donald Trump.

Trump will soon take the reins of an economy that's bounced back strongly during the four years he was out of office. For many families, though, that rebound was overshadowed by soaring prices for food, housing, and other necessities.

Will his policies bring costs down? Or rekindle inflation?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Bill Clinton is hospitalized with a fever but in good spirits, spokesperson says
SUMMARY: The 78-year-old former president was hospitalized "for testing and observation" after developing a fever, his deputy chief of staff said in a statement.

TITLE: Drug lord is deported to Colombia and walks free after 20 years in U.S. prisons
SUMMARY: Fabio Ochoa, one of Colombia's legendary drug lords and a key operator of the Medellin cartel, has been deported back to the South American country, where he has walked free.

TITLE: 2024 will be the hottest year on record, even hotter than expected
SUMMARY: It's looking like 2024 will be the hottest year since record-keeping began, unseating 2023 for the top spot. Climate change is playing a role, and scientists say it was even hotter than expected.

TITLE: Here are two seismic changes pushing Honda and Nissan into merger talks
SUMMARY: The two major Japanese automakers are discussing a merger. Here is what to know, from the reasons why they are doing this to how it could impact you.

TITLE: How to protect yourself from AI scams this holiday season
SUMMARY: Generative AI is making it easier for fraudsters to dupe people, now more than ever. Protect yourself from scams this holiday season with these five tips.

TITLE: In a year of tough news, these are some of the stories that made us smile in 2024
SUMMARY: Whether we were paying attention or not, 2024 was filled with good news. In case you weren't, NPR's member stations have been keeping track. Here are some of the stories that made us smile this year.

TITLE: Inside a secret Ukrainian drone command post, where Russian soldiers are seen as prey
SUMMARY: NPR visits a secret drone command center near the front lines in eastern Ukraine, where crews are using remote-controlled aircraft to hunt Russian soldiers on the battlefield.

TITLE: H-1B visas face uncertainty during Trump's 2nd term. And, the perfect mashed potatoes
SUMMARY: Foreign-born scientists may face challenges working in the U.S. during President-elect Donald Trump's second term. And, cooking tips for the perfect mashed potatoes this holiday.

TITLE: An Indian movie, loved abroad, is snubbed at home for Oscar submission
SUMMARY: <em>All We Imagine as Light

TITLE: Starbucks baristas' 'strike before Christmas' has reached hundreds of U.S. stores
SUMMARY: Starbucks' union says workers are walking off the job at some 300 — out of over 10,000 — stores across the U.S. as contract negotiations falter. The company urges it to return to the bargaining table.

TITLE: American Airlines lifts ground stop that froze Christmas Eve travelers
SUMMARY: American Airlines passengers across the U.S. endured a sudden disruption of service on Christmas Eve as a "technical issue" forced the airline to request a nationwide ground stop of its operations.

TITLE: 2023 was extremely hot. Then came 2024
SUMMARY: It's looking like 2024 will be the hottest year since record-keeping began, unseating 2023 for the top spot. Climate change is playing a role, and scientists say it was even hotter than expected.

TITLE: The Assad regime's fall has freed displaced Syrians stuck in a remote desert camp
SUMMARY: More than 7,000 people had taken shelter in the Rukban camp, near the border with Jordan, many of whom fled the regime and ISIS attacks almost a decade ago.

TITLE: Richard Perry, record producer behind 'You're So Vain' and other hits, dies at 82
SUMMARY: A recipient of a Grammys Trustee Award in 2015, Richard Perry died at a Los Angeles hospital on Tuesday. Perry was a hitmaking record producer with a flair for both standards and contemporary sounds.

TITLE: Want government money for a heat pump? Time might be running out
SUMMARY: The Biden administration introduced new consumer tax credits for climate-friendly heat pumps. What does a Trump administration and GOP-led congress mean for that money?

TITLE: Azerbaijan Airlines passenger jet crashes in the Kazakhstani city of Aktau
SUMMARY: An Azerbaijani airliner has crashed in the Kazakhstani city of Aktau with 30 people likely dead and at least 28  survivors, according to Kazakhstan's Emergency Ministry.

TITLE: 'The Bachelor,' Ukraine edition, features a veteran who lost both legs in the war
SUMMARY: He wants to give hope to the tens of thousands of Ukrainians who have lost limbs since Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Azerbaijani airliner with 67 people onboard crashes in Kazakhstan leaving 32 survivors
SUMMARY: An Azerbaijani airliner has crashed in the Kazakhstani city of Aktau with 30 people likely dead and at least 28  survivors, according to Kazakhstan's Emergency Ministry.

TITLE: When kindness becomes a habit, it improves our health
SUMMARY: Whether it's volunteering at a local school or taking soup to a sick neighbor, improving the welfare of others can also improve our own physical and mental health, a sizable body of research shows.

TITLE: A gang attack on a Haitian hospital reopening kills 2 reporters and a police officer
SUMMARY: Street gangs forced the General Hospital in Port-au-Prince to close earlier this year. As journalists gathered to cover its reopening, suspected gang members opened fire.

TITLE: Far from the front lines, Ukrainians fight a war to preserve their culture
SUMMARY: In the Transcarpathia region, some locals embrace a traditional lifestyle and cultural identity. After surviving Soviet threats, now they fear President Vladimir Putin seeks to erase their culture.

TITLE: Russia targets Ukrainian energy infrastructure on Christmas Day
SUMMARY: Russia's massive missile and drone barrage struck a thermal power plant and prompted Ukrainians to shelter in metro stations on Christmas morning.

TITLE: Azerbaijani airliner with 67 people onboard crashes, yet dozens may have survived
SUMMARY: An Azerbaijani airliner crashed Wednesday near the Kazakhstani city of Aktau with dozens dead, according to officials.

TITLE: Pope urges 'all people of all nations' to silence arms in Christmas address
SUMMARY: Pope Francis in his traditional Christmas message urged "all people of all nations" to find courage "to silence the sounds of arms and overcome divisions" plaguing the world, from the Middle East to Ukraine, Africa to Asia.

TITLE: Snowboarder's death in Swiss Alps avalanche is a reminder that even pros face risk
SUMMARY: The death of an Olympic snowboarding athlete is a reminder that even the most skilled and experienced athletes are not immune to the threat of avalanches, and that knowledge is key to staying safe.

TITLE: Scientists await signal from spacecraft after historic close encounter with the sun
SUMMARY: To get so close, the Parker Solar Probe had to withstand the sun's extreme heat and radiation like no spacecraft before it.

TITLE: Mega Millions jackpot surges past $1 billion
SUMMARY: The Mega Millions prize has now grown to an estimated $1.15 billion, which could be the fifth-largest jackpot in the game's history.

TITLE: Minn. Democratic party chair says his wins could help nationally after loss to Trump
SUMMARY: Ken Martin helped turn around the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party's finances and secure a streak of statewide wins for the party over 18 years. Now, he wants to do the same thing for the Democratic National Committee.

TITLE: Giving up alcohol for Dry January? Our newsletter can help you reach your goal
SUMMARY: If your New Year's resolution is to drink less alcohol, Life Kit is here to help. Sign up for our Dry January newsletter series, and get tips and strategies to help you stay alcohol-free for a month.

TITLE: Popeye, Tintin and more will enter the public domain in the new year
SUMMARY: The copyrights of thousands of 20th-century films, books, compositions and sound recordings expire on Jan. 1, making them free for anyone to share and adapt. Here are some of the highlights.

TITLE: Remembering the actors, musicians, writers and artists we lost in 2024
SUMMARY: Every year, we remember some of the writers, actors, musicians, filmmakers and performers who died over the past year, and whose lifetime of creative work helped shape our world.

TITLE: 100-plus cities in the U.S. banned homeless camping this year. But will it work?
SUMMARY: The burst of new laws follows a landmark Supreme Court ruling, and reflects public frustration with record-high homelessness. But advocates say fines and jail time will only make the problem worse.

TITLE: Israeli strike kills 5 Palestinian journalists in Gaza, officials say
SUMMARY: An Israeli strike killed five Palestinian journalists outside a hospital in the Gaza Strip overnight, according to the Health Ministry. The Israeli military said it had targeted a group of militants.

TITLE: Honda and Nissan consider a merger. And, Russia's Christmas Day attack in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Honda and Nissan are in talks over a merger as the auto industry sees two seismic changes. And, Russia violently attacked Ukraine's energy infrastructure on Christmas Day.

TITLE: How to navigate gift returns and regifting this holiday season
SUMMARY: Etiquette experts weigh in on what to do with that ugly sweater you got for the holidays.

TITLE: Here are some of the NPR stories that had a big impact in 2024
SUMMARY: From learning a new skill to prompting federal legislation, here are some of the ways people's lives were affected by the NPR Network's journalism this year.

TITLE: Mourners mark 20 years since Indian Ocean tsunami that killed some 230,000 people
SUMMARY: Triggered by a 9.1 magnitude earthquake off the coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra, the catastrophic event was the deadliest tsunami in recorded history.

TITLE: Photos: Fishermen, known as 'Sea Nomads,' dive to protect ocean life in Madagascar
SUMMARY: They make their living off the sea, but their catch is dwindling. So these traditional fisherfolk are taking steps to preserve both sea life — and their livelihood.

TITLE: Investigation begins into the cause of the Azerbaijan Airlines crash
SUMMARY: Azerbaijan observed a day of mourning for the victims of the plane crash that killed 38 people and left all 29 survivors injured as speculation mounted about a possible cause of the disaster.

TITLE: Giving a kidney to a stranger? Researchers call it 'extraordinary altruism'
SUMMARY: Only about 300 to 400 people a year give a kidney to someone they never met. It's an act of generosity so unusual, a neuroscientist studies the people who do this.

TITLE: Manmohan Singh, India's prime minister from 2004 to 2014, has died
SUMMARY: Singh was known as the father of economic reforms in India. He served as finance minister in the early 1990s, and his policies then set India on the path of economic liberalization and globalization.

TITLE: Israel strikes Houthi targets in Yemen's capital. WHO chief says he was nearby
SUMMARY: A round of Israeli airstrikes targeted the Houthi rebel-held capital and multiple ports. The head of the World Health Organization said the bombardment occurred as he prepared to board a flight.

TITLE: The 'Beyoncé Bowl' halftime show was a massive hit for Netflix. The football was too
SUMMARY: Netflix says more than 200 countries tuned into the "Beyoncé Bowl" and its two NFL games. We may just be starting to learn what that ultimately means for the future of television and sports media.

TITLE: Bird flu has killed 20 big cats including cougars at a U.S. wildlife sanctuary
SUMMARY: The sanctuary in Washington state said it was working with officials to determine the cause of the outbreak, which has killed over half of its cats in recent weeks.

TITLE: Biden is expected to announce new asylum rules for migrants at the border
SUMMARY: President Biden is expected to issue an executive order Tuesday that would greatly reduce the number of asylum-seekers allowed into the country.

TITLE: French authorities indict Telegram founder Pavel Durov on multiple charges
SUMMARY: Charges against the CEO of Telegram mark one of the few instances where the head of a major internet platform has been charged over alleged criminal failure to moderate what users do on its site.

TITLE: Honda and Nissan consider a merger. And, Russia's Christmas Day attack in Ukraine
SUMMARY: Honda and Nissan are in talks over a merger as the auto industry sees two seismic changes. And, Russia violently attacked Ukraine's energy infrastructure on Christmas Day.

TITLE: How to navigate gift returns and regifting this holiday season
SUMMARY: Etiquette experts weigh in on what to do with that ugly sweater you got for the holidays.

TITLE: Aviation experts say Russia's air defense fire likely caused Azerbaijan plane crash
SUMMARY: As Azerbaijan observed a day of mourning for victims of the plane crash that killed 38 people, experts pointed to a possible cause: fire from Russia's air defense against a Ukrainian drone attack.

TITLE: Richard Parsons, who steadied Time Warner and Citigroup, dies at 76
SUMMARY: Parsons, one of corporate America's most prominent Black executives who held top posts at Time Warner and Citigroup, was known as a skilled negotiator, a diplomat and a crisis manager.

TITLE: Finland detains Russia-linked vessel over damaged undersea power cable in Baltic Sea
SUMMARY: Finnish authorities detained a ship linked to neighboring Russia that Finnish customs officials and the European Union's executive commission describe as part of Russia's shadow fleet of fuel tankers.

TITLE: South Korea's opposition-controlled parliament votes to impeach acting president
SUMMARY: The impeachments of the country's president and then acting-president worsen the nation's political turmoil, deepen its economic uncertainty and hurt its international image.

TITLE: At the end of 1999, many thought Y2K would cause the world to collapse
SUMMARY: At the end of 1999, there was anxiety about a potential computer glitch known as Y2K. Some thought the world would crumble, including some who waited out the apocalypse in an old house in the woods.

TITLE: The World's Largest River is Running Low (Encore)
SUMMARY:
The region drained by the Amazon River, including the Amazon Rainforest, is in the second year of a punishing drought. That has lead to the lowest water levels in more than 100 years for the Amazon and its major tributaries. Millions of people and an array of wildlife depend on those quickly disappearing waters. In a story we first brought you in October, we travel to the region to see the effects.

Support our non-profit journalism by joining NPR+

TITLE: Congressional lawmakers almost got a pay bump this year. Then it crashed and burned
SUMMARY: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill haven't had a pay increase since 2009, representing a 31% decline in their salary when adjusted for inflation.

TITLE: A health care provider that faced dozens of prisoner lawsuits is filing for bankruptcy
SUMMARY: Wellpath, a health care provider for hospitals, prisons and jails, has been dogged by wrongful death and medical negligence suits. What happens to those cases now that it has filed for bankruptcy?

TITLE: For homeless seniors, finding stable housing takes a village — and a lot of luck
SUMMARY: The number of unhoused seniors is expected to triple by 2030. As rents rise, it becomes tougher to find affordable housing that's accessible for those with medical conditions and disabilities.

TITLE: A wild year in politics, by the numbers
SUMMARY: From the election results to the the charges against President-elect Donald Trump, here are the numbers that defined 2024 in politics.

TITLE: Protests in Georgia continue as demonstrators rally in support for joining the EU
SUMMARY: On the eastern edge of the Black Sea, the Georgian president is refusing to step down, as demonstrations have gone on for weeks in support of Georgia joining the European Union.

TITLE: More than 10,000 migrants died in 2024 trying to reach Spain by sea, aid group says
SUMMARY: The migration route that connects West African nations with the Spanish Canary Islands remains the deadliest in the world, according to a Spanish aid organization.

TITLE: South Korea's acting president impeached. And, how the 'Beyoncé Bowl' did on Netflix
SUMMARY: South Korea's acting president has been impeached less than a month after the impeachment of his predecessor, Yoon Suk Yeol, for imposing martial law. And, how'd the "Beyoncé Bowl" do on Netflix?

TITLE: Global stories from 2024 that we loved ... but that you may have missed
SUMMARY: These stories didn't get huge numbers of views, but readers who found them stayed with them for what qualifies as an eternity on the online clock. Here are our underappreciated favorites.

TITLE: How a fox skull shape conquers the snow
SUMMARY: Research explains how foxes hunting mice can plunge down into the snow at high speeds without injuring their poor little snouts.

TITLE: Top global TikToks in 2024: Mr. Bean disciple, lip-sync for their life, baby hippo!
SUMMARY: Scenes from some of the most popular TikToks from the Global South in 2024: a dancing teen from the Philippines; an homage to Mr. Bean, that cute baby pygmy hippo.

TITLE: New leaders in Damascus call for cordial Syria ties with a resistant Israel
SUMMARY: "Our problem is not with Israel. We don't want to meddle in anything that will threaten Israel's security," Damascus Governor Maher Marwan tells NPR. Syria and Israel have never had diplomatic ties.

TITLE: Rescue team ends search for a man overboard from Norwegian Cruise Line ship
SUMMARY: The tragedy marks the 19th overboard incident on a cruise ship this year, with only two passengers successfully rescued.

TITLE: Top global TikToks in 2024: Mr. Bean disciple, lip-synch for their life, baby hippo!
SUMMARY: Scenes from some of the most popular TikToks from the Global South in 2024: a dancing teen from the Philippines; an homage to Mr. Bean, that cute baby pygmy hippo.

TITLE: Claim of dementia could derail former Abercrombie CEO's sex trafficking case
SUMMARY: Can his legal team's claims that he has late-onset Alzheimer's disease and dementia put a pause in the sex trafficking trial of former Abercrombie & Fitch CEO Mike Jeffries?

TITLE: Delta apologizes - again - after another stowaway boards a flight without ticket
SUMMARY: The incident marks the second time in less than a month that an unticketed passenger was discovered on a Delta Air Lines flight, this time en route to Hawaii.

TITLE: Photos from Azerbaijan jet crash suggest a missile strike, according to experts
SUMMARY: The Embraer 190 with 67 passengers and crew was flying from the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to Grozny in Chechnya, Russia, when it crashed in Kazakhstan on Wednesday, killing 38 people.

TITLE: Syria's U.S.-backed Kurdish coalition faces an uncertain future after Assad's ouster
SUMMARY: After Bashar al-Assad's ouster, there are questions about the fate of the Syrian Democratic Forces, the U.S.-backed Kurdish coalition that currently controls a third of Syrian territory.

TITLE: At least 9 people died when a bridge collapsed in Brazil
SUMMARY: Another eight people remain unaccounted for. Several cars and trucks plunged into the Tocantins River after a section of the 1,748-foot-long bridge crumbled on Sunday.

TITLE: Costco egg recall for salmonella receives FDA's most severe designation
SUMMARY: The FDA has classified its recall of eggs sold under Costco's Kirkland brand as a Class I recall, a designation reserved for instances of the highest potential health risk — including death.

TITLE: Delta apologizes — again — after another stowaway boards a flight without ticket
SUMMARY: The incident marks the second time in less than a month that an unticketed passenger was discovered on a Delta Air Lines flight, this time en route to Hawaii.

TITLE: U.S. homelessness jumps to another record high, amid affordable housing shortage
SUMMARY: The annual federal count finds more than 770,000 people living in shelters or outside. It cites rising rents and the recent surge in migrants as key factors behind the increase.

TITLE: Sportscaster Greg Gumbel dies at age 78
SUMMARY: Greg Gumbel, a longtime CBS sportscaster, has died from cancer, according to a statement from family released by CBS on Friday. He was 78.

TITLE: Trump asks the Supreme Court to delay the start of the TikTok ban
SUMMARY: President-elect Donald Trump asked the Supreme Court on Friday to pause the potential TikTok ban from going into effect until his administration can pursue a "political resolution" to the issue.

TITLE: Winning ticket for $1.22 billion lottery jackpot sold in California, Mega Millions says
SUMMARY: After three months without anyone winning the top prize in the lottery, a ticket worth an estimated $1.22 billion was sold in California for the drawing Friday night.

TITLE: New year, new pygmy hippo: A naming poll for this Virginia zoo baby is underway
SUMMARY: Moo Deng and Haggis are joined by another slick, round supreme on the scene. Fans of the new baby can cast their vote to name her until New Year's Eve, with the winning name announced the next day.

TITLE: A sea turtle plagued by 'bubble butt' condition is helped by a 3D printer
SUMMARY: "Bubble butt" can leave turtles struggling to swim normally — or unable to submerge at all. A 3D-printed harness can help.

TITLE: With Trump's Panama Canal talk, it feels like 1976 all over again
SUMMARY: It's unclear how the issue of ownership of the Panama Canal became a talking point for President-elect Donald Trump this week, but the question has a long political history.

TITLE: Curious about Dry January? What to expect — and how it works
SUMMARY: If your New Year's resolution is to give up drinking for the month of January, this expert guide can help you get to Day 31 alcohol-free.

TITLE: Opinion: Prayers are messages for our own hearts
SUMMARY: Hanukah began on Christmas this year. A reflection on celebrating both holidays in a multi-faith family.

TITLE: Putin apologizes to Azerbaijani leader for 'tragic incident' involving crashed plane
SUMMARY: The Kremlin said air defense systems were firing near Grozny due to a Ukrainian drone strike as the airliner attempted to land, but stopped short of saying it was shot down by Russian air defenses.

TITLE: In Fresno, one of California's toughest new camping bans comes into focus
SUMMARY: Three months since Fresno implemented its new law, police have made over 300 arrests, but only a few unhoused people are taking them up on drug treatment services

TITLE: How to fight ageism in the world around you — and in yourself
SUMMARY: Discrimination based on someone's age is so ingrained in society that most of us don't notice it. Yet it affects us all and fighting it not only helps make a better society, it also helps us live longer, healthier lives.

TITLE: Severe weather could disrupt holiday travel, with tornadoes forecast in the South
SUMMARY: Severe thunderstorms and an outbreak of tornadoes could disrupt holiday travel Saturday. More than 3,000 flights were delayed.

TITLE: Instagram reel roundup: School for dads, COVID conundrum, skateboarders in skirts
SUMMARY: The most popular Instagram reels from our Goats and Soda team: Bolivia's bold women skateboarders, ponytail-making lessons, a perplexing COVID situation, fog harvesting.

TITLE: Israel detains a Gaza hospital director, Palestinian medical officials say
SUMMARY: Gaza's Health Ministry said Dr. Hussam Abu Safiya, director of Kamal Adwan Hospital, was arrested by Israeli forces along with dozens of other staff and taken to an interrogation center.

TITLE: Y2K seems like a joke now, but in 1999 people were really freaking out
SUMMARY: People feared the computer glitch would mean "the end of the world as we know it." Thankfully, Y2K didn't live up to the hype after years and billions of dollars were spent on painstaking preparation.

TITLE: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says U.S. could hit debt limit in weeks
SUMMARY: Yellen told Congress her agency will need to start taking "extraordinary measures," or special accounting maneuvers intended to prevent the nation from hitting the debt ceiling, as early as Jan. 14.

TITLE: Olivia Hussey, star of the 1968 film 'Romeo and Juliet,' dies at 73
SUMMARY: Hussey was 15 when director Franco Zeffirelli cast her in his adaptation of the Shakespeare tragedy. The film won two Oscars and Hussey won a Golden Globe for best new actress for her part as Juliet.

TITLE: Magnus Carlsen quits chess championship after refusing to change out of jeans
SUMMARY: The Norwegian chess grandmaster was fined $200 and given a warning by the International Chess Federation (FIDE) to change into acceptable attire or be disqualified.

TITLE: Big Lots reaches deal to keep hundreds of U.S. stores open
SUMMARY: Big Lots said Friday it will be sold to Gordon Brothers Retail Partners, a firm that specializes in distressed companies.

TITLE: WHO chief recounts narrow escape at Yemen airport hit by Israeli missile
SUMMARY: The World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says he and colleagues "escaped death narrowly" when an Israeli airstrike targeted Yemen's main airport.

TITLE: A plane has caught fire at a South Korean airport and rescue work is underway
SUMMARY: The emergency office says the plane caught fire at an airport in Muan after its landing gear malfunctioned.

TITLE: Severe weather takes a deadly turn in the U.S. South as tornadoes touch down
SUMMARY: The National Weather Service said it confirmed several tornadoes had touched down outside of Houston on Saturday.

TITLE: Plane burst into flames at an airport in South Korea, killing at least 28
SUMMARY: South Korea's emergency office said the fire was put out and rescue officials were trying to remove passengers from the Jeju Air passenger plane at the airport in the South Korean city of Muan.

TITLE: Plane burst into flames at an airport in South Korea, killing at least 47
SUMMARY: Footage of the crash aired by YTN television showed the Jeju Air plane skidding across the airstrip, apparently with its landing gear still closed, and colliding head-on with a concrete wall on the outskirts of the facility.

SUMMARY: The ban, which will take effect on Jan. 1, is based on health and environmental grounds and is a groundbreaking move for European Union nations.

SUMMARY: When Syria's dictatorship fell, celebrations broke out around the world, including in Ohio, where Mohammed al-Refai, a refugee from Syria, lives now. NPR has followed his story for nearly a decade.

TITLE: What were the biggest life lessons in 2024? Here's what NPR listeners learned
SUMMARY: The year is coming to an end and with it, many lessons were learned. Some of which could have altered how we move forward into the new year. NPR listeners provide insight on their lessons from 2024.

TITLE: Under a 'grandma moon,' Native Americans honor their sacred pact with salmon
SUMMARY: Native American New Year was celebrated on the solstice under a canopy of winter stars. Near a crackling bonfire, the Nisqually tribe shared their culture and renewed their sacred pact with the salmon.

TITLE: He left everything to flee war in Syria. What does the war's end mean for his future?
SUMMARY:
When Syria's dictatorship fell in early December, celebrations broke out around the world - including nearly 6,000 miles away, in Toledo, Ohio.

That's where Mohammed al-Refai, a refugee from Syria, lives now. NPR has followed his story for nearly a decade.

In 2015, millions of Syrians fled the civil war in their country. al-Refai got a visa to come to the U.S. His parents and siblings, who fled to Jordan, did not. So, he moved on his own to Toledo, where built a new life for himself.

He long dreamed of visiting his family and maybe, one day, returning to Syria.

With the Syrian civil war now over, we talked to al-Refai about what comes next.

TITLE: 2 men were found dead from exposure after looking for Sasquatch
SUMMARY: The bodies of two men looking for Sasquatch were found in a forest in Washington state after a three-day search.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter, former U.S. president and peace activist, dies at 100
SUMMARY: Carter was president from 1977 to 1981, but he was perhaps more famous for the life he led after he left office. He was one of the biggest advocates for peace, democracy and human rights.

TITLE: A look back at Jimmy Carter's presidency
SUMMARY: Former President Jimmy Carter served as president of the United States from 1977 to 1981, with a focus on human rights-centered policies.

TITLE: Carter's single White House term still stirs controversy after more than 40 years
SUMMARY: Jimmy Carter was a former one-term governor from Georgia, almost unknown nationally, when he broke through in Iowa and New Hampshire early in 1976 and rode that momentum all the way to Washington.

TITLE: These were the most-borrowed books from public libraries in 2024
SUMMARY: Many of the most-borrowed books in 2024, including 'romantasy' titles and memoirs, also appeared on public library lists in 2023.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter gave Panama control of the canal. It's one of his most controversial achievements
SUMMARY: Handing control of the Panama Canal from the U.S. over to the Central American country was one of President Jimmy Carter's most controversial, and most overshadowed, foreign policy achievements.

TITLE: At least 3 migrants die trying to cross the English Channel
SUMMARY: This latest incident comes as 2024 is named the deadliest year on record for small boat crossings along the perilous migration route.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter to be honored with a state funeral before being buried next to Rosalynn
SUMMARY: Carter was president from 1977 to 1981, but he was perhaps more famous for the life he led after he left office. He was one of the biggest advocates for peace, democracy and human rights.

TITLE: 2024 in photos: NPR station photographers share memorable moments
SUMMARY: NPR's member and affiliate station photographers share memorable moments from throughout 2024.

TITLE: Carter made the decision to establish relations with China
SUMMARY: Carter helped make ties between Washington and Beijing, ushering in an era of engagement that brought China out of isolation and underpinned its meteoric economic rise.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter had an early ally in the Senate: a young Democrat named Joe Biden
SUMMARY: When they met in the mid-1970s, Jimmy Carter and Joe Biden were both political underdogs. They forged a strong friendship that lasted more than 50 years.

TITLE: For seniors with hoarding disorder, a support group helps with stigma and isolation
SUMMARY: Concern is growing about the prevalence of hoarding disorder among seniors, and the lack of access to effective treatments. Some have found coping strategies — and community — in a support group.

TITLE: 10 essential books about Jimmy Carter
SUMMARY: Throughout his lifetime, Jimmy Carter took on many titles: 39th President of the United States, Nobel Peace Prize winner, philanthropist, humanitarian, artist – and writer.

TITLE: Bird flu Q&A: What to know to help protect yourself and your pets
SUMMARY: Each week some revelation about bird flu seems to flutter through the news cycle. Here's what the latest research is saying about how it is spreading and how to keep yourself and your pets safe.

TITLE: Four years after the Capitol riot, why QAnon hasn't gone away
SUMMARY: QAnon followers played an outsized role in the Jan. 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol. While the online conspiracy community is less prominent now, it still draws attention from GOP politicians.

TITLE: A look at Jimmy Carter's legacy. And, rules for regifting unwanted presents
SUMMARY: Jimmy Carter, the 39th president of the U.S., died in Plains, Ga. on Sunday at age 100. Here's a look back at his legacy during and after his presidency. And, the rules of regifting and returns.

TITLE: Egyptian and Israeli leaders send condolences for Carter, who brokered their peace treaty
SUMMARY: One of the crowning foreign policy achievements of Carter's single term as U.S. president was brokering a series of agreements that later came to be called the Camp David accords in 1978.

TITLE: Former President Jimmy Carter: The 'Fresh Air' interviews (Part 1)
SUMMARY: The 39th president spoke with Terry Gross in 1993, '95, '96 and '98 about growing up on a Georgia farm, entering politics and his advocacy for human rights and peace. Carter died Dec. 29 at age 100.

TITLE: Court rejects Trump appeal in E. Jean Carroll sexual abuse and defamation case
SUMMARY: Trump contended the trial court judge erred in several rulings — including decisions to allow the testimony of two women who alleged that Trump sexually assaulted them in the past.

TITLE: 9 countries said goodbye to a devastating disease in 2024
SUMMARY: Nine countries eliminated a disease in 2024. Here's how Pakistan pulled it off — fulfilling a young boy's dream of eliminating blindness caused by bacterial infections.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter was 'a very unusual kind of politician,' biographer says
SUMMARY: In the wake of Jimmy Carter's death, biographer Kai Bird, author of 'The Outlier: The Unfinished Presidency of Jimmy Carter' discusses the late president's successes and failures.

TITLE: 5 people have been charged in the death of Liam Payne
SUMMARY: An Argentine judge ordered pretrial detention for two of the charged for suppling Payne with drugs. Prosecutors had filed initial charges against three people in November but didn't reveal their names.

TITLE: Top chess player is back in competition after quitting over dress code
SUMMARY: Magnus Carlsen, the No. 1 ranked chess player, quit the World Rapid Chess Championship in New York on Friday after refusing to change out of jeans to conform to a strict dress code.

TITLE: Top chess player Magnus Carlsen is back in competition after quitting over dress code
SUMMARY: Magnus Carlsen, the No. 1 ranked chess player, quit the World Rapid Chess Championship in New York on Friday after refusing to change out of jeans to conform to a strict dress code.

TITLE: Photos: Former President Carter redefined post-presidency role
SUMMARY: The Nobel Peace Prize winner devoted himself to improving the health of people around the world, promoting democracy and resolving global conflicts.

TITLE: In Jimmy Carter's hometown of Plains, people remember the former president
SUMMARY: People in Plains, Ga., are remembering former President Jimmy Carter who died on Sunday at the age of 100. Carter embraced his hometown and never forgot the importance of the place.

TITLE: Jimmy Carter will have funeral services in Plains, Ga., Atlanta and Washington, D.C.
SUMMARY: Former President Jimmy Carter's state funeral services will span six days, three cities and multiple places of significance from his life.

TITLE: Treasury says Chinese hackers remotely accessed documents in 'major' cyber incident
SUMMARY: The revelation comes as the U.S. grapples with a massive cyberespionage campaign that gave Chinese officials access to private texts and phone conversations of an unknown number of Americans.

TITLE: South Korea to inspect Boeing aircraft as it struggles to find cause of plane crash
SUMMARY: Many worry how effectively the South Korean government will handle the disaster as it grapples with a leadership vacuum after the impeachments of the country's top two officials.

SUMMARY: Here's what NPR's White House correspondents would ask Biden at a press conference as his presidency comes to a close.

TITLE: What to know about Finland, Russia's 'shadow fleet' and a severed undersea cable
SUMMARY: Finland says a ship affiliated with Russia's "shadow fleet" is linked to a 60-mile-long anchor drag mark on the seafloor. A power cable in the Baltic Sea was severed last week.

TITLE: Transit systems turn to AI-powered cameras to catch drivers who block bus lanes
SUMMARY: The nation's biggest transit systems are using AI-enhanced cameras to keep bus lanes clear of illegally parked cars. That's making buses move faster, but the rollout has hit a few speed bumps.

SUMMARY: Watching a huge ball descend down a pole in Times Square has been a beloved New Year's Eve tradition for over a century. Here's how the spectacle started and what's changed over the years.

SUMMARY: Bird strikes occur daily for commercial flights, costing airlines millions in damages each year. Although rare, these incidents can result in injuries and fatalities.

SUMMARY: From charismatic macrofauna to tiny sea squirts, here are some species formally identified by scientists in 2024.

SUMMARY: President Biden signed significant legislation that his backers say will leave a lasting impact. And, north Gaza's last major hospital has been shut down with no ceasefire in sight.

SUMMARY: Conservationists are getting better at monitoring the movement of the highly endangered Right Whale. They hope it will help encourage ships to slow down in an effort to save the species.

SUMMARY: NPR's health reporters followed the emerging science on what keeps our brains and our minds healthy. Here are highlights of the studies that piqued our readers' interest the most.

SUMMARY: More than 1.3 million people were plunged into darkness early Tuesday. Failure of an underground power line is believed to be the cause and repairs could take up to two days.

SUMMARY: Bird strikes occur daily for commercial flights, costing airlines millions in damages each year. Although rare, these incidents can result in injuries and fatalities.

SUMMARY: The northern lights could be visible Tuesday night and Wednesday night over the Northern Hemisphere due to a geomagnetic storm.

SUMMARY: Former opposition groups — some of whom are U.S.-trained — will be knitted together into new Syrian security forces organized by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the group that led the ouster of Bashar al-Assad.

SUMMARY: The couple married in 2014, but separated two years later. A lengthy legal battle ensued over custody of their children and the future of their once-shared Château Miraval.
